column13: Sgt. Knapp, P.O. Dominguez, P.O. Farhi and I responded to the listed location for an aggravated assault report. Upon arrival, we observed the victim laying on the ground alert and conscious with his face covered in his own blood. The victim suffered a laceration to the left side of his face. The witnesses and victim were heavily intoxicated while attempting to report the incident.      The victim reported that the suspect was a chubby Hispanic male with unknown clothing description. He further reported that the witnesses were in a verbal argument with the suspect over a cigarette. While attempting to diffuse the argument, he was struck in the head with a bat like object in front of the Briarcliff Apartments. The victim does not remember the amount of times he was struck. Hackensack ambulance #101 and #1341 responded, treated and transported him to Hackensack University Medical Center. P.O. Farhi responded to the hospital for further.      Both witnesses reported that the suspects were black males, unknown ages and unknown clothing descriptions. They further reported that a cigarette was disposed onto the Briarcliff Apartment lawn. One of the two suspects appeared from the bushes and confronted the witnesses about the cigarette. The witnesses reported while the victim attempted to stop the argument, the second suspect charged at them from the apartment complex and struck the victim several times with a bat like object. The suspects fled the area into the apartment complex. The witnesses do not remember if the suspects entered an apartment or fled the area. They also could not describe the weapon other than it possibly being a bat like object.      We searched the area for the weapon and suspects which yielded negative results. Det. Magnotta and Det. Shields from Bergen County Sheriffs Department responded to process the scene. See case #2020-0003. Det. Mora responded. A New Jersey Victim Notification form was completed. P.O. Dominguez transported the witnesses to headquarters for further investigation. Tot Detectives.

P.O. Katsaroans and I responded to the listed location on a report of a 9-1-1 Hang up in which two people were heard arguing prior to disconnecting the phone call. On arrival, we located the victim, Fernando Lucero, who reported that the suspects, Denys Ludizaca and "Anthony" Ludizaca, assaulted him while they were drinking with each other. The victim had a cut to his eye and was bleeding on our arrival. The victim was offered an ambulance which he refused. I asked the victim what started the incident to which he stated that a verbal argument started near the kitchen of the home.  The victim stated that he observed a handgun in the kitchen and confronted Denys over it. The victim described the handgun as a black square metal gun that was approximately 6 inches in length and stated that it was possibly still within the kitchen. The victim stated to Denys that the reason he has to go to court (traffic violation) is because of him and this gun. It should be noted that the victim, was stopped while driving a vehicle that matched a bolo description for an armed robbery incident that occurred in South Hackensack. The victim was subsequently issued a summons for driving without a license by this officer during that motor vehicle stop. After Denys was confronted by the victim,  the suspects began to punch the victim and a fight ensued. The victim grabbed a chair and used it to defend himself against the suspects. As per the victim the suspects were still inside the home.      P.O. Katsaroans, Sgt. Bay and I made contact with Amy Ludizaca and advised her of the fight incident. I asked her if Denys was home to which she stated that he left. Headquarters confirmed that Denys had an outstanding warrant from South Hackensack for robbery. I then asked her if we could check the home for him which she freely and voluntarily agreed. She escorted us into the home and a check of the home was negative for the suspect.      The victim was unsure if he wished to pursue a criminal complaint against the suspect at this time. He was advised of the procedure on how to proceed with one at a later date if he wished to do so.

P.O. Reo, P.O. Rios and I responded to the listed location on a fight in progress. Upon arrival, I spoke to the victim who stated that while he was sitting inside the listed location (Angelos Deli) the suspect entered the store and began arguing with him. The victim stated that he is familiar with the suspect. During the verbal argument, the suspect punched the victim with a closed fist, which caused swelling above the left eye. The victim refused to have an ambulance responded on scene. At this time the victim only wants the incident documented.

Mr. Fernando Franco, a tow truck driver with Lightning Towing, responded to police headquarters with the listed vehicle as a recovered stolen vehicle.  Mr. Franco advised that he had picked up the vehicle from Bergen Brookside in this City on behalf of PV Holding Corporation (Avis Budget car rental).  Mr. Franco provided a notarized letter allowing the release of the vehicle to him as well as the vehicle title.  A hit notification was sent to NYPD where the vehicle was reported stolen.  The vehicle was subsequently removed from NCIC.  I examined the vehicle which was involved in an accident and appeared to be a total loss with heavy front and front right damage.  It appeared that all the airbags had deployed as well.  The appropriate paperwork was placed in the BCI box.

The complainant responded to police headquarters on behalf of the victim, Harini Mittal, to report her vehicle as stolen. The complainant provided me with valid notarized documents stating the victim was allowing the complainant to make this report due to the victim not being in the country at the moment.     The complainant stated the victim parked her vehicle in the rear parking lot of 290 Anderson Street in space number 65 on 12/20/2020 at 17:00 hours. The victim then received an alarm notification from Hyundai Blue Link on 01/07/2021 at 12:17 hours stating the vehicle's alarm had been triggered. The victim then contacted the complainant to respond to her residence to see if she could locate the vehicle.     The complainant stated she checked the entire parking lot and had negative results on locating the vehicle. The total amount loss is $23,000 dollars. The vehicle did not have insurance the time it was stolen. A Hackensack stolen auto card was completed. The vehicle was then entered into the NCIC system as stolen. A victim notification form was completed. All documents in regards to this case was left in the detective box with the case number attached.

On the listed date and time I responded to the area of 560 Hudson St on a report of a stolen vehicle.  Upon arrival I spoke with the complainant and owner of the vehicle, Henry Rojas Aguilera who stated that he parked his vehicle, a gray Nissan Sentra PALJC1245 in front of 560 Hudson St at approximately 1400 hours on this date.  He returned to where he parked the vehicle at approximately 1640 hours and noticed that the vehicle was missing.  The complainant stated that he was in possession of the vehicle key and also stated that the vehicle was locked.  He further stated that he was up to date on all payments and confirmed with his bank.  According to the complainant the vehicle is worth approximately $8,000.00.  The complainant mentioned that when he bought the vehicle he made a $4000.00 down payment but owed a total of $15,000.00 due to interest.      This Officer checked the area where the complainant stated the vehicle was parked.  No broken glass or any other signs of forced entry were observed in the vicinity.  The vehicle was entered stolen into NCIC.

The victim and suspect are not and never have been in a dating relationship. They do not nor have ever lived together. They also do not have any children in common.      On this date S.P.O. Abueg and I were dispatched to the listed location on a dispute call. Upon arrival we were able to speak to the victim, Casssandra Gipson. She informed us that her and the suspect, Christopher Clinkscales had engaged in a verbal argument that escalated into a pushing match between the two. The victim further stated that she had fallen on the cement stairs outside of that location as a result of being pushed. She also stated that she had struck her head causing a knot on the back of her head. She informed us that the suspect fled inside the building.     We went to the suspect's listed apartment C6. The suspect's grandmother, Sylvia Clinskscales informed us that the suspect was not at home and she has not seen him.     An ambulance was requested to check the victim's injuries. Soon after Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance Squad arrived. The subject was checked at the scene and elected to be checked out at HUMC. A Victim Notification Form was competed. The victim was also advised on how to sign complaints at later date, if she wished to do so.

P.O. Shiehk and I responded to the listed address on a report of a domestic dispute between father and son. The victim and defendant are family members who reside in the listed apartment. Upon arrival we spoke with the victim, Anthony Green (9/14/1959), who was yelling from inside his bedroom slurring his speech and appeared to be intoxicated. He stated that his son, Anthony Green 3rd (11/16/1997), punched his flat screen television set after an argument regarding dinner. The television had a small crack in the center of the screen. The value of the television set is $150.00 according to the victim. The defendant gave a similar account as to what happened, admitting to punching the television. The defendant sustained a minor cut to his right hand from punching the television to which he refused medical attention. It should be noted that the victim was extremely uncooperative during the entire encounter while trying to explain his Domestic Violence rights.  I completed a Victim Notification form to which the victim declined to apply for a Temporary Restraining Order at this time, but will make a decision in the near future. The victim refused to initial and sign the Victim Notification Form. The victim also refused to speak with a DVRT member and complete a written statement. He also refused to sign the DVRT paperwork. The defendant was dispersed from the area without incident. We explained to the victim the process of signing complaints in the future.

column2: Service of TRO / FROWarrant Arrest
column13: On the listed date and time, Sgt. Klosk,  P.O Reyes and I responded to the listed address to serve a TRO first attempt( no docket number given) and also warrant arrest (W-2021-000050).Upon arrival, we made contact with the defendant, Johnnie Hawkins and advised him of the listed warrant. At that point the arrestee was placed under arrest and searched incident to arrest. The search yielded negative contraband.The arrestee was transported to headquarters in radio car 108. The rear seat was checked for contraband prior and after the transportation with negative results. Upon arrival to headquarters, a secondary search was made with negative results.The arrestee was photographed and processed by P.O. E. Reyes. The arestee was transported to Bergen County Jail without incident.  The arestee was also given a copy of the TRO.

On 1/22/2021 at approximately 10:28 A.M. Officer Debonis and myself were dispatched to 211 Hudson St. ( Lin Z towing ) on a dispute.Upon our arrival Ms. Gray ( victim 1 ) and her son ( Victim 2 ) were in the parking lot arguing. When asked what was going on. Ms. Gray stated that they were trying to pull into the gas station to get gas but a truck was in the way. Her son got out of the car tapped on the window to the truck and asked them to move. The truck backed up then started to leave but stopped. When her son went back up to the driver door.  The driver opened the door and punched her son in the face. The driver then exited the vehicle and started fighting with her son. She exited her vehicle and tried to stop them from  fighting. The actor then pushed her to the ground.  She stated that the actor pulled out an exacto blade, then went around the truck got back in and left the scene. The company name on the side of the van was Colonial Moving in Hackensack NJ. The actor was heavy set Hispanic male around 5'10 wearing a green hat, black jacket and black sweatpants.   Victim 2 was very uncooperative and belligerent toward us, he refused to give his name or any information.  Officer Debonis requested a Supervisor to respond to the scene. Sgt. Dominguez arrived on scene. Victim 2 was still uncooperative, he stated he didn't want to report anything and that he will handle it. Ms. Gray-Thompson ( witness ) gave the same statement that victim 1 provided.  I spoke to the owner of Lin Z towing he advised that he does have a camera system and the footage would be good for about 30 days if the detectives need a copy.Victim 1 stated that she had somewhere to go and she will come to Headquarters at a later date.Detective division was notified of the situation and will take a statement when the Victim decides to come to Headquarters.

On the listed date and time, P.O. Sheikh and I responded to the listed address on a dispute. The victim, David Giraldo, reported that while visiting Alyssa Rivera, who is the  home owner of 98  Berry St., an ex-boyfriend of hers assaulted him.   While speaking with the victim, David Giraldo. He stated that at approximately 0120 hours, while he was on a first date with the witness, Alyssa Rivera, the door bell rang. The victim stated he was in the living room when the witness opened the front door and her ex-boyfriend, Wilson Mateo (suspect) barged into the home and stated to him "Who the fuck are you!." The complainant stated at that point and with out provocation, the suspect began to punch him with a closed fist several times on the faceand kneed him in the face. The suspects then exited the home, stating "I know who you are and what you drive."  I requested a supervisor. Sgt. Bay and Sgt. Klosk arrived to assist.   I observed swelling on the victims forehead and he complained of pain to his jaw. The victim requested an ambulance. Hackensack Volunteer ambulance #192 responded and evaluated the victim. The victim refused transport to Hackensack University Medical Center.    The victim stated at this time, he would like the incident to be documented. The victim was advised on how to file a complaint at a later date if should he change his mind.    I then spoke to the witness who stated that when the door bell rang, she opened the front door and allowed the suspect to cross the front door threshold. The witness stated when she told the suspect she was on a date and it was not a good time to speak, the suspect walked passed her, approached the victim and assaulted him. The witness stated during the incident, she was not assaulted and did not wish any police action.

The victim, who is the owner of the vehicle, responded to headquarters to report a motor vehicle theft.  The victim reported that on 1/24/21 at approximately 22:30 hours, a friend who had been borrowing the vehicle notified the victim that it was left parked out front of 101 Prospect Avenue this city due to the friend being transported to the hospital. The victim reported that she arrived at 101 Prospect that evening to retrieve the vehicle, but could not locate it. The victim proceeded to call multiple towing companies, police departments, as well as the Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance department in order to find out information on the whereabouts of her vehicle. It should be noted that on 1/24/21, the victim's friend was transported to Hackensack University Medical Center via ambulance and a report was generated, however there was no mention of the vehicle by the victim's friend (See Case #21-005561). A stolen auto card was completed and the vehicle was entered into NCIC as stolen. A New Jersey Victim Notification form was also completed and a copy provided to the victim. The approximate value of the stolen auto is $2,000.00.

The victim stated he parked his vehicle in his assigned parking space (1H) on 1/28/21 at approximately 2000 hours. When he returned on this date he noticed the front passenger's side window was shattered and the center console was left open.  The victim stated his wallet was taken.  It was described as brown and contained the following:      NJ driver's license (A18217068201821)   Work permit   State Department ID   $5.00 US cash   Health Insurance card   No suspect(s) description was given.Motor vehicle insurance policy: 6041236024 code: 100

I responded with P.O. Ortiz to the listed location for a residential burglary.  Upon arrival we met with the homeowner and victim, Kathleen Hornes who stated that she arrived home at approximately 1320 hours and entered through the side door of the residence on the Herman St side.  Upon entering the house she observed broken glass on the floor from the rear door.  She also noticed numerous drawers and items in disarray on the first floor.  Upon realizing that her home had been burglarized she immediately went outside and called the police department.  She left the house at approximately 1200 hours prior to returning at approximately 1320 hours.     P.O. Ortiz and I entered the residence to conduct a sweep to make sure there were no suspects still inside.  Sgt. Briggs arrived on scene.  Once the residence was cleared, Detectives and Bergen County Sheriff's department BCI were contacted.  Detective Carroll responded to the scene.  The homeowners conducted a quick inventory and stated that the following items were missing:-Approximately $1100 cash-White Gold diamond engagement Ring approximate size 6 $11,000-Platinum diamond wedding band $3,000-Michelle Watch with Ivory face $1,000-4 Jeffery watches totaling $1000     The homeowners stated that a more detailed inventory will be conducted at a later time and a list along with possible photos will be sent via email to Detective Carroll.  All serial numbers for the missing items is also unknown at this time.  BCI Detectives Anastasio, Park, and Zema responded and processed the crime scene (see BCI Case #2021-0091).  This investigation was turned over to the detective bureau.

Sgt. Briggs and I responded to the construction site at the listed location on a report of a burglary.  Upon arrival, I met with 2 of the 4 victims, Eric Lohmeyer and Cielo Alverez.  They explained that their work site storage container had been closed and secured on 2/4/21 at approximately 17:00 hours and when they came to work this morning on 2/5/21 at 08:00 hours, they found their storage container to have been burglarized.  They explained that the master lock used to secure the storage container had been cut and left on the ground as well as many power tools were stolen.  The storage container is a white rectangular walk-in metal storage container used to store miscellaneous tools and equipment.  The container is located on the East side of the construction site where Midtown Bridge Approach and the Salem Street Extension meet.  The construction site is fenced and the point of entry is unknown.The Hackensack Detective Bureau was requested to respond and Detective Papanikolaou responded.The third victim, Bobby Mclean, who also had power tools stolen from this storage container was not on scene at the time and was advised to contact Detective Papanikolaou when he arrived at the job site to inventory the stolen items.  All victims were advised to contact Detective Papanikolaou with serial numbers, make and model of the tools as well as value of the items.  Approximately 20 tools were known to be stolen and approximately 12 batteries were stolen at a loss of approximately $7,000.00.Victim Lohmeyer did not have any identifying marks on his tools but explained that he has serial numbers and receipts for his tools at home.  Victim Cielo Alverez identified his tools by marking his initials "CA" on the tools and cases.  Victim Bobby Mclean identified his tools with brown tape as well as marking his tools with the initials "BM."These three victims work for the company Encore Electric LLC (426 Main Street, Spotswood, NJ 08884).  The tools stolen were personally owned by the victims and not the company.  Tools belonging to the company are stored in the storage container but none have been identified as stolen.  A 4th employee, Humberto Gonzalez (24 Grace Avenue, Clifton, NJ 07011, 973-851-0014),  also works at this job site for Encore Electric and shares the storage container, but he takes his tools home and did not have any items stolen.  I then met with Armenio Gomes who explained that his trailer may have also been broken into.  Next to the burglarized storage container, a white rectangular trailer was parked and housed very few items of value according to Gomes.  He advised that he noticed new marks on the door that he believed were pry marks.  He did not observe any stolen items from the trailer. Detective Kenneth Mclillo #1759 of the Bergen County Sheriff BCI division arrived to process the crime scene.Investigation turned over to the detective bureau.

On Saturday, February 6, 2021 at approximately 12:24 p.m., P.O. Donnerstag and I responded to 589 Main Street on a report of a dispute. Upon arrival, we spoke with the victim's uncle who stated that just moments prior to our arrival the suspect pushed, his nephew, the victim while in the parking lot of 589 Main Street. The complainant further stated, he has had ongoing problems with the suspect in recent weeks over the shared parking lot of their building.     Next, I spoke with the suspect. He stated on this date at approximately 12:00 p.m., while walking in the parking lot to throw away garbage, he accidentally bumped into the victim. He stated he tried to speak with the victim but the victim only speaks Spanish and he was unable to communicate with him. He further stated a few minutes later while he was outside, the complainant threatened him. Seecase 21-008494 for further information.    Last, I attempted to speak with the victim but was unable to due to the victim only able to communicate in Spanish. P.O. Lara-Nunez, a bilingual officer, Spanish/English, responded to the scene and assisted with translation. He advised me the victim stated on this date at approximately 12:00 p.m., the victim was shoveling snow in the parking lot of 589 Main Street. As he was shoveling, the suspect pushed him with two hands to the chest then left the parking lot. The victim stated he was not injured, and he refused medical attention. The victim was advised on how to sign complaints. See case # 21-008494 for further information.

On Sunday, February 7, 2021 at approximately 1904 hours, I responded to the intersection of American Legion Drive and Prospect Avenue on a report of a recovered stolen vehicle. Upon arrival, I observed the listed vehicle parked curbside facing west on American Legion Drive, just west of Prospect Avenue. I then spoke with the owner of the listed vehicle, Alan Pena. Pena advised me that he reported his vehicle was stolen to the Garfield Police Department on 01/29/2021. He further reported that, while traveling through Hackensack, he coincidentally located his vehicle at the aforementioned location. Pena reported he located the vehicle's key, which was allegedly stolen from his home, on the passenger seat. He did not report any of his property to be missing from the vehicleand did not observe any new damage. Pena wished no further police action at the time of this report. Headquarters contacted the Garfield Police Department who reported the vehicle was not needed for investigation and could be released to the owner. The vehicle was then turned over to Alan Pena.

This officer while on patrol of the T3 observed the listed BMW backed into a parking spot in the corner of the parking lot, with no front plate attached and covered in snow. Upon running the rear license plate it was found to be stolen out of Linden, NJ Under Linden Police OCA: 21005417 DOT: 2/3/2021 NIC# V362670766. The vehicle was found locked, missing front NJ plate and has old existing damage to the front bumper, see tow report.

On the listed date and time Sgt. Briggs and I were dispatched to 301 Beech Street apt 2f on a burglary. Upon arrival I met with the victim and his wife.  The victim stated he and his wife had stepped out at 1215 this afternoon and when they returned back at 2pm when they observed their apartment to be burglarized. The victim stated he drooped his wife off at 2pm and he headed out to run some more errands when he received a call from his wife that the apartment was possibly burglarized causing him to return home immediately. The wife advised me that she did leave the apartment door unlocked after returning to return a cart back to the lobby.  She stated she was gone for no longer then four minutes and when she returned back to the apartment she observed a jewelry rack containing assorted jewelry to be knocked down in the hallway.  She then stated she proceeded into the bedroom where she observed the victims two top dresser draws to be fully opened and in disarray. She also advised me that's where the victim keeps some of his handguns. She further stated a small I-pad that she keeps in her bedroom was also found in the bathroom.     I then spoke with the victim who stated after being alerted by his wife that the apartment was burglarized and that the suspect(s) had went through his dresser where he keeps his guns he observed immediately his M&P 9mm Generation 2 gun serial #NCV2124 to be stolen which was later entered into NCIC as stolen by Police Headquarters. The victim stated the gun was placed in a thumb break holster with a round in the chamber as well as three loaded magazines and a Pelican 7060 LED flashlight engraved with "LPD053" that were also stolen. The victim was then asked if any other guns were stolen which he then inventoried which were not stolen.  Being that there was no forced entry into the apartment the victim was asked if anyone besides he and wife have a key to the apartment which he replied he keeps one in a safe lock box downstairs in case of an emergency and the other his cleaning lady has. The victim advised me the cleaning lady hasn't been around due to Covid19. The victim also stated the cleaning lady has been seen in the building cleaning other peoples apartments but no his in six weeks.    BCI Det/Sgt Savino and Det Park from the Bergen County Sheriffs Department arrived on scene which was later photographed and processed. See Case #2021-0112.    See Det Koenig's supplemental for further.

P.O. F. Competiello and I responded to 78 Main Street Apt. 1 on a fight.  Upon our arrival, I observed the victim washing blood off of his face in the bathroom sink.  The victim's parents, Jorge Zhinin-Pena and Esthela Sanango, were both on scene and reported the victim was assaulted on Bridge Street near the intersection with Main Street.  The victim complained of pain to his nose and was actively bleeding from it.  I requested an ambulance and Hackensack University Medical Center Ambulance #1346 responded and treated the victim.       The victim stated that he was being challenged to a fight by M.M., a former classmate at Hackensack High School, via social media.  The victim then agreed to meet M.M. on Bridge Street near Main Street.  Upon meeting, M.M. missed striking the victim with a closed fist and then the victim struck M.M. with a closed fist in order to defend himself.          J.D., another former classmate of the victim at Hackensack High School, then came from behind and struck the victim with a closed fist.  The victim subsequently fell to the group and both M.M. and J.D. continued hitting him with closed fists.  Both assailants then fled the area and the victim responded inside 78 Main Street Apt. 1.     Sgt. E. Meneses responded.  Det. L. Furcal of the Juvenile Detective Division was notified.  The victim was transported to Hackensack University Medical Center for further treatment with the complainant accompanying him in the ambulance.  The complainant will sign complaints in the future and I explained the process to her.  I completed a Handle with Care Form which I e-mailed to Sgt. Patricia of the Hopatcong Police Department due to the victim attending Phillipsburg High School.

P.O. Mena and I responded to the area of Willow Avenue and Krone Place on the report of three male parties (suspects) in dark clothing pulling the door handles on vehicles.  As I arrived on scene, Sgt. Klosk transmitted the suspects' location, stating they were on Cedar Avenue, fleeing through backyards.  I then saw two of the three suspects, Mr. Campbell and Mr. Clement running North on Herman Street, in my direction.  As I approached they attempted to duck behind a parked vehicle.  The third suspect, Mr. Frost was located nearby by P.O. Mena, who stated he had been hiding underneath a parked vehicle.  The suspects were immediately patted down for weapons yielding negative results.   Sgt. Klosk advised me that he witnessed the suspects as they were pulling on car door handles on Cedar Avenue prior to fleeing.  A search incident to arrest revealed the following:   A Chamberlain garage door opener (model #953ESTD) an EZ Pass (tag #G402212485254) a gold colored ring and $3.00 in cash were found in Mr. Clement's Possession; a pair of children's pink sunglasses, were found in Mr. Frost's possession; $6.78 in change was found in Mr. Campbell's possession.  The items were seized and submitted as evidence.  The amount of burglarized vehicles is unknown at this time.       The suspects were handcuffed and placed under arrest.  Mr. Campbell and Mr. Clement were transported to Police Headquarters in radio car 104 without incident.  While at Police Headquarters the suspects admitted to their affiliation with the "Crips" street gang.  The rear seat of radio car 104 was checked for contraband prior to and after the transport, yielding negative results.  Mr. Marquis was transported by P.O. Mena in radio car 185.  P.O. Caneja, P.O. Estrada and P.O. Sheikh also responded and checked the surrounding area for contraband and property damage.  See supplement reports for further.  Suspect Description:   Marquis Frost - Tall, very thin, braids, wearing black jogging pants, yellow sneakers   Kevin Campbell - Tall, very thin, braids, black jogging Adidas pants, all black running sneakers,                                     black hooded sweatshirt with rose on the back     Jevon Clement - Tall, very thin, black jogging pants, black and white Jordan sneakers, braids                   All evidence located was secured in 4 separate evidence bags # 5805901,02 and 017116, 0179242 and secured in locker #1.                Detectives were notified and Det. Papaniakolaou responded.

On this date I was dispatched to 18 DiCarolis Court on a report of a stolen motor vehicle. Upon arrival I was able to speak to witness, Martin Lovy, he informed me that between the hours of 1410 and 1415 a van was stolen from the front of 18 Dicarolis Court. The van is operated by an employee, Antonio Reyes, who was not present at that location at that time. Lovy further  explained that the vehicle, NJ L83-MZS, a Blue 2008 Ford Econoline  van was parked on the North side of DiCarolis Court facing West. He observed what  he described as a short dark skinned male, possibly Hispanic, wearing a dark coat and jeans enter the van and  immediately flee West on DiCarolis then North on Railroad. Lovy also stated that the keys were in the vehicle, but not in the ignition.     I was also able to speak  to another witness, Miguel Leon. He described the suspect as a black      male wearing a dark coat, jeans and wearing a knit hat.  Leon also stated that  the suspect appeared to hit a remote alarm as if he had the keys to the  van.      I was able to speak to Antonio Reyes, who normally operates the vehicle, via telephone and he stated he did not allow anyone to take the vehicle.     Lt. Lopez spoke to the  registered owner of the vehicle, Dalila Hernandez-Rios, and she informed him that she did not give anyone permission to take the van other than the normal operator, Antonio Reyes.      A stolen vehicle card was completed and the  vehicle was  entered into  NCIC  as stolen (V062750637). A consent to  search form was unable to be completed since the registered owner and operator were not on  the scene at that time. A Victim Notification form was completed and left at the scene for the operator.       Video cameras at 18 Railroad may have captured the incident.

On Tuesday, February 16, 2021 at approximately 1934 hours, I responded to 121 Myer Street on a report of a parking complaint.     On arrival, I met with the complainant, Andrew Walsh. The complainant reported the listed vehicle was partially parked in his parking space, #30. I conducted a check through InfoCop of the NJ registration (L83MZS), which revealed the vehicle was reported stolen to this agency on this date, see OCA/21-010802. Police communications was advised and confirmed the vehicle was reported as a stolen vehicle.     The registered owner was contacted and reported to my location. Upon her arrival, I confirmed ownership. The registered owner refused consent to have the vehicle processed by the Bergen County Sheriffs Department, Crime Scene Unit. The vehicle was released to the owner, and Police Communications cleared the vehicle from NCIC as a stolen vehicle.

On the listed time and date, I responded to Hackensack University Medical Center (HUMC) on a report of a simple assault. The victim, Claudecir Oliveira (Rm-4881) reported he was assaulted by hospital security.   On arrival, I spoke to RN Dorothy Cajuste. Cajuste reported the victim was admitted into HUMC on 2/15/2021 due to shortness of breath. The victim was transferred onto her unit on this date and has been refusing to take his medication. Due to the victim refusing to take his medication, a psychiatric evaluation was ordered to gauge his mental stability. The victim who was upset attempted to leave the unit with an IV attached to his arm. Security was advised and responded. Upon security's arrival, the victim was redirected into his bedroom and administered an injection.   I spoke to the victim, Claudecir Oliveira. The victim reported he went to HUMC to seek medical attention for shortness of breath and rectal cancer treatment. The victim stated he was then transferred to Rm # 4881 and has not been given his medication and wanted to leave the hospital. The victim stated staff told him he could not leave the hospital with an IV in his hand and it was at that point the victim stated he will go downstairs to have the IV removed. The victim stated he put his jacket on and attempted to leave the unit. When the victim was at the elevator, security grabbed him, twisted his arm behind his back causing him to fall on the floor. While the victim was on the floor, security picked him up, placed him into his bed and he was given an injection. The victim complained of pain to his back.   I  spoke to Security Supervisor, David Delorenzo. Delorenzo stated on this date, security officers, Daniela Suarez, Kenneth Lind, Patrick Dowd and Joseph Levy responded to the unit on a report of an unstable patient attempting to leave the hospital with an IV attached to his arm. Upon his officers arrival, the patient attempted to push his way into the elevator. At that point the officers attempted to escort the patient back into his bedroom and that is when the patient placed himself on the floor. The officers picked the patient off the floor and placed him back into his bedroom.  The victim was advised on the procedure on how to file a complaint, if should he chose to file.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: On February 17, 2021 at approximately 2047 hrs, while on patrol assigned to the Traffic Division in a marked police unit, I observed the listed trailer traveling north on Polifly Road with no tail lights, in violation of 39:3-66 while being towed by the listed vehicle #2.  Upon running the Georgia License Plate of LE63782 affixed to the rear bumper of the trailer,  I was alerted via INFO COP, that the trailer was reported stolen out of Edison PD from U-Haul Rental Company. I conducted a traffic stop in marked radio car 141. I made contact with the driver, identified as Martin Cash. I explained the reason for the motor vehicle stop and requested the drivers license, registration and proof of insurance.  The arrestee stated,  he rented the trailer from U-Haul in Edison, new Jersey on Route 1 on or about January 6, 2021 and has been in contact with the company to continue the rental agreement.  Sgt. Bay arrived on scene at this time to assist.      The arrestee was instructed to exit the vehicle and advised he was under arrest for receiving stolen property.  The arrestee was handcuffed, searched incident to arrest and secured. The arrestee was then placed in radio car 111 which was checked by Sgt. Bay.  Brookside Towing responded to the scene both the pickup trucker and recovered stolen trailer from the roadway.     The arrestee was transported without incident to Hackensack Police HQ for processing.  The entire transport from the motor vehicle stop to headquarters was recorded on the in-car video camera attached to vehicle #111. The arrestee was removed from radio car 111 which was again checked by Sgt Bay. At police headquarters, a secondary search was conducted on the arrestee, with negative results.  The arrestee provided the rental agreement given to him by U-Haul. I contacted U-Haul Recovery who indicated that they made several attempts to contact the arrestee for payment with negative results at which time they contacted Edison PD for a report: DOT: 1/12/2021, OCA 21001848.The arrestee was processed and Charged with 2C:20-7a(3rd Degree) under Summons # S-2021-000100-0223.  All property was returned to the arrestee, prior to being released.  The arrestee was given a copy of his charges, along with a Central Judicial Processing notice.

I responded to the listed location on a report of a domestic dispute. Upon arrival, I met with Ms Ramirez. She stated that she had gotten into an argument with her boyfriend of 10 years and had left the apartment prior to our arrival. She stated that her boyfriend, Victor Cambizaca was intoxicated and started arguing with her while they were in bed. While arguing, he pushed her arm away. She did not complain of any pain and there were no signs of any injuries. Ms. Ramirez was emotional while I spoke with her. She stated that her children were all sleeping in a different room while this incident occurred and were not woken up. She stated she has 2 children in common with Mr. Cambizaca and another child from a previous marriage       Ms. Ramirez advised me of her history with the suspect. She stated that he was verbally and  physically abusive with her when they began dating years ago. She stated she did not want to be in a relationship with him anymore. I advised her of her right to obtain a Temporary restraining order and she stated she not want one at the time of this report. A victim notification form was signed and she refused the restraining order but was advised on how to obtain one at a later date if she wished. She refused to complete a handwritten statement and indicated that she would consider speaking with a DVRT member at a later date. She was provided with the contact number so she could speak with them at her own leisure.

I responded to the listed location for a simple assault report. The suspect is the victim's live in step-father. The victim reported that an argument ensued with his sister about cleanliness. He further reported that the suspect overheard the argument and began attacking him. He reported that the suspect grabbed his shirt with his two hands, pinned him to a wall and screamed, "I'LL FUCK YOU UP!" The suspect left the area prior to my arrival. The victim did not any medical attention. He was advised on how to sign complainants and obtain a TRO. A New Jersey Victim Notification form and DV Offense report was completed.

The victim reported that while walking through the City of Hackensack he was assaulted by  3 black or Hispanic males. The victim was unsure of where it occurred but was located in the area of 146 South Main Street. The victim then reported that it occurred at a friend's house but he could not recall where or any pertinent information of the actors or friend. It should  be noted that while speaking to the victim, he was highly intoxicated. Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance responded to the scene. The victim was transported to Hackensack University Medical Center after suffering a cut to his head from the incident.

Suspect's description: Four (4) young black males, skinny, dark clothing, dark mask, dark head covering.      I responded to the listed location for a robbery. MR. SINGH, an employee, reported that he observed the suspects enter the parking lot on foot and entered the business on the east side door. One suspect stood by the door, another suspect walked the isles, two suspects walked behind the cashier area and began looting the registers. MR. SINGH entered the north side of the business and attempted to stop the suspects. He reported that one of the suspects displayed a short knife with red handle and aggressively stated, "MOVE, MOVE!" The suspects stole money and register, exited through the same door they entered and fled the area.     MR. ADLAN, second employee, reported when he exited the restroom which was inside the business, he observed the suspects going behind the register. He immediately exited the business and observed the incident occur outside the business. He further reported that none of the suspects approached him nor spoke to him while exiting the business. Once the suspects were done, he followed them to a neighboring parking lot which is located south of the business and identified the fleeing vehicle. The vehicle fled south on route 17 south. P.O. Williams searched the area and yielded with negative results.      Sgt. Meneses responded. Det. Papanikolaou responded. Det. Melillo #1759 from Bergen County Sheriff's BCI responded and processed the scene. See case #2020-0132. There are several surveillance cameras overseeing the parking lot and business. Also several fresh footprints on a snow bank outside the business which was also processed. After reviewing the surveillance footage, it appeared to be five (5) suspects involved with the robbery. A New Jersey Victim Notification form was completed. MR. ADLAN believes there was approximately $600.00-$700.00 inside the lottery register and an unknown amount along with cashier register was stolen. The cost of the register is unknown at this time.

I responded with P.O. Tedesco and S.P.O. Abueg to the listed location on a reported dispute.  Upon arrival I spoke with the victim who stated that she was assaulted by her boyfriend's sister, Jazminne Cacho.  The victim stated that she was with her boyfriend inside of the residence when the suspect arrived.  The boyfriend let the suspect inside the residence and according to the victim the suspect attempted to apologize to her regarding past events between them.  The victim did not wish to accept the suspect's apology and asked her to leave the residence.  The suspect did not leave and they began to argue.  The suspect had a key chain in her hand which contained a small pink bottle of pepper spray on it.  The victim believed that the suspect was going to use the pepper spray on her so the victim began to pull the suspect's hair and strike her.  The victim and suspect then wereseparated and the victim picked up her 3 year old daughter, MG.  The suspect at that point located the pepper spray and sprayed it towards the victim while she was holding the child.  The victim's father, Marco Caceres stepped between the victim and suspect and was subsequently pepper sprayed in the face by the suspect.     Sgt. Pierce arrived one scene.  Hackensack BLS responded and examined Marco Caceres who had redness on his face.  Mr. Caceres refused any further medical attention.  The victim and her daughter, MG were not harmed in this incident and were not pepper sprayed by the suspect.  This Officer contacted DCP&P and spoke with Alexandra #1576 who stated that a follow up will be conducted at a later date.  The victim was advised on how to sign complaints against the suspect if she wished to do so.

I responded to 185 High Street on a report of a simple assault that occurred at 351 Park Street. It should be noted that another incident report was generated in reference to an incident at the same location. See OCA#21-11863 for information provided by the suspects in reference to the same incident.      I made contact with the victim who reported that she responded to 351 Park Street to attempt to retrieve a cell phone that she purchased for the suspect. The victim reported that the suspect was supposed to be making payments to her for the phone but stopped. While speaking to the suspect a physical altercation ensued between the two parties in which the victim stated that the suspect was the aggressor. Per the victim, the suspect grabbed her hair, began to punch her, and scratched her several times while fighting. The victim then stated that the suspect's father then began to attempt to intervene between the two. The victim then stated that she was then struck by suspect #2 as well. At this time, the victim removed a key-chain sized bottle of pepper spray and utilized it in self defense. The victim and the witness then left the scene and responded to the victim's residence. It should be noted that the witness provided a similar recollection of the incident as the victim.      The victim was advised on the procedure of how to proceed with a criminal complaint against the suspects if she wished to do so at a later date.

On February 23, 2021, Sgt. Klosk, P.O. Sheik and I responded to the listed location on a possible assault. Upon our arrival we met with the complainant who stated the victim had been assaulted. We then met with the victim who spoke minimal English. P.O. Caneja then responded to translate.     The victim was highly intoxicated and was unable to provide clear information regarding the  assault. The victim stated he was possibly assaulted on 02/22/2021 in the area of Hudson Street and Broadway  where he  was punched in the left side of his face which caused bruising near his left eye.               The victim was unable to clearly state the circumstances of the assault or recall any information about the suspect other than that he was an Hispanic male. The victim did not wish to pursue any further police action and requested to be transported to HUMC for further treatment. Hackensack Volunteer ambulance arrived and transported the victim.

PO Scangarella and I responded to the listed location on a dispute. Upon arrival I spoke to the victim who stated that she got into a verbal argument with her ex-boyfriend who she has a child in common with. At this time the suspect was no longer on scene. The victim stated that the suspect arrived at her home to pick up their son. While he was there they both began to have a verbal argument over the suspect's new girlfriend. During that argument the suspect spit on the victim.   The victim had no complainant of pain or any signs of injury. The victim further stated that she does not want to sign complaints at this time.     A victim notification form was completed and a copy was given to the victim. The victim declined to apply for a temporary restraining order at this time. The victim also declined to give a written statement or speak to a DVRT member at this time. The victim was given a copy of the DVRT phone number.Due to A.W. witnessing the incident, DCP&P was contacted. I spoke to Maya #1554 and advised her of the situation. She advised me that no member from DCP&P will be responding at this time. A Handle With Care form was completed and e-mailed to A.W. school.The Domestic Violence Registry was checked, and yielded negative results for any active restraining orders.

Sgt. Pierce, P.O. Farhi, P.O. Rios, and I responded to the listed location on an anonymous report made by a third party in reference to a disturbance within the listed location. It should be noted that the anonymous complainant further stated that an unknown party, within the establishment, may be armed with a handgun.       On arrival, P.O. Farhi and I located the victim and arrestee actively fighting amongst a group of people in the stairwell. The victim and arrestee were separated. This officer stayed with the victim while P.O. Farhi and P.O. Rios spoke with the arrestee in a separate location. The victim identified the arrestee as the individual who struck him in the face with a bottle of Hennessy to this officer. At this  time, the group gathered in the hallway began to self disperse.     Upon speaking with the victim, who is the manager/owner of the Craftsman Club/Lounge, he stated that earlier in the evening the arrestee was escorted off the property for bringing his own liquor into the establishment. Per the victim, the arrestee was causing a disturbance at that time but ultimately left the establishment. The victim then stated that the arrestee once again returned and attempted to enter the establishment when he was met at the stairs by the victim.  At this time, the victim told the arrestee to leave when a dispute ensued in the stairwell. Per the victim, the arrestee then grabbed the bottle of Hennessy out of his pocket and struck him with it in the face. The arrestee then continued to fight with the victim who was at the time attempting to escort him outside of the establishment. The victim and arrestee where then separated by P.O. Farhi and I.      An ambulance was requested to the scene to due to the victim's injuries which consisted of a cut near his mouth. The victim refused medical attention on scene. The victim then responded to police headquarters and provided a statement to Detective M. Koenig. See his supplemental report for additional information.     I then spoke to the arrestee who stated that he was involved in an altercation with an unknown person at the listed location. Per the arrestee, he stated that the unknown individual struck him in the face first at which point he began to fight in self defense. While speaking to the arrestee, I detected the odor of an alcoholic beverage and slurred speech.      The arrestee was then handcuffed with his arms behind his back. He was searched incident to his arrest with negative results for any contraband. The arrestee was then escorted into the rear seat compartment of Radio Car #118. The arrestee was transported to police headquarters while P.O. Farhi followed. At headquarters a secondary search of the arrestee was conducted with negative results for contraband. An ambulance was requested for the arrestee due to him having a cut from the fight. At headquarters, the arrestee refused any further medical attention. The arrestee was then processed by P.O. Farhi without incident.      P.O. Rios responded to the scene with the Hackensack Police Department Patrol Division camera. P.O. Rios took 8 photographs of the scene and 2 photographs of the victim's injuries. It should be noted that the weapon utilized, the bottle of Hennessy, was not recovered due to its fragile nature and it breaking during the incident.      I generated complaint 0223-W-2021-000112 against the arrestee for violations of N.J.S.2C:12-1B(2), N.J.S.2C:39-4d, and N.J.S.2C:39-5D. The arrestee was then remanded to the Bergen County Jail.

The victim responded to police headquarters to report a simple assault that occurred inside of the Hackensack University Medical Center. The victim stated while being treated inside the hospital for high blood pressure in an unknown room number. The victim stated he got into a dispute with the doctor over taking blood and he did not want to put on the medical gown and wished to have it placed over his clothes.  Security was called to his room. Security Officer Terrance Fitzpatrick then grabbed the victim by the neck and pushed him onto the medical bed and removed his sweat pants from him. The victim stated after the incident he felt lower back pain and neck pain. The victim wished to have this report documented and was advised on how to sign criminal complaints.

Suspect #1 is described as a medium built, 5'5" tall white or hispanic female with black hair, wearing a white shirt, grey sweatpants and white moccasins.Suspect # 2 is described as a thin, 6'3" tall white male with facial hair, wearing glasses, a hat with ear flaps, a green windbreaker jacket, blue jeans and Timberland boots.Suspect vehicle: White Kia, NJ registration G97K5Y.   On the listed time and date, I responded to the emergency room at Hackensack University MedicalCenter on a report of an aggravated assault.  Upon arrival, I met with the victim, Mishena Dent. While I spoke to the victim, her boyfriend, Javan Johnson (witness) was on speakerphone. The victim reported on this date while they entered an intersection on Johnson Ave, a white Kia (NJ-G97K5Y) beeped, pulled in front of their vehicle and suspect # 1 spat on their car. The witness, who was driving, then pulled up to the Kia. Suspect # 1, who was driving then threw a water bottle at them. The witness then drove his vehicle in front of their vehicle and stopped the car. The witness exited his vehicle and confronted the male passenger, suspect # 2. At that point they reentered their vehicles and pulled into a nearby parking lot located at Johnson Ave and Voorhis Place. While the witness was speaking to suspect # 2 to deescalate the situation, suspect # 1 and the victim were arguing. While they were arguing, suspect # 1 struck the victim and a physical altercation ensued. During the physical altercation, the victim yelled out "She has my ear!" and was bitten. At that point, the victim and suspect # 1 were separated and a portion of the victim's right ear was on the ground. Both suspects then entered their vehicle and fled the area. Please note, the victim and witness stated they did not know the suspects and were unfamiliar with the area of the incident as they are not from the area. A check of the Kia NJ registration (G97K5Y) revealed the registered owner as the possible suspect,  Nikita Kelly, who resides at 975 Bonnel Ct. Apt. 309, Union, NJ 07083  The victim sustained an injury to her right ear, specifically the top portion of the ear was bitten off. Scratches on the right side of the face, specifically on the eyebrow, nostril and cheek.  Sgt. Capone was apprised with the above information. Sgt. Capone notified the Hackensack Detective Bureau and Det. Han responded. Det. Han spoke to the victim and captured photographs of the victims injuries with her consent. Det. Han captured several photographs utilizing his department issued cellular phone.  After the victim was discharged, Det. Han responded to the location of the incident with the victim and witness to accurately document the exact location. See Det. Hans report.  A NJ Victim Notification Form was completed and was provided to the victim by Det. Han.

On Tuesday, March 2, 2021 at approximately 2305 hours, I responded to 160 Overlook Avenue on a reported simple assault.Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, a security guard with Premier Security Services, outside of the listed location. The complainant reported she called police after being assaulted by her coworker, the suspect, when she relieved him at the security desk on this date at approximately 2258 hours. P.O. Caneja arrived to assist. The complainant reported she entered the security office and a verbal dispute ensued between her and the suspect. The dispute reportedly became physical when the suspect pushed the complainant underneath her chin and struck her in the face. During the altercation, the complainant reported she sustained a laceration to a finger on her right hand. The complainant was offered medical attention and refused. P.O. Caneja provided her with first aid supplies from his medical kit. The complainant was then explained the process for obtaining a copy of this report, as well as the process for signing complaints against the suspect. It should be noted that throughout our entire interaction with the complainant, she was irate, yelling that the police and her employer were not helping her. At one point, the complainant spontaneously uttered, "If nothin's done, I'm doin' somethin' to this nigga! I don't care!" The complainant added that she had reported multiple incidents of harassment involving the suspect to her employer and was upset that as of the date of this report, no action had been taken.I then spoke with the suspect. The suspect reported that animosity between he and the complainant commenced shortly after she began her employment with Premier Security Services in early January of 2021. The suspect reported that when the complainant entered the security office to begin her shift, he began advising her that he needed to pass along some information regarding the elevator being repaired. The complainant then reportedly pushed her way past the suspect, grabbed his bag, and threw it out of the office. The suspect reported it was at that time that the complainant accosted him and he raised his forearm in self defense. The suspect reported he was struck several times in the face as the complainant wildly flailed her arms. The suspect reported he suffered a minor superficial laceration above his upper lip. He refused medical attention. The suspect was explained the process for obtaining a copy of this report, as well as the process for signing complaints. Julio Bendezu, an operations manager with Premier Security Services arrived on scene and was apprised of the incident. Bendezu arranged transportation for the complainant in the form of a Lyft and explained to her the process for reporting the incident to the human resources department. The complainant continued her irate behavior, yelling and screaming at Bendezu, creating a disturbance in front of the building. Shortly thereafter, the complainant's Lyft arrived and she left the premises. Bendezu advised that security cameras may have captured the incident, but he was unable to access the footage at the time of this report. Bendezu reported the surveillance footage would be accessed and saved at a later date.

On the listed time and date, P.O. Sheikh and I responded to the listed address on a dispute.   On arrival, I spoke to the victim, Uber driver, Jefrey Rosario. The victim reported on this date he responded to the listed address to pick up his passenger, Romeo (suspect).  While the victim was waiting an extended time for the suspect to arrive, he canceled the Uber ride due to the suspect not being on time. At that point the suspect arrived and entered the victims vehicle, rear seat. The victim then advised the suspect since he waited an extended amount of time for him, he canceled the Uber ride. At that point the suspect became upset, slapped the victim with an open hand on his right cheek and exited the vehicle in an unknown direction. The victim stated he was not injured and refused medical attention. The victim stated the only identifying information for the suspect was the name Romeo. The victim contacted Uber who advised they had no other information on the suspect due to the ride being canceled. The suspect is described as a 5'6" tall black male, wearing a green and yellow jacket and black pants. The victim stated at this time, he does not wish to file a complaint, but he would like the incident to be documented.

On this date P.O. Sheik and I were dispatched to the listed address on a report of a simple assault. Upon arrival we met with the suspect, Connor Williams, who was waiting for our arrival outside of the business. He stated that he and the victim, Darius Walker, had engaged in a physical altercation. He stated that he had pushed the victim because he was too close to him. He further stated that the victim had pushed him back so he punched the victim with a closed fist in the face.      I then spoke to the victim who stated the same as the suspect and added that he was punched with a closed fist 2 or 3 times in the nose. He did have a small scratch at the bridge of his nose, near his right eye. The victim refused medical attention at that time. He was advised on the procedure     on how to sign a complaint on the suspect if he wishes to do so at a later date. The victim was provided a copy of the NJ Victim Notification Form.     P.O. Sheik gave the suspect a ride to the the Hackensack - Hasbrouck Heights border. The suspect was also informed that he was not welcome back at the business.

On the listed date and time, I was dispatched to Hand & Stone Massage Spa located at 500 South River Street on a possible sexual assault. On arrival I met with the complainant, also the spa owner. I was then assisted by Sgt Briggs. The complainant advised me, the victim approached her after her massage was complete and that the arrestee had massaged her breast area then also massaged her nipples. The complainant then stated, the victim felt very uncomfortable and had asked the arrestee to stop, which he did. The complaint further stated, the victim was in her office waiting for Police arrival.    I then spoke to the arrestee who stated, he was massaging the victim and when he got to her breast area, he asked her if she was comfortable with this which she replied "yes". The arrestee then stated, he then continued to massage her breast area then massaging her nipples without her permission, at which time the victim told the arrestee to stop, which he did. The arrestee then stated, he completed the rest of the massage and once completed, he apologized to the victim.                The victim was visibly crying and upset.  The victim advised Sgt. Briggs that during the massage, the arrestee began to rub her upper breast area and nipples without her consent.                 Based on the victim's statement as well as the arrestee's admission of the offense, I arrested the arrestee for criminal sexual contact.    The arrestee was then handcuffed, searched and then escorted out of the store into radio car 119. The rear seat of 119 was check prior and after transport with negative results of contraband. The arrestee was then transported to Police Headquarters for processing. At Police Headquarters the arrestee was searched again and later charged with 2C:14-3B on summons 0223S2021-000124.                 Both the arrestee and victim were interviewed by Detective Mora, see his report for further.

The victim responded to headquarters to report a simple assault. The victim reported while walking on Railroad Avenue South towards Central Avenue, he observed a person he is no longer friends with (Alejandro Restituyo-Polanco) walking with an unknown Hispanic male. The victim reported he overheard suspect #1 tell suspect #2 in Spanish, "There goes the person I was telling you about." The victim reported suspect #1 then grabbed him by the front of his coat and struck him in the face with a closed fist. The victim reported suspect #1 then yelled to suspect #2 in Spanish, "Are you not going to do anything?" The victim further reported that suspect #2 then grabbed him by his coat and shoulder area pulling him down to the sidewalk. The victim reported once on the sidewalk, suspect #2 pulled the victim's coat over his face as suspect #1 struck him   several times in the face. The victim reported he was unable to see due to the coat obstructing his vision and he does not know if it was a closed fist that struck him. The victim reported the suspects then fled the area on foot, last seen running towards the area of Park Street.         The victim declined medical attention while in headquarters. The victim complained of pain in his left arm, left hand, and face. The victim had a minor abrasion near his left eye. The victim was explained how to sign complaints and will be doing so on a later date.         Suspect #2 was described as a Hispanic male, light brown skin tone, 6'1, approximately 140 pounds, and wearing a red coat.

I responded to the listed location on a reported burglary. Upon arrival, I met with the victim who reported his bicycle was missing from the foyer to his residence and the front door to be slightly ajar. The victim reported he had previously locked the front door. The victim reportedly spoke with his landlord and after reviewing video surveillance observed an unknown male suspect climb in through the window located on the South side of the residence. A Hackensack Fire Department fire truck was seen stopping in front of the residence and an unknown fireman appears to speak with the juvenile suspect prior to driving North on Holt Street.          Sgt. Capone and Det. Garrett responded. The bicycle was a SE Big Flyer Wheel Size 29'' Rad Series 2019. Bicycle serial # SWBD041L0445P and valued at $525.00. The bicycle was white in color with red tires and "BIG FLYER" written in baby blue across middle of frame.          The bicycle was a SE Big Flyer Wheel Size 29'' Rad Series 2019. Bicycle serial # SWBD041L0445P and valued at $525.00. The bicycle was white in color with red tires and "BIG FLYER" written in baby blue across middle of frame. The suspect was last seen wearing a blue sweater, white undershirt, black pants, and walking a dog. A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed. Bergen County Sheriff's Department BCI Det. David Fego #1695 and Det. Andrea Zema #256 responded to process the scene. No prints were able to be lifted, see case #2021-0196 for further. Case turned over to Det. Garrett.

Sgt. Pierce, P.O. Rios, P.O. O' Neill and I responded to the 7-11 located at 202 Essex Street on a report of an armed robbery. The suspect was described as a black male wearing a black shirt, black bandana with red letters possibly armed with a handgun. Upon my arrival headquarters stated the suspect was observed running across the street and was inside of the McDonald's located at 193 Essex Street. Sgt. Pierce, P.O. Rios and I responded to the McDonald's in an attempt to set up a perimeter and to canvas the area while P.O. O' Neill spoke to the victim at 7-11 to gather additional information. While in the McDonald's parking lot on the South side, near the drive through lane, Sgt. Pierce and I observed a black male walking towards us who matched the description.   I further observed a large amount of US Currency in plain view protruding out of right pocket  along with multiple items bulging in his pants. I then unholstered my department issued duty weapon and pointed it at the suspect. With verbal commands, I ordered the suspect to the ground, which he complied. Due to the initial dispatch of a man with a gun, he was then placed in handcuffs behind his back for officer safety. I conducted a protective frisk of the suspect, which was negative on weapons. He was then stood up and multiple sealed "JUUL" electronic cigarette packages fell out of his person. P.O. O'Neill advised that the suspect had robbed approximately $300.00 dollars from the cash register in various denominations of US Currency. See P.O. O'Neill's supplement report for further.   Based on the victim's statements, the suspect clothing matching the description, the large amount of US currency protruding out of his pocket, the numerous Juul merchandise, as well as my training, education, and experience I placed the arrestee under arrest.      The arrestee identified himself as Jahsi Charlotin and was not in possession of any legal identification. He was searched incident to arrest yielding negative results on contraband. The arrestee was then transported to headquarters in R/C 109 and all evidence was secured in R/C 109 and transported back to headquarters. See P.O. Rio's supplement for further.    Police dispatch then advised that a witness stated he observed a black male jump out of a white pickup truck located at the McDonald's drive through.  I then observed a white pickup truck at the drive through, with a white male driver. Based on the robbery as well as this white pickup being a possible get away vehicle, the driver was then ordered out of the vehicle, which he complied and was placed into handcuffs behind his back. He was advised he was being detained. The driver immediately said a black male that he did not know opened up his passenger front door, while he was waiting for his order at the drive through. The black male, without his permission, got into the passenger seat and told him "hurry up man, just drive, there after me." The driver said he was overly nervous but was neither threatened by the suspect in any way nor was any weapon displayed.  The driver saw the police outside in the parking lot of the Mc Donald's and did not attempt to drive off. The suspect got out of the vehicle and was then detained.  It was determined the driver of the white pickup was not a suspect in this incident and was a witness who stated he wished to give a statement to detectives.    P.O. Tedesco responded to 7-11 to secure the crime scene. See P.O. Tedesco's supplement for further.    The witness TRACY responded to my location and stated while looking out of the window from 142 John Street, he observed a black male suspect enter a white pickup truck at the McDonald's drive through.  Det. Koeing arrived on scene and was briefed. See his supplement report for further. Witness DRISCOLL was transported backed to headquarters in R/C 138 for a statement.      At headquarters all stolen items were photographed with the patrol camera and was turned over to Det. Mora. See his supplement for further. See Det. Koeing's report for the total amount of stolen property.     While the arrestee was in cell 1, he stated he wished for an ambulance to respond. Hackensack Ambulance # 1321 responded. The arrestee was brought into the OD East room and met with medical staff. He then stated he wished no further treatment and signed a refusal of medical attention form. He was placed back into cell number 1.     During the arrest process, the arrestee provided the listed information:Name Jahsi CharlotinDate of birth 10/13/2001 Social security number 158-08-7373Address of  635 Clark Street, Linden, NJ 07036.            It was determined based on his fingerprints his real name was Zyair Desire with a date of birth of 04/04/2001, social security number 222-94-8994. Based on the arrestee tattoo on his wrist of roman numerals I asked him if he was in a gang, which he said yes. He identified himself as a West Side 36 fruit town blood. See the street gang Intel report for further.      I signed complaint number 0223W2021000132 against the arrestee for violations of 2C:15-1a(2) and 2C:29-3b(4).  The arrestee was committed to the Bergen County Jail.

The arrestee was brought into the OD East room and met with medical staff. He then stated he wished no further treatment and signed a refusal of medical attention form. He was placed back into cell number 1.     During the arrest process, the arrestee provided the listed information:Name Jahsi CharlotinDate of birth 10/13/2001 Social security number 158-08-7373Address of  635 Clark Street, Linden, NJ 07036.            It was determined based on his fingerprints his real name was Zyair Desire with a date of birth of 04/04/2001, social security number 222-94-8994. Based on the arrestee tattoo on his wrist of roman numerals I asked him if he was in a gang, which he said yes. He identified himself as a West Side 36 fruit town blood. See the street gang Intel report for further.      I signed complaint number 0223W2021000132 against the arrestee for violations of 2C:15-1a(2) and 2C:29-3b(4).  The arrestee was committed to the Bergen County Jail.

column13: I responded to the listed location on a report of a motor vehicle theft. On arrival I met with the victim and her husband. They reported that their vehicle was parked in the lot of 200 Holt Street (Frederick Street side) with the keys in the ignition and the vehicle running. They reported that they left the vehicle running so that it would warm up. Upon returning outside, the vehicle was stolen. The vehicle has an approximate value of $8,700.00. The vehicle was entered into NCIC as stolen. The victim completed a Hackensack Police Department consent to search for to authorize the vehicle to be processed upon recovery.      Sgt. Knapp was advised of the incident. Detective Sgt. Tripodi responded to the scene.

P.O. Dejesus and I responded to the listed location on a report of a burglary. The complainant who is the owner of US Mortgage located at 20 Court Street reported that there was an unknown individual within the premises that was observed via a security camera. It should be noted that there have been previous incidents of criminal trespass with an unknown vagrant who was also subsequently dispersed by management. See OCA #21-015082 for additional information.     P.O. Dejesus and I gained entry into the business and conducted a search of the premises. At that time, we located the arrestee, Manuel Cravero, who was attempting to hide near a desk of the business. Cravero was confronted and subsequently acknowledged that he had no reason to be  inside the closed business. Cravero then stated that he is homeless and that he often enters this business as it appears to be closed. He stated that he enters the business regularly for shelter and to utilize the internet. It should be noted that the business did not appear to be disturbed nor did any items appear to be missing at this time. Cravero was then escorted outside of the business and into the vestibule. While speaking with him, he stated that it was previously easier to enter the business with utilizing just a business card. He then stated that on today's date he used a wrench to enter the premises due to the newly added security features. The wrench was subsequently located on his person and it was secured as evidence. Cravero also stated that an employee previously yelled at him to leave the business in the past but he subsequently returned.      Sgt. Deleon responded to the scene along with Detective Carroll. They were apprised of the incident.            The complainant, Josh Westreich, was contacted in regards to the incident. He stated that since he was an hour away that he would not be responding to the scene. He stated that the incident was captured via the surveillance camera. Westreich stated that he would attempt to save/download the footage and attempt to make it available at a later date.      Cravero was then placed under arrest. He was handcuffed with his arms behind his back. He was searched incident to his arrest with negative results for contraband, He was then escorted into the rear seat compartment of Radio Car #118, which was checked prior to and after his occupancy with negative results for contraband. The arrestee was then transported to police headquarters. At headquarters a secondary search of the arrestee was conducted with negative results for contraband. The arrestee was then processed by P.O. Dejesus without incident.      I generated complaint 0223-W-2021-000137 against Cravero for violation of N.J.S.2C:18-2A(1) and N.J.S.2C:5-5A(1). Cravero was then remanded to the Bergen County Jail.

On this date Sabrina King (victim) walked into Police Headquarters to report a criminal sexual contact. She was accompanied by her mother, Elizabeth Burr and father Derrick Burr. The victim stated that her supervisor, Yong KIm (suspect), at the place of her employment, B and W Bakery, 641 Main Street had inappropriately touched her on this date. The victim also stated that she has been employed by that business since August 2020.      The victim stated that on this date at approximately 1330 hours the suspect asked her to wash her hands, because he cannot have any dirty girls working there. She further stated that as she was at the sink, in a common area near the suspect's office, he slapped her on the buttocks.        The victim then stated that at approximately 1400 hours she had made an error completing a card and the suspect called her into his office. As she entered the office he stated she was being disrespectful. It was at this time that the suspect again slapped the victim on the buttocks. The victim stated that she became upset as a result of the contact and verbalized to the suspect that it was not okay to do that.       The victim also stated that on this date the suspect asked her, "How much money would it take for you to come back and see me at 5 o'clock." The victim stated that the suspect often says that to the females that are employed there, but she does not know if any have taken the offer.       The victim resigned her employment as of today at B and W Bakery. A Victim Notification Form was completed.      Detective Han was notified and responded. See his supplement for further.

Sgt. Briggs and I responded to the listed location on a report of a simple assault.  Upon our arrival, the victim met us, who reported that he got into a verbal argument with the suspect over a parking dispute on 03/22/2021 that continued into today's date.  The victim reported approximately 1600 hours on this date, he walked to the rear of 70 Madison Street to throw the trash away in the dumpster.  He began to walk back to his apartment from the dumpster when the suspect entered the rear parking lot.  The suspect exited his vehicle, which was described as a possible white Nissan unknown model.  The victim reported he was pushed by the suspect from behind and struck in the back of his head with a closed fist, causing him to fall to the ground.   The victim reported when he fell to the ground, he landed on his right hip and elbow.  After the victim fell, he reported thesuspect then entered his vehicle and fled the area.  The victim had a complaint of pain in his right hip and a laceration to his right elbow.  While speaking with the victim, who had his button-down shirt undone, I questioned him about the brushing to his lower left abdomen.  He replied that it was caused when he fell to the ground.   I advised Sgt. Briggs of the situation who contacted Det. Papanikolaou and advised him of the situation.  The victim was advised to contact Det. Papanikollaou, after he was complete with his medical treatment to leave a statement and to sign complainants at a later date and time.

column2: Unlawful Possess./Weapons  2C:39-5Weapons/Unlawful Purposes  2C:39-4Domestic Dispute
column13: P.O. Farhi, Bongiovanni, Sgt. Briggs and I responded to the listed address for a domestic dispute with a report of a knife and sword involved.  Upon arrival we heard yelling coming from apartment 8.  Sgt. Briggs and P.O. Farhi kicked in the front and upper apartment door since the yelling increased became louder.  Once entry was made both parties were separated and handcuffed for our safety.   I escorted the victim downstairs and he described the following incident.  The victim and arrestee were having a verbal argument since 0900 hours which became physical at approximately 1055 hours.
