The victim stated that the arrestee grabbed a hairbrush and struck him on his chest causing redness and swelling.  The victim further stated that the arrestee then grabbed a large kitchen knife and was holding it in a threatening manner causing him to fear for his life.     The victim stated in response to the arrestee waving the knife at him, he grabbed a katana sword in order to defend himself.  He stated he was able to disarm the arrestee.  The arrestee stated that the same facts also occurred.  We located a large kitchen knife in the kitchen next to the refrigerator and it was secured as evidence (item 1-2).  We then found a red wooden hair brush used to cause injury to the victim on the living room floor, secured as evidence (item 2-2).  The katana sword was taken from the victim and secured as property.  Due to the signs of injury to the victim and weapons found on scene, the arrestee was placed under arrest for Domestic Violence.  The arrestee was already handcuffed with her hands behind her back and searched incident to arrest with negative results.  The arrestee was secured in the rear of radio car #115.  The victim refused to speak with a member of the DVRT, refused a TRO and refused to provide a hand written statement.  The victim also stated he would move out on his own.  A victim notification form was completed and given to the victim.  The victim refused medical attention on scene and also did not want to have photographs taken of his injuries.  The arrestee was transported to police headquarters without incident.  The rear of radio car #115 was check for contraband prior to and after transporting the arrestee to police headquarters with negative results.    Inside headquarters, the arrestee was processed, fingerprinted and photographed.  I signed complaints against the arrestee on Summons #0223-S-2021-00150.  The arrestee was then released after she signed for her CJP notice and property form.    Charges Signed against arrestee:   2C:12-1A(1)  Simple Assault, a DP Offense  2C:12-1A(3)  Simple Assault by Physical Menacing, a DP Offense  2C:39-4D  Unlawful Purpose of a weapon, Third Degree Crime   2C:39-5D  Unlawful Possession of a weapond, Fourth Degree Crime

Suspect and victim are involved in a dating relationship, are living together and have two children in common.     P.O. Oneill  and I responded to the listed location on a reported domestic dispute.  Upon arrival I spoke with the arrestee, who was also the caller.   The arrestee stated that him and his girlfriend, the the victim, got into an argument about his drinking alcohol and she kicked him out of their room and locked the door.  The arrestee became angry and forced his way back into their bedroom.  He further stated that after he gained entry back into the bedroom she attacked him and bit a toe on his left foot.  Sgt. Pierce and P.O. Rios responded to the scene.  P.O. Riosresponded to translate for the victim.      The victim stated that she and the arrestee got into an argument over his alcohol consumption.  She advised the arrestee that he will be staying in the living room and she locked the door to their bedroom where she was in bed with their two children, CA and AA.  The arrestee entered the bedroom by breaking the door and began to assault the victim by striking her in the face and mouth area with a closed fist.  According to the victim he struck their son, CA, on the right side of his face while attempting to strike her.  CA had some slight bruising on the right side of his face.  The victim did not have any visible signs of injury but stated that she had pain to her face and mouth area.     After speaking with both parties and examining the scene which consisted of a broken bedroom door I determined that arrestee was the aggressor.  The arrestee was placed under arrest and transported to headquarters in radio car #110.  The rear seat of radio car #110 was checked prior to and after the arrestee occupied it.  The arrestee was also searched a second time at headquarters.  Detective James was notified and responded due to a possible assault on a minor child.  The arrestee was processed and charged with 2C:12-1A(1) on warrant #0223-W-2021-000154 and 9:6-3 on warrant #0223-W-2021-000155.       The victim signed a victim notification form indicating that she did not want to apply for a TRO at this time.  She filled out a written statement in Spanish.  She also indicated that she may want to speak with a DVRT member at a later time.  She was provided a phone number by P.O. Rios who also took two photographs of CA at the hospital.  The arrestee was transported to the Bergen County Jail.  DCP&P was contacted by Detective James.  Hackensack BLS responded to the scene and CA was transported to the hospital at the request of the victim.

I responded to the listed address to investigate a report of a vehicle theft.     Upon arrival I spoke to Leonardo Santana-Mota and his wife Danyeska Bello. Mota stated that at 15:30 hours on today's date he double parked his car described as a 2007 Honda Accord in Gray at the intersection of Essex St and Lehigh St. He stated that he left the car running with the key in the ignition while he shopped for items at the liquor store at that corner.      He then stated that when he exited the store minutes later his car had been taken. On scene I was able to view the footage of the surveilance camera. At 15:30 hours a black female wearing a black sweatshirt with a white logo, green book bag, faded white and blue jeans with red and white sneakers appeared from the Essex Street side of the corner with an adult black male wearing a dark blue sanitation suit with reflective tape on the legs.  She observed that the vehicle was running and unattended and entered the vehicle. She then drove off heading North on Lehigh Street. It is unknown if the adult black male was assisting her but it was apparent that they knew each other. The store owner of the liquor store stated that he would save the date on his computer and the incident but is requesting a thumb drive from the investigating Detective to save the footage.      Both Bello and Mota stated that they are requesting the vehicle be fingerprinted upon recovery. A vehicle search consent form was signed as well as verbal consent given on my BWC. She was provided with a completed victim witness form.      The vehicle information is as follows:      2007 Honda Accord, NJ Registration L75JBC in color Gray.      The estimated value of the vehicle is approximately $ 4000.00 dollars

P.O. O'Neil and I responded to the listed location on a report of a simple assault.  Upon arrival I met with the victim, who stated that a female named Nicky (suspect) rang her doorbell.  She explained that when she saw who it was at the door, she told the suspect never to come to her house and demanded she leave.  When that happened, the suspect started hitting the victim in the head.  The victim added that the suspect had an unknown object in her hand, possibly a knife, and hit her with that object as well.  The victim had no injuries except a complaint of pain to her head and refused an ambulance.  The victim knows the suspect only by Nicky and believes she lives on Third Street in Hackensack.  A possible last name for the suspect is Powell.   Next I spoke with the witness who identified himself as the victim's nephew.  He stated that he heard the doorbell ring so he answered the door to a female that wanted to speak to the victim by the name of Nicky.  He stated that once they began fighting, he was trying to break up the fight along with another female passer who was not identified.  During the fight he saw the victim have her hair pulled and struck in the head by which he believes to be a hard round object.  Sgt. Deleon was requested on scene as well as an ambulance.  Once the ambulance arrived, the victim accepted medical treatment and was transported to Hackensack University Medical Center by Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance 194.  The suspect was described as a thin, 37-39 years old, 5'6"-5'7" light skinned black female with short dark hair wearing dark colored sweat pants and dark/gray colored sweatshirt.  It was reported by the witness that she walked West on Clay Street towards Third Street upon leaving the fight.  A check for Nicky Powell in the police records yielded negative results.  A check of third street did not produce any suspects matching that description.

P.O. Dominguez and I responded to the listed location for a dispute. The complainant is a director from EHaib Human Services and the suspect is a caretaker. The listed location is a group home that offers personal care and/or supervision. The victim, who is a patient, reported, on 04/02/2021, the suspect two handed pushed him in the chest region. The victim further reported that he believed he was not wearing a mask and too close to the suspect prior to him being pushed. The victim did not fall nor injured himself after being pushed. The complainant reported that his employer is doing an internal investigation and only wants it to be documented at this time. No further police action.

I responded to the listed location for a motor vehicle theft. The complainant reported that he parked vehicle 1 in the southeast corner of the parking lot between the listed times. He left the vehicle unlocked and car keys in the vehicle's compartment. There are no surveillance cameras overlooking the parking lot. The vehicle's insurance policy is unknown. The complainant wishes to process the vehicle and completed a consent to search form. Both front and rear license plate were on the vehicle. Additional license plates were located inside the vehicle, unknown plate numbers. The total amount stolen is $2,500.00.

On 4/10/21 at approximately 19:15 hours, I responded to 490 Essex Street, Apt. F on a medical aid call. Upon arrival I met with the victim who reported that she was assaulted by her daughter, the suspect. The victim reported that the assault occurred on 3/29/2021 at 11:30 hours. The victim complained of severe pain to the left side of her ribcage and was subsequently transported to HackensackUMC by Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance #194, while I followed.        While en route to HackensackUMC, I notified Sgt. Pierce, who responded to the emergency room and was briefed.         After the patient was assessed and treated by Hospital staff, I spoke to her in further detail about the incident. The victim stated that on 3/29/21, she and the suspect were involved in a verbal dispute which turned physical. She stated that the suspect struck the victim with a closed fist numerous times on the left side of her torso, causing her to fall to the ground. The victim further stated that while on her back on the ground, the suspect placed her left hand on the victim's neck and attempted to strangle her. The victim did not lose consciousness. She stated that she was able to free herself from the suspect, at which time the altercation ended.        The victim did not contact the police after the incident and stated that she was not injured at that time. She reported that she contacted the police on this date because her pain gradually increased.        It should be noted that the victim and suspect are mother and daughter, however they have never resided together. The victim lost custody of the suspect in 1986, while they were residing in California and that the suspect was only visiting at the time of the incident. The victim also did not have any sign of injury or residual swelling or bruising from the initial assault that took place two weeks prior to this date.         The victim wished to have the incident documented. She further stated that she would apply for a restraining order at a later date and was advised how to do so.        A New Jersey Victim Notification form was completed and a copy was given to the victim.

I responded to the listed location with P.O. Iannacone on a possible road rage incident involving a bat. On arrival, I observed two male parties standing outside two vehicles along with Detectives Peralta, Ranelli and Lyak who had them separated. I first made contact with Romano (arrestee) who reported he had been cut off by the victim's vehicle while on Route 80 West. He then followed the victim's vehicle to the off ramp onto Kennedy St. where the victim's car suddenly stopped and the victim got out and approached him in an aggressive manner. Romano exited his car with a baseball bat style steering wheel lock to defend himself. Romano stated that he pushed the victim away, but never struck him with the object.     Det. Ranelli then directed me to a tow truck driver who was parked several feet away, stating hewas a potential witness to the incident. I met with the driver who was identified as Hulahan. He stated that while traveling on Kennedy St. he observed the victim and arrestee in a physical altercation. He reported he observed the arrestee knock the victim to the ground and begin swinging a long yellow object at him. He then intervened and told the males not to go anywhere while he waited for police.     Lastly I spoke with the victim Romanello. He reported that while on Route 80 West, he had an issue with the arrestee cutting him off. He then got in front of the arrestee's vehicle and took his exit onto Kennedy St. He observed the arrestee following him down the off ramp and once he reached the stop sign, he exited his vehicle. He stated he approached the arrestee to tell him to stop following him. At that time, the arrestee exited his vehicle and knocked the victim to the ground. He stated he then threatened him with a yellow bat like object, but never struck him with it. The victim reported he felt threatened and was willing to make a statement at headquarters.     I returned to speak to the arrestee and asked him to show me the object involved in the incident. He retrieved the item from his front passenger seat and handed it to me. I then observed it to be a metal baseball bat style steering wheel lock. I secured the item as evidence and advised the arrestee he was under arrest for assault. He was handcuffed with his hands behind his back and searched incident to arrest with negative results. He was then secured in the rear of radio car 112 and the camera was activated. The victim agreed to follow officers to headquarters and the arrestee was transported without incident. The rear seat was checked prior to and after the transport with negative results.     At headquarters, the victim and arrestee met with Detectives to provide statements. The witness was contacted and also responded to headquarters to provide a statement.     I signed complaints against the arrestee for 2C:33-4B, 2C:39-5D, 2C:39-4D. He was placed on a summons and released without incident at 20:00 hours. The baseball bat style wheel lock was secured as evidence in locker 1.

I responded to the listed location on a reported motor vehicle theft. Upon arrival, I met with the victims who reported that she parked her vehicle, bearing New Jersey Registration - MVV33C, on American Legion facing East towards Overlook Avenue, on Saturday, April 10,2021, at approximately 1400 hours. The victim further reported when she returned on April 13, 2021 at approximately 1620 hours, she observed the vehicle was missing. The vehicle's estimated value was $9,000.00.            It should be noted the victim reported she locked her doors and that the keys were on her person. I checked the area afterwards with negative results. A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed. The victim wanted the vehicle processed for fingerprints if recovered and a City of Hackensack Consent to Search form was also completed.

On 04/14/2021 at aproxiamtely 13:45 hours I responded to Riverside Nissan on a stolen auto report.  Upon arrival I was met by the manager, Anthony DeOliveira who stated he needs to file a report for a stolen vehicle.  After an inventory check was conducted, he was unable to locate a 2021 Nissan Rogue.Mr. DeOliveira stated that the 2021 Silver Nissan Rogue VIn # JN8AT3DD5MW306984 was last seen on 03/05/2021 when then last inventory check was completed.  They keep vehicle's on multiple lots so he is unsure where the vehicle was last seen. He was unable to tell me who the vehicle was last seen by.Mr. Deoliveira stated that an inventory was completed today and multiple cars were missing.  After several hours the cars were located but he was unable to locate the Rogue.  He checked the computer system which showed the keys were not detected.  When he checked the vault, the keys were not present inside the vault.  He stated that all sales reps have access to the vault.The vehicle did not have any plates on it at the time it was taken.  He also stated that the vehicle was stock and had no distinguishing marks or identifiers.  The value of the vehicle is listed at$37,636.00.  He also stated that he did not want the vehicle processed and called to check if maybe the vehicle was towed.

Suspect: fair skin male, wearing a face mask, tall with slim build. Wearing a black jacket, blue or green shirt, blue jeans and black shoes.    I responded to the listed location on a reported motor vehicle theft. Upon arrival I spoke with the owner of the vehicle, Mr. John Crocco. Mr. Crocco reported he parked his vehicle in the parking lot of the listed location, today 04/14/2021 around 0900 hours. Mr.Crocco reported he parked his vehicle   near the southwest corner of the building next to an Amazon truck. He also reported the vehicle was unlocked with the key fob in the middle console. While on scene, Mr. Crocco was able to show me surveillance footage from the cameras around his building.  The surveillance footage showed the possible suspect walking out of the Bergen County Jail and crossing the street onto  Mr, Crocco's property. It shows the suspect walking towards Mr. Crocco's vehicle, a 2016 white, Ford F15 pickup truck bearing NJ license plate Z50HRP. Mr. Crocco reported both plates were on the vehicle. Due to network issues with the surveillance cameras, the video shows the suspect walking towards the vehicle but does not show the suspect enter the vehicle. Moments after the vehicle is driven away. Mr. Crocco further reported the technician was working on fixing the issue as soon as possible. Mr. Crocco will provide surveillance footage at a later date. A victim notification form and  consent to search form was signed and completed. Mr. Crocco reported the vehicle is estimated to be valued of $40,000 dollars. He also reported inside the vehicle there were several items:1. 3 pairs of sunglasses valued at $250.00 each. Unknown brand or color.2. Two or three jackets valued $250.00 total.3. One Bank of America bank card. 4. One gold PBA card from Bergen County Sheriffs.I advised Mr. Crocco to contact the financial institution about the bank card and to contact the Bergen County Sheriff officer that had given him the gold PBA card as soon as possible. I then contacted Bergen County Jail and was able to obtain information on the only inmate released during that time frame, Xhonatan Gaba of 395 Passaic avenue, Lodi,NJ 07644 . Bergen County Jail also reported Gaba was released wearing a black jacket. Bergen County Jail will provide surveillance footage at a later date. I contacted Lodi Police Department to conduct a check of the residence for the vehicle with negative results.Other possible location for Mr. Gaba could be his brother's home in Garfield- Merian Gaba, 48 Morell place, Garfield, NJ 07026. Garfield Police Department conducted  a check with negative results. Sgt. Capone responded.Detective Han was also notified.

On 4/15/2021, Det. Garrett and I were dispatched to 340 Hudson Street Apt. #13 on a report of a domestic dispute.  Upon arrival, we met the victim, Mr. Hugso Cisneros, at the entrance of the parking lot.       He stated that he was drinking with his fianc, Ms. Maria  Batista-ALberto, and she accused him of cheating on her when she discovered photographs of another female on his cellphone.  He stated that she slapped him twice on his on his right side cheek.  I did not observe any visible signs of injury and Mr. Cisneros did not complain of pain.  He also told us that he did not wish anything else to happen to her and he needed assistance to gather some belongings from inside of the apartment.  He stated that he was willing to leave as soon as he gathered his belongings.  Mr. Cisnero also a small scratch on his nose.  I asked him about the scratch and he stated that he scratched it yesterday which caused the skin to break.  I did not observe it as a fresh injury he sustained from the dispute.  His nose did not have fresh blood or dried up blood.  The injury already had a scab on it.       I then met with Ms. Batista-Alberto and she requested a Spanish speaking officer.  P.O. Mena responded and spoke with Ms. Batista-Alberto.  It should also be noted that a juvenile, J.R. (12 YOA male) was sitting on the couch located in the living room.  He appeared to be healthy and I did not observe any signs of injury.       Upon speaking with Ms. Batista-Alberto, P.O. Mena stated the same as Mr. Cisnero where she was accusing him of cheating on her when she saw photographs of another female on his cellphone.  I also did not observe any visible signs of injury on Ms. Batista-Alberto.       Mr. Cisnero wanted to grab his car keys so that he can retrieve his wallet.  He was given two set of key fobs.  He walked to the rear parking lot and entered his vehicle.  I then transported him to the Wawa (Hackensack location), to be picked up by his brother, in the rear seat of Radio Car #106.  He was checked for weapons prior to entering the vehicle which revealed negative results.  The rear seat was checked prior to and upon arrival without any incidents.  Upon arrival at Wawa, Det. Garrett and I awaited for few minutes until his brother arrived to pick up Mr. Cisneros.       D.V. report was completed and a copy of the Victim Notification Form was given to Mr. Cisneros.  DCP&P was contacted and I advised Ms. Shalma Lane #1552 of the incident.  She gathered the information that she needed and advised me that the case will be forwarded to the Bergen South Office.  I also completed the Handle with Care report.  The form was scanned and sent to Jackson Avenue School representative.

Sgt. Meneses, P.O. Rios, P.O. Tedesco, and I responded to the listed location on a report of a fight.  Upon arrival, staff had already separated the victim from the rest of the group.  After the floor was settled down and calm, I spoke to Supervisor Pete Hernandez who explained to me that victim JD was attacked by MG, JR, JR, KK, and KA all of whom are juveniles.  Hackensack University Medical Center ambulance #1341 and #3005 responded and treated the victim who sustained scratches to her arms and back of her neck.  Supervisor Hernandez signed a RMA for JD as it was deemed unnecessary to transport the victim to Hackensack University Medical Center for further treatment.  I then spoke to the victim, who stated that one of the girls kicked her while she was in bed so she defended herself by hitting her back and she was attacked by the rest of them.  Staff intervened and separated her from her attackers.No one else reported any injuries sustained in the fight.

Sgt. Deleon, Sgt. Pierce, P.O. Katsaroans, and I responded to the listed location on a report of a suicidal party walking on the railroad tracks.  Upon our arrival, I spoke with the complainant, Ashley Castillo (girlfriend), who reported that she received a phone call from the patient's brother, who advised her that he received a phone call from the patient, later identified as Jerome Johnson stating that he was suicidal. He was walking on the railroad tracks. Johnson was described as a black male, thin build, 5'10", black sweater, Blue jeans, and black and gray sneakers.  I provided the description to the units conducting a check of the area.  Sgt. Pierce located Johnson at Linden and Main Street.  Sgt. Pierce radioed that he needs assistance Sgt. Deleon, P.O. Katsaroans, and I responded to the area to assist.  Upon our arrival, Johnson was combative towards officer's we attempted to secure Johnson in handcuffs for his and the officer's safety due to Johnson being combative.  P.O. Katsaroans and I escorted Johnson to the front of Radio Car 138 and had him sit on the hood of Radio Car 138.  While attempting to speak with Johnson several times, he kept talking over officers and asking why he was handcuffed while still acting combative towards officers.  Johnson began spitting towards Sgt. Deleon, P.O. Kataroans, and I, which stuck us several times in the face and on our uniforms.  We attempted to face him towards the radio car to avoid further spitting while waiting for the ambulance.  Johnson began to bang his head against the hood of Radio Car 138.  Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance # 195 responded while securing Johnson to the stretcher. EMT's provided us with a N95 face mask for  COVID-19 protocols prior to entering the ambulance.  Johnson was transported to New Bridge Medical Center as P.O. Katsaroans, and I rode in the ambulance as Sgt. Deleon followed.    While in the ambulance, Johnson continued spitting at P.O. Katsaroans and I, which stuck our uniforms several times.  While Johnson was spitting at us, he advised us he was positive for COVID-19.  At the hospital P.O. Katsaroans stayed with Johnson while Sgt. Deleon and I responded back to police headquarters.  At police headquarters I sign complaint number S2021-000171 against Johnson for 2C:12-13.  I responded back to New Bridge Medical Center and served Johnson his complainant.  The suspect was involuntarily committed at New Bridge Medical Center for Evaluation due to suicidal statements.

I responded to the listed location on a report of a Burglary. Upon arrival, I met with Sgt. Pierce and P.O. Mena who were already on scene. P.O. Mena provided translation as the victim only spoke Spanish. The victim reported that he left the residence on 04/09/2021 at 02:30 for his flight to Mexico. He reported that when he returned to his residence on this day he observed damage to the interior door frame. The door was left open with the lights on. When the victim went upstairs he observed the apartment to be in disarray. At this time he reported that approximately $2,000.00 in U.S. Currency, three gold rings ($1,900.00) and one gold bracelet ($1,800.00) were missing from his bedroom.     I observed all of the drawers in the kitchen and bedroom to be pulled out from the cabinets and dressers. The mattress and bed frame in the bedroom had also been moved.        Det. Koenig and Det. Melillo #1759 of the Bergen County Sheriffs Department BCI responded to the scene. The victim signed a consent to search (Spanish) form and the scene was processed and photographed. A victim notification form was filled out and the victim was provided with a copy. The scene was then released back to the victim.Proceeds:1 Gold ring with the name "Alex" valued at $500.001 White Gold ring with seven diamonds valued at $800.001 Gold ring valued at $600.00 (No further description)1 Gold bracelet valued at $1,800.00 (No further description)$2,000.00 in U.S. Currency.Total Proceeds - $5,700.00

On the above date and time, I was dispatched to 47 Hobart Street on reports of unlawful taking. Upon arrival, I met and spoke to the victim, Sonia Leon, who stated that she got in a verbal argument with her boyfriend, Mario Alvarez. Due to the argument the victim stated Mr. Alvarez took his clothes and left the house in her car without her permission.  The victims car is a 2006 Ford S31 Van, black in color, bearing N.J. reg: XKNG96.  The victim believed her boyfriend will be going to stay at his brother house who lives at 70 Dewitt, Hackensack.  The area was checked, but it yielded negative results for the vehicle or Mr. Alvarez.   I provided the victim a N.J. Victim Notification Form. The approximate value of the van is $3000.

P.O. Tedesco, Sgt. Knapp and I responded to the area of 194 Clay St on a report of a fight that occurred earlier at Carver park.  Upon arrival I spoke with witness, Darleen Francis,  who stated that her grandson, EF, was slapped in the face by suspect. The witness further stated that she observed the suspect to be in possession of 2 knifes at Carver Park.  The suspect was running around with the knifes and chasing other children.  One of the knifes was described as having a pink handle according to the witness.  The witness also stated that she observed the suspect enter 194 Clay St and come back out without the knives.  The suspect than got on a bicycle and left the area.       I spoke with the victim and his brother, TF.  Both parties stated that the victim was assaulted by the suspect by her slapping the victim in the face with an open hand.  Both brothers stated that the  suspect did not attempt to assault the victim with the knifes that were in her possession.  Detective Garrett was notified by Sgt. Knapp.  The grandmother and both brothers responded to headquarters to provide a statement to Detective Garrett.  The investigation was turned over to the juvenile division.

Suspect: white male with long blonde dreadlocks, fled in an older model maroon Chrysler or Mercury with front end damage, accompanied by two black females. suspect is possibly Aaron Daza.        P.O. Tedesco and I responded to the listed location on a report of a robbery. On arrival we met with the victim and the witness. The victim reported that the above described suspect entered the store and grabbed an unknown amount of snacks and energy drinks. The suspect then exited the store without paying for the items. The victim confronted the suspect in the parking lot. The suspect exited the vehicle and then began to fight with the victim. The fight continued in the store and the suspect and victim were separated by the two females who accompanied the suspect and the witness. The suspect and two females then entered the vehicle and fled westbound on Clay Street into an unknown direction. As a result of the fight, the victim sustained an injury to his left shoulder and right hip. The victim responded to police headquarters and provided a statement to Detective DiMartino. Hackensack University Medical Center Ambulance responded to police headquarters and the victim refused further medical attention at this time.       The witness was advised to save the surveillance footage of the incident for a later date.       Through viewing the surveillance footage, Sgt. Briggs was able to identify the suspect as Aaron Daza. A belt that the suspect was wearing was recovered from the scene and secured by Detective DiMartino.      See Detective Dimartino's supplemental report for further.        A NJ Victim notification form was completed.

On this date P.O. Reyes and I were dispatched to the listed location on an active burglar alarm. Upon arrival, I discovered the front right door glass to be smashed. I entered the business to conduct  a search for the party responsible for the damage. The business was clear of any persons. I then exited the building from the hole in the glass door. When I exited the store, I was able to observe through the window that the security wires had been cut on 5 displays on the South side of the store and also on 5 displays on the North side of the store. P.O. Reyes arrived to assist. Sgt. Capone  also arrived  to assist. Sgt. Capone requested that Detectives respond.  David Haddad, the owner's brother arrived. He contacted the owner, Louis Haddad, who soon arrived. The owner had video of the incident on his phone. The suspect is described as a:       White or Hispanic male, wearing a black jacket with unknown white writing on the back, a white shirt, dark pants, black sneakers with white soles, a black baseball style hat, black face  mask, white gloves and carrying a black duffle bag.      The video shows that subject entered the building through the broken door, the video does not show how the suspect broke the glass. The suspect enters the business and goes to the South side of the business and is seen clipping the security wires on the display model Iphones  and Ipad tablets. The suspect then goes to the North side of the business and is seen clipping the security wires on 5 Iphones that were on display. The suspect then exits through the hole in the door. The suspect can be seen opening the passenger door of a dark colored SUV, possibly a SUV model Mercedes. He closes the passenger door and moves around the back of the vehicle then enters the vehicle through the driver's door. The vehicle was parked in front of the store facing North. The vehicle then drives North through the parking lot and out of camera view.      Det. Sgt. Tripodi arrived.       Loss: 3 ipad tablets, serial numbers, models and values are unknown at this time. 7 iphones, models, serial numbers and values are unknown at this time. Glass door replacement approximately $800.00. The estimated loss of the Apple products is $8,100.00. Total estimated  loss $8,900.      Det. Sgt. Tripodi will obtain the serial numbers, models and  values of the Apple products once the owner conducts and inventory. See his report for further.      Det. Christopher Mueger #1617 from the Bergen County Sheriff's Department, BCI Unit arrived to photograph the scene. See his report 2021-0356 for further.

This officer was given a list of abandoned auto's from Bergen Brookside Towing. Upon running the listed vehicles license plate it was found to be Stolen out of Fairlawn Police Department, NJ Under OCA: 21-03523, NIC: V292816885, DOL: 3/29/2021. It should be noted that there were no keys recovered with vehicle. See Case 21-001225 for Tow report and further information.

column2: Aggravated Assault 2C:12-1bSimple Assault  2C:12-1aCriminal Mischief  2C:17-3
column13: The victim and suspect and victim have been in an on again, off again relationship for 21 years and used to reside together.                The victim responded to Police Headquarters to report two separate assaults that occurred within the city of Hackensack on 4/14/21 and 4/28/21.  The victim stated that on 4/14/2021, he was in his vehicle with his girlfriend, Joslin Harrington, and they got into a verbal argument.  The argument escalated and became physical and the suspect grabbed a Patron Tequila bottle and broke it over his head.  The victim suffered a large laceration to the top right side of his head and has pictures of the injury on his cell phone.  Neither of them called the police the night the incident happened and he took himself to the hospital the next day, 4/15/21, to get his injuries looked at.  He is unsure of the hospital he went to but said its connected to Hackensack Meridian and its in either North Bergen or West New York.  The suspect also kicked out the windshield of his 2018 Nissan Maxima after striking him in the head with the bottle.  Cost to replace the windshield was $280.00.  The wound was healed by today's date and stated he no longer has complaint of pain to his head.        The victim stated that yesterdays incident, they were on Mary Street, at the intersection of Ames Street, in his vehicle and got into another verbal argument which turned physical.  The victim stated he was driving and she struck him three times, with a closed fist, on the right side of his face, just under his eye.  Neither of them called the police when the incident occurred until he decided to come to Police Headquarters today to report it.  There was no signs of injury today but he has complaint of soreness to the right side of his face from where she punched him.  I offered to have an ambulance respond to check him out but he refused medical attention.        Detective Division was notified and Det. Ghirardi and Det. DiMartino responded and spoke with the victim in the Officers Duty Room West.  The victim advised the detectives that he did not wish to give an audio and recorded statement upstairs with detectives.  He was also adamant that he did not want complaints to be signed and just wanted this all to be documented for his records and did not plan to go any further with it.        I took one photo with the patrol camera of the victims injury that is starting to scar from the 4/14/21 incident and one photo of the area under his eye where he stated he had soreness and swelling from the 4/28/21 incident.  The victim did not wish to speak to anyone from the DVRT and refused to complete a voluntary handwritten statement.  I completed a New Jersey Victim Notification Form which was explained, signed and he was given a copy.  The victim stated he does want a restraining order but will do it at a later date and was explained on the procedure on how to do so.          I signed complaint W-2021-000181 against the suspect for 2C:12-1b(1) and 2C:17-3a(1) and complaint W-2021-000182 against the suspect for 2C:12-1a(1).

On 04/30/2021 at approximately 10:00 hours Parking Enforcement Officer Salazar was in the area of 101 Prospect Ave. when he noticed a vehicle in violation of a parking offense.  The vehicle had  several summons on it as well as dirt and leaves.  He ran NJ Reg (MVV33C) which was on a white Toyota Camry.  That vehicle was reported stolen out of this jurisdiction of 04/13/2021.I responded to the location and observed the vehicle which showed no signs that it was stolen.  The door locks and ignition were both intact and not tampered with.  There was a parking summons that was issued on 04/16/2021 for no parking during certain hours.  The inside of the vehicle was not ransacked and there was still a GPS left in the center console. Officer Carillo notified and transported the owner to the scene.  She still had a key to the vehicle with her and stated the spare key is at home.  She further stated that she does not remember parking the vehicle at that location.  The vehicle was turned back over to her and the NCIC system was updated.  Det. Konieg was notified and stated he was not going to process the vehicle based on the new information.

Suspect: B/M wearing a black track suit and white sneakers.     Sgt. Briggs, P.O. Dogali and I responded to the listed location on a report of a possible burglary. Upon arrival we spoke with the victim who reported that when he arrived home he observed the windows on the top of his door to be shattered and droplets of blood on the ground. He also observed a blue key ring with a house key, a Planet Fitness (608000000014773372) card, a Shop Rite (470160073891) card, a Different Breed Sports Academy (10207064381325) card in the lock of his door and a $10.00 bill laying on the ground. The victim reported that no entry was made due to the dead bolt on the door still being locked upon his arrival. He reported that he had checked the apartment and it was negative for any parties being inside.    While on scene the witness responded outside. She reported that approximately one (1) hour in the past she heard someone banging loudly on the door. She then opened her window and asked the suspect, described as a black male wearing a black track suit with white sneakers, what he was doing. The suspect told her that he was attempting to get into his apartment. The witness then advised him that that was not his apartment and asked where he lived. She reported that he appeared confused and possibly intoxicated. He attempted to make a phone call and then left south on Esplanade. Sgt. Briggs and P.O. Dogali checked the area with negative results for the suspect.    The victim reported that the estimated cost of damage is between $150.00 and $200.00. A victim notification form was filled out by this officer and the complainant was provided with a copy. I secured the keys and the $10.00 and transported them to Police Headquarters where they were secured in evidence locker #2.

Suspect: Slim male, dark hooded sweatshirt w/ hood over his head,  gray sweatpants, book bag.      The complainant responded to Headquarters to report a motor vehicle theft. He reported at approximately 08:05 he discovered NJ-W309717 missing from his business lot of 67 S. Newman Street (Global Launch LLC). The complainant checked the security camera footage and discovered the vehicle was stolen by an unknown male party at approximately 0141 hours, May 4, 2021. The complainant stated he left the keys inside the vehicle underneath the front passenger seat because the vehicle was to be rented out by a customer for today May 4, 2021. The complainant checked the vehicle's GPS and the last known location shown was 72 Franklin Street, Hackensack, NJ.

I responded to Police Headquarters on a report of a walk-in report of simple assault.  Upon arrival, I met with the victim, Nikita Kelly. The victim reported on March 2, 2021 she and her boyfriend, Krzyszof Ziarno were traveling on Kinderkamack Road onto Johnson Ave. While traveling down the road, the suspect (Mishena Dent) and her boyfriend pulled out of a side street nearly striking her vehicle. The victim reported, she beeped at the vehicle and her boyfriend yelled "What are you doing?" The victim reported, the occupants of the other vehicle then stuck their middle finger at them and began to follow them. The victim reported the suspects boyfriend, who was the driver, pulled up on her passenger side and threw a beverage at her vehicle. After the beverage was  thrown, the driver then pulled up in front of her vehicle and stepped out of his vehicle to speak to her boyfriend. The driver told her boyfriend, lets handle this like men and he agreed. They pulled into the Cheers Bar & Restaurant parking lot located next to 85 Johnson Ave. The victim reported her boyfriend and the driver of the other vehicle settled the issue, but the driver's girlfriend, suspect-Mishena Dent was not satisfied. The victim reported, the suspect began to argue stating "You guys are dirty!". The victim reported she verbally responded back to the suspect as they were walking back to their vehicle. While walking back, the suspect charged at her and began to assault her by punching her with a closed fist on the head. While she was getting punched, they fell to the ground which caused the victim to suffer numbness to her right shoulder. The victim reported while she was getting punched on the ground, she bit the suspects ear. The victim reported after biting the suspects ear, the suspect punched her three more times then they were separated by their boyfriends.  The victim reported after departing from the scene of the incident, she went home and attended to her injuries. The victim stated on March 27, 2021 she responded to Clara Mass Hospital located in Belleville, NJ due to on going discomfort from the injuries she sustained to her shoulder. The victim reported she suffered the following injuries on the date of the incident.-Right shoulder dislocation.-Hematoma to her forehead.-Scratches to her right foot.-The eye lids under both eyes were black and blue.-A laceration under her right eye.-Swelling to her face, both cheeks. The victim provided five photographs of her injuries along with a Certification of Probable Cause, which she filed at the Superior Court of Bergen County, Docket No.: 0023-W-2021-000128. Please note, the victim of this report was previously charged with aggravated assault for biting the suspects ear off, see report: 21-013764. Sgt. Bay was notified. The victim was advised on how to file a complaint against the suspect for simple assault.

This writer was dispatched to the listed location on a report of city property damage.  Upon my arrival I spoke with the complainant, L.H..  L.H. was accompanied by his younger brothers, D.M., and J.M. and their friend L.G..   With the assistance of J.M., L.H. reported that between the listed date and times, the three juveniles (J.M., D.M., and L.G.) were playing tennis in the tennis court and were approached by two older juveniles. (Description given a Dominican juvenile male approximately 12-13 years of age and a black juvenile male approximately 11-12 years of age.)  The two suspects began to call all three younger juveniles names and stated that they were looking for an Apple air bud that had gone missing. Both suspects then approached the juvenile J.M. and each suspect slapped J.M. twice with an open hand in the area of J.M.'s neck / back of head.   J.M. did not complain of any pain and I did not see any signs of trauma.   After each suspect assaulted J.M., the suspects began to hit the tennis net, possibly causing damage to the tension cable. (See OCA # 21-028859 for further)  The two suspects then grabbed a set of tennis rackets and several tennis balls that were lying next to a fence within the tennis court area. The suspects then fled on foot out of the tennis court area with the victim's property.  L.H. observed the theft of the tennis equipment and began to chase the two suspects on foot.  After a short chase the two suspects dropped the tennis equipment and fled Carver Park in a unknown direction.  A Sergeant was requested and Sgt. Bay responded.     All four juveniles were followed to their residence of 267 Second Street were Sgt. Bay and this writer spoke with the guardians / parents of the juveniles, Mr. Marco Mejia and Ms. Jocelyn Hernandez.    Mr. Marco Mejia was asked if his son required any medical attention and responded that he did not.  Juvenile Division was notified by Sgt. Bay.

On 05/07/2021 at approximately 10:40 hours Officer Competiello and I responded to the area of 158 Tracy Pl. on a dispute.  Upon arrival we were met by Danny Quiroz who is the superintendent for Brookdale Apartments.  He stated he was assaulted by a female tenant who also made racial comments at him.Mr. Quiroz stated he was driving down Tracy Pl. in the company golf cart with Ricardo Gomez who is also an employee of Brookdale Apartments.  They stopped in front of 123 Tracy Pl. to collect the garbage at the building.  While doing so, Grace Acquaye from 123 Tracy Pl. Apt started advancing towards them in an aggressive manor.  She began yelling at Mr. Quiroz and asking him why he wastalking to other tenants about her.  At that time he got back into the golf cart and attempted to drive away.  Ms. Acquaye got in front of the cart and stopped him from driving off.  He jumped out of the cart and pulled out his cellular phone to record the incident.When he began recording from his phone, Ms. Acquaye  advanced toward him and struck him in his stomach with a underhand closed right fist.  Mr. Quiroz put up his left arm and shoved her back to create distance between Ms. Acquaye and himself.  At that time he told Mr. Gomez to contact the police.  Mr. Quiroz was not injured as a result of the assault and later refused medical attention.The verbal argument continued for several minutes between Ms. Acquaye and Mr. Quiroz through half the parking lot.  Both of them informed each other they were recording the incident.  During the argument Ms. Acquaye stated she was going to sue the company that he is employed by because he was talking to other tenants about her.  Several minutes into the dispute, Ms. Acquaye stated, " Where did you come from? Mexico, two days ago."Mr. Quiroz stated that her statement was racially bias and put him in fear because he doesn't know what she is going to do.  He also stated that he believes she was intoxicated at the time of the incident.   Enn Kunnapas who is in charge of the management company that manages Brookdale Apartments responded to the scene.   Mr. Kunnapas informed us that he contacted housing authority because Ms. Acquaye is on Section 8 and should not be acting like that.  He further stated that our tax dollars pay her rent. Sgt. Capone was notified and responded to the scene.  While on scene he contacted Det. Mora who was briefed the of incident.  He stated that he would follow up with Mr. Quiroz at a later date.  I completed a victim notification form as well as the Supplementary Bias Incident Offense Report Form.

The complainant is the registered owner of the listed vehicle.  She stated on the listed date the suspect, her son, borrowed her vehicle.  The following day (4/30) the suspect reportedly came back home and told the complainant that the vehicle had a flat tire and was left on the side of Route 17, however he didn't know the exact location.  The vehicle has not yet been returned and its whereabouts are unknown.  The vehicle has a total of three keys, all of which are in the complainant's possession.     The suspect stays with the complainant periodically but has no other known address or phone number, according to the complainant.

I responded to the listed location on a report of a dispute that had occured in the past. Upon arrival I spoke with the complainant, Mrs. Smajlaj, who reported a dispute involving her 17 yr old son K.S. and the step-father of his 17 year old girlfriend W.H.   While speaking with Mrs. Smajlaj she wanted to have K.S give me his side of the story. K.S reported he was in the home of his girlfriend W.H. He further reported he is not allowed to be in the home without her parents being there, however he still decided to enter the home. He reported they both decided to take a nap in the bedroom. Soon after, he was awakened by the father of W.H., Mr. Johnny Reyes. K.S. reported that Mr. Reyes was angry and began to push him out of the bedroom with his  hands and ultimately out of his home. K.S. reported no complaint of pain nor need of any medical attention. K.S. further reported that Mr. Reyes then threw his cellular phone onto ground and possibly broke the cell phone. Due to Mr. Reyes physically pushing K.S. Multiple times, K.S. was unable to pick up the phone from the ground and left the phone there and went home.  I then responded to 174 High street, apt 1, to see if I could retrieve the cell phone as well as to speak with Mr. Reyes about the incident that had occured.  P.O. Sheikh also responded. Mr. Reyes reported to me that he has spoken to K.S. numerous times and has told him he is not allowed in his home when he or his wife were not home. He also reported to me that when he arrived home he found K.S. and W.H sleeping in his bedroom and on his marital bed. Mr. Reyes reported upon seeing this he became upset and grabbed the cell phone and threw it on the ground. Mr. Reyes reported he then began to push K.S. out of his bedroom using his hands. He also reported he will not be paying for any of the damages caused to the cell phone. I was able to retrieve the cell phone and give it back to Mrs. Smajlaj. The cell phone had a shattered screen and was broken. Mrs. Smajlaj reported she will be contacting the phone carrier regarding the insurance on the phone the following day.   Mrs Smajlaj reported the cell phone is an apple XR black and is estimated around $1,000 dollars. At this time Mrs. Smajlaj wanted to document the incident. Mrs. Smajlaj was advised on how to sign complaints at a later time. Handle with care forms were also completed and placed in juvenile box. A victim notification form was also completed.

I was dispatched to the listed location on a report of a motor vehicle accident.  Upon arrival, it was determined that an assault had occurred.  Victim, Odai Alazzam, explained that at 15:27 he was assaulted by an unknown black male who punched him with a metal object that he believed to be brass knuckles.  The victim had a complaint of pain to his chin and a swollen lip.  Hackensack University Medical Center Ambulance 1352 arrived to treat the victim but he refused all medical attention.  I was allowed to view the store video which showed the man enter the store, walk up to the counter where the victim was standing and punched him over the counter in the face.  A weapon was observed in the suspect's hands that resembled brass knuckles.  I asked the victim why he was attacked and he stated that the suspect asked for store credit but he was not allowed to give that out so he told him no.  The suspect left the store and returned to punch him in the face.  The man fled Westbound on Central Avenue.The victim stated the suspect is described as a black male, very tall and muscular, wears glasses, has approximately 6" braided hair, is approximately in his late 20's or early 30's in age and was wearing a green hooded sweatshirt.  The victim originally advised me that he believed the suspect's name was "Tyrone". Upon returning to the store after the completion of the call, he advised me that he now believed the suspect's name was "Tyrone Clark". He was unable to provide any further specific information about him.Witness Farouq Almali was on the retail floor side standing in the Southwest corner of the store.  He observed the suspect enter the store and punch the victim.  He added that there were two unknown black males with him that waited outside during the incident.  I checked the area where the suspect may have fled but was not located.The victim was advised that Detective DiMartino will follow up with him on 5/10/21.  The victim notification form was completed and provided to the victim.

Suspect: (Kiana Wilson) Black female, 30s, heavy set wearing a black sweater and camo leggings.P.O. Farhi and I responded to the listed location on a report of a simple assault. Upon arrival I spoke to the victim who reported that as she was entering the Deli(137 Hudson Street) when the suspect who was already inside the Deli pushed her. The victim fell back on the uneven pavement and hit her head on the ground.  P.O. Farhi reviewed footage of the incident which appeared that the suspect pushed the victim intentionally.  Hackensack Volunteer Ambulance responded and transported the victim to HUMC.  It was reported that the suspect fled South on Hudson Street Prior to our arrival.  The victim reports that the suspect is known as an acquaintance that they have had issues with for years.  A check of the area was conducted with negative results.  The victim was advised on how to sign complaints.

P.O. Williams and I responded to the listed location on a report of an EDP.  Upon arrival I met with the complainant who stated that her husband, the patient, put his arms around her neck when she was changing his pants and proceeded to choke her.  According to the complainant the patient has severe Alzheimer's and dementia.  The complainant further stated that her husband's medical condition is so sever that he does not even remember to use the bathroom.  Because of the patient's medical conditions he is not able to recognize his wife or where he currently is.  I attempted to ask the patient basic questions like his date of birth, current location, and current year and he was not able to answer them.       I contacted Lt. Smith and advised him of the situation.  I also contacted 262-HELP and spoke with  screener Tom #T5451.  Screener Tom conducted a tele-health screening and determined that the patient needed to be involuntarily transported to New Bridge medical center for further evaluation.  HUMC BLS responded and transported the patient to New Bridge where he was turned over to staff without incident.  An FID check was conducted for the patient with negative results.  The complainant stated that she did not require any medical attention.       Due to the patient's limited mental facilities, it was determined that the action taken by the patient towards his wife lack culpability required for criminal intent.

On the listed date and time, P.O. Dogali and I were dispatched to Prospect Height Medical Center on a report of a dispute. Upon arrival we met with Nurse Christopher Orpilla and other staff members. The complainant stated, the victim who suffers from an altered mental status had become combative having him to be restrained to the ground. The complainant then stated during the altercation with the patient, he suffered some pain to his left hand. The complainant later refused any medical attention and would document the incident on his own report. BLS 195 then transported the victim to Hackensack UMC as per the victim's primary physician request.

I responded to 185 Ross Avenue on a report of a motor vehicle theft. Upon arrival, I met with the resident and registered owner, Munees Pasha (victim). The victim stated that he left his house at approximately 07:45 hours on this date and when he returned at 11:00 hours on this date, his 2020 White Toyota Rav-4 (NJ/Z97HDR) was missing from his driveway. The victim stated that no one else has access to his vehicle and that he only has one key for the vehicle.  While speaking with the victim, the resident at 189 Ross Avenue, MIchael Oates, responded and showed this officer his Ring doorbell camera footage. The footage shows an unknown tow truck arrive at 10:42 hours and remove the vehicle from the victim's driveway. The victim then contacted Toyota finance to see if the vehicle was repossessed, which it was not. Headquarters confirmed that no vehicle with thatregistration was in our tow log.        The victim's neighbor was advised to preserve the Ring doorbell footage, as it may be needed in the future. A New Jersey Victim Notification form was completed and the vehicle was entered in NCIC.        Geico Auto Insurance: Policy #4095-93-05-76/100.        The vehicle was valued at $35,000.00.

Suspect : White female no other description given.  I responded to the listed location on a reported dispute. Upon arrival I spoke with the victim who reported she was sitting down in Veterans Park on Hudson street with her daughter and her one year old baby. She further reported the suspect, a  white women with a dog approached her and her 1 year old baby. The victim reported she did not want the dog near her or her baby and told the woman. The victim reported at this time a verbal dispute ensued, the victim, took out a small can of mace and told the suspect to  get back. At this time the suspect grabbed the victim's mace and sprayed the victim with her own mace.  A physical altercation took place between both parties. The victim had two large scratches on each side of her face and redness to both sides of her face. I also observed spots of blood on the front of her pants. The victim reported the father of her child arrived and took her to the listed location and left her there. Initially the victim reported the father of the child was present and then changed her story and told me he was not present during the altercation. The victim reported the father of the child went home with the one year old and that the one year old was in good health. Hackensack University Medical Center Ambulance #192 responded. A RMA was signed by the victim. The victim reported she would seek medical attention on her own. The victim also reported she needed to go home and did not have to time to identify the suspect if video surveillance was obtained. The victim also reported she would possibly come back at a later time and date.   I contacted DCP&P  and spoke with Dachia #1742. The Newark north east office will follow up with a 72 hour response time. Handle with care form was also completed and placed in Juvenile box.  A copy of the same was forwarded to Newark Police, Detective Han was also notified.

Suspect: B/M, mid to late 20's, 5'10-6'00, thin build wearing black sweatpants, an ivory colored hooded sweatshirt with beige/tan sleeves with a small black Adidas logo on the left breast, a beige/tan winter hat (beanie), with black sneakers and a blue surgical face mask.        I responded to 400 Hackensack Avenue (Louis Vuitton) on a report of a Robbery. Upon arrival, I met with two employees, Jacquelin Falletta (Victim #1) and Jessica Julcapoma-Perez (Victim #2). Victim 1 reported that at approximately 12:00 hours on 5/14/21, the suspect arrived at the store and  stated he was looking for a gift for his mother and that he wished to browse the merchandise. The suspect then walked around the store, looked at, picked up and touched several items as though he was interested in purchasing something. Victim #1 stated that she followed from a distance while the Suspect browsed.        After approximately 10 minutes, the suspect suddenly grabbed three handbags off of a shelf and began running towards the doors. The entrance/exit door was propped open, however, it was blocked by a retractable belt barrier, with Victim #2 standing in the doorway. Prior to the suspect approaching the exit, he knocked into Victim #1, causing her to fall down. He then collided with Victim #2, then maneuvered around Victim #2 and fled the store in an unknown direction.        Victim #1 injured her left hand and the left side of her head as a result of being knocked down by the suspect. Victim #2 was not injured. An ambulance was requested and moments later, Hackensack University Ambulance #1326 responded. Victim #1 was evaluated and taken to HackensackUMC for further treatment.        Sgt. Melber and Detective Papanikolaou responded to the scene and were advised.        The employees stated that they did not wish the have the items that were touched by the suspect processed for fingerprints as that would damage their merchandise.        The estimated combined value of the three handbags that were taken was approximately $8,000.00. An itemized receipt was unable to be obtained at this time.        Surveillance footage was made available to Detective Papanikolaou and the scene was turned over to him.        New Jersey Victim Notification forms was completed for both the victims.

The complainant is the Building Superintendent.  He reported on the listed date and time the suspect approached him outside near the Leasing Office.  The suspect was reportedly irate, shouted obscenities and then pushed the complainant.  He then entered the Leasing Office, where the Witness works and shouted, "Who the fuck is looking for me?"  This was followed by more obscenities.     According to the witness, the suspect was angry at the fact that his girlfriend needed some sort of assistance the previous day and the complainant was unable to help her.  Prior to leaving the suspect reportedly stated, "If something would have happened to her, I would've killed him", referring to the complainant.  The complainant did not wish to sign complaints at this time.

P.O. McCarthy and I responded to the listed location on a reported dispute. Upon arrival I spoke with the victim, Ms. Jessica Gomez. Ms. Gomez reported she was visiting a friend, Ms. Caei Salazar, living at 59 Michael street  and that they had been consuming alcohol and smoking marijuana. Ms. Gomez was unsure of the apartment number. Ms. Gomez reported a verbal dispute ensued that quickly turned physical when she was trying to leave to go  home. Ms. Gomez  reported Ms. Salazer grabbed her with both hands by the neck and punched her twice in the stomach with a closed fist. I observed no marks or redness to her neck or stomach area. Ms. Gomez also reported her Paypal card was missing and that Ms. Salazar could have possibly have taken it. Ms. Gomez reported she did not see Ms. Salazar take the card but believes she could have.Ms. Gomez was advised to contact the credit card company and advise them of the situation. Hackensack University Medcal Center Ambulance #192 responded and transported her  to HUMC. Ms. Gomez reported at this time she only  wanted to document the incident and was advised on how to sign complaints at a later time and date.

Suspect: Male - late 20's, medium skin complexion, 5'10", black sunglasses, beard, pink shirt, khaki pants.        The victim, Gary Wowk, reported that on the listed time and date, he was standing in line at Starbucks (360 Essex Street). He further reported that the suspect entered the store and cut in front of him while he was waiting on line. A verbal dispute began, which turned physical, when the suspect shoved the victim and then left the store. The victim reported that the suspect entered a black sedan bearing NJ registration V96LNA. The victim requested the incident be reported for documentation purposes.

I responded to 200 Lee Place on a report of a located stolen motor vehicle.  The complainant works for Hackensack Auto Body and advised that he towed the listed vehicle on March 3, 2021 from Area E in Hackensack, NJ.  I spoke to Officer McCall who initially towed the vehicle on 3/3/21.  See report 21-014013.  The vehicle appears to have been noticed missing by the owner on 3/3/21 but wasn't reported reported stolen until 3/26/21 to the NYPD, their case number 2021047002911.No owner information is displayed from the NCIC hit.  According to the complainant, the owner of the vehicle is Santandar Bank, who has an active repossession order for the vehicle and is requesting a tow release to obtain the vehicle.  As per Lt. Natale, this case will be turned over to Officer McCall.

Sgt. Briggs, P.O. Francavilla and I responded to the listed location on a report of a fight between father and son.  Upon arrival both Emmanuel Nunez (Father/victim) and N.N.(15/suspect), were already separated.  Both parties had visible signs of injuries and both refused medical attention. Sgt. Briggs who was on scene reported that the victim had an argument with his son.  His son then stated "suck my dick" while approaching the victim.  The victim then extended his arm to keep his son back. The suspect then hit the victim in the face multiple times leaving a bruised eye.   The victim then defended himself and attempted to control his son, leaving bruising on his arms and shoulder area.  In the end the fight was separated by the other family members that were present.  While on scene, the suspect kept antagonizing the victim, stating "lets fight" while cracking his knuckles.  Sgt. Briggs contacted DCPP and spoke to Peggy #1317 who reported that they would have a 24 hours response from the Bergen South Office.  D/Sgt. L. Dominguez was notified. The father Emmanuel Nunez voluntarily left the scene and would be staying at 486 Linden Pl., Bogota. All Juveniles in the home were listed in the contacts.

I responded with Sgt. Meneses to the listed location on a reported burglary.  Upon arrival I spoke with the complainant, An Clafferty who stated that when he returned home at approximately 1500 hours he noticed his apartment door was partially open.  Upon further inspection he observed damage to the door and dead bolt.  After checking inside of his apartment he observed his bedroom cabinets to be open.  He further stated that his Apple I Mac air worth approximately $1000.00 (serial #COZMW112G086) was broken into two pieces.  According to the complainant nothing was taken from the apartment including cash and watches that he had in the cabinet drawers in the bedroom.       Sgt. Meneses and I asked the complainant numerous times if he would like to have the apartment processed and he stated "no".  Detective Han was notified and stated that he would not be responding but would follow up at a later date.  This Officer did observe damage to the dead bolt and door consistent with a forced entry.  The complainant was gone from the apartment from approximately 1230 hours to 1500 hours.

SUSPECT : (KEVIN) Hispanic male 20's high curly black hairSgt. Deleon and I responded to the Hackensack High School on a report of a group creating a disturbance. Upon my arrival, I met with the victim, who stated he was physically assaulted at Carver Park at approximately 15:30 hours. The victim stated he was in the park in the middle near the benches when the suspect "Kevin" along with multiple juvenile males confronted him. Kevin then punched the victim in the forehead. The victim stated after he was punched, multiple juvenile males started to punch him. The victim was unsure of any further suspect information at this time. The victim had a large red bruise on his forehead.       Hackensack Ambulance # 1341 responded and checked the victim who refused any further medical treatment. The victim stated he did not want to sign complaints and wished to have this report documented for his records only.

I responded to 81 McKinley Street for a simple assault report. The complainant, victim's mother, reported that her daughter was assaulted and is worried that it is going to be an ongoing issue between her and the suspect. The victim and suspect are 9th graders and have biology and english class together. The victim reported, on 05/18/2021 at approximately 1330 hours, she confronted the suspect at the main entrance of the high school (Beech Street) as to why the suspect constantly mocks her. The suspect pulled her hair in which they began wrestling until Ms. Lozano, teacher, broke up the fight. The victim and suspect were sent to the principal's office. The victim reported that she was experiencing neck and face soreness but does not want medical attention at this time. The complainant just wanted this incident to be documented at this time.

The victim and the suspect have never been in a dating relationship and have never resided together.        I responded to the listed location on a report of criminal mischief. Upon arrival, I spoke with the victim who reported that on 05/17/2021 at approximately 22:00 hours, he had the suspect over at his residence to hang out. He reported that the suspect appeared to be under the influence of drugs or alcohol and became irate when discussing finances. He reported that the suspect then stood up, clenched his fists and then approached the victim. The victim stated that he did not want to fight the suspect and attempted to wrap his arms around the suspect in order to prevent the suspect from being able to hit him and calm him down. The victim and the suspect wound up on the floor at which time the suspect began striking the victim in the face with a closed fist. The suspect then put his hands around the victim's neck and began to squeeze at which time the victim stated he had difficulty breathing but did not lose consciousness. The victim reported that he sustained bruising and cuts on his face but did not seek medical attention. The victim also denied any medical attention at this time. While on scene I observed a small scab under the victim's right eye.    He reported that during the incident the suspect also broke two kitchen cabinet doors by pulling down on them and the curtain rod to the sliding glass doors off the wall. The victim reported that he had been in contact with the suspect's father who agreed to pay for the damages. The victim showed me a receipt from Natsheh Hanyman services in the amount of $450.00. He reported that the suspect's father has stopped answering his text messages.   The victim also stated that he no longer knows the suspect's phone number due to having blocked and deleted it from his cell phone. He also believes that he may be staying at 18 Leonard Street in Tenafly at this time.   Total cost of damages: $450.00

The victim and neither suspect were ever in a dating relationship, have no children in common and have never resided together.    P.O. Farhi and I responded to the Main Street in River Edge on a report of an assault that occurred within our city. Upon arrival, we were met by River Edge Police Officers Blue and Roman. They reported that they located the victim at the intersection of Kinderkamack Road and Main Street and that she stated she had been assaulted by two males in Hackensack. We then spoke with the victim who was highly intoxicated. I observed the victim had her shirt on backwards due to the front collar being torn and a minor scrape on her left knee. The victim refused any medical attention at this time.   The victim reported that she had been at The Straphanger (126 Anderson Street) with Rowe and an unknown black male. They left The Straphanger at approximately 01:30 hours in a blue Chrysler Pacifica and drove near Fairmount School where the suspects forced the victim out of the vehicle. The victim first stated that the suspects grabbed her shoulders and tore her shirt while within the vehicle and that she had thrown a beverage on them to get away. She then changed her story and stated that Rowe had grabbed her shoulders and the other male grabbed her leg attempting to get her out of the vehicle. I asked the victim where all parties were located at this time during the incident and she stated that she was in the back seat while the suspects were in the front seats. She stated that during the incident the suspects had grabbed her breasts.   Sgt. Briggs was advised of the incident. Det. Carroll was notified.   She then again changed her story and stated that she had thrown a beverage on the suspects prior to her getting out of the vehicle and then the suspects grabbing her shoulders while she was standing in the street. At this time the victim stated that no sexual contact had occurred and that the suspects had only grabbed her shoulders.  The victim stated that she got back in the vehicle at which point Rowe drove to River Edge and forced the victim to get out of the vehicle at the intersection of Kinderkamack and Main. The victim then told the same account of being grabbed on the shoulders and removed from the vehicle at this location. When asked to clarify at which location it occurred the victim stated "both." The victim then stated "it happened by the middle school (Union Street) and then here."    It should be noted that it was difficult to obtain information from the victim due to her level of intoxication. The victim constantly refused to answer yes or no questions and would restart her account of the incident which had conflicting locations and occurrences.    Officers Blue and Roman transported the victim back to her residence.             The victim was advised to contact Detectives in the morning after she is no longer intoxicated.

Paul Bailey, the Victim responded to Police Headquarters to report an incident of a simple assault that took place on 5/20/21.      He stated that on 5/20/21 at 20:40 hours he was inside the Simple Simon's Deli near the corner of Essex Street and Prospect Ave. He stated that while in the store he saw an unknown black female which he believed worked at the the Lodi NJ DMV. She was on face time with an adult black male party at that time. The victim stated that he approached her and asked if she worked at the DMV to which she stated no. He stated that he spoke to her because he had a question about DMV information changes due to the pandemic. She then affirmed that she did not work there again. Being satisfied with the answer, a few minutes later the victim walked out of the store. While on the sidewalk he was shoved to the floor from behind and repeatedly punched and kicked . He sustained a bruise to the left side of his forehead and pain to his ribs and stomach over the assault. He stated that while he was being attacked, the suspect, an unknown black male was attacking him for "talking to his wife." The victim stated several times that he was sorry.      At this very time, the unknown female realized her and the suspect were being video recorded and quickly left the scene in an unknown direction. According to a video that was proved to the victim by a random witness, the female was not attempting to stop the altercation.     The victim did not seek medical attention at the index of the assault nor were the police called. He stated that he is willing to sign complaints against an identified suspect.      He was described as a black male standing at 507 to 509 feet in height wearing black striped Adidas pants, a black sweatshirt, black dew rag and black and white shoes. according to the video produced , he appeared to be under 200 pounds.     The unknown female appeared to be black, standing at 505 feet in height with long dread lock hair wearing a white shirt and white sweatpants. The victim stated that Simple Simon's Deli could have a clear image of her from inside the store.  The witness who was not described at the time of the report provided her phone number to the victim. 551-206-6915 . The victim was provided with a copy of the video from the witness which he has on his personal cellphone.      I made contact with a Mrs. Justyna Kolc at 13:40 and 14:15 hours via cellphone. She was provided with a work e-mail address to forward a copy of the incident.  She can be contacted at Jbkolc@gmail.com for further

Suspect # 1: 5'10 slim white male (25-30 Yrs), with black hair, wearing a white shirt and black pants.Suspect # 2: 5'10 slim white male (25-30 Yrs), with black hair, wearing a black shirt and black pants. On the listed time and date, P.O McCarthy and I responded to 7 State Street on a reported aggravated assault. Upon arrival, we met with the victim, Shkelqim Rustja and witness, Ded Sokoli. The victim reported prior to our arrival, he went to his vehicle which was parked in the parking lot, located on the north west side of the listed address. The victim reported as he arrived to his vehicle, the two unknown suspects were waiting for him. The victim reported both suspects stated in their native tongue (Albanian Kosovo Dialect) "You spoke about my wife!" The victim reported after both suspects made the statement, they pepper sprayed him then began to punch him several times with a closed fist about his head. The victim reported the suspects then struck him on the back of the head with a metal object which caused him to fall on the ground. The victim reported while he was on the ground, the suspects kicked him several times then fled at an unknown direction. The victim reported the suspects did not take any of his property, and believes someone sent them to assault him. The victim stated at this time, he will not name the suspected person(s), as he would like to confirm who had sent the two suspects to assault him. I observed a laceration to the back of the victims head and an abrasion to his right knee. P.O McCarthy canvassed the surrounding area for the suspects, which yielded negative results. While on scene, Hackensack EMS #1062 arrived. Upon contact, the victim refused medical attention.   I then spoke to the witness, Ded Sokoli, who reported as he exited the rear door, he observed the suspects flee north on State Street. The witness reported he did not witness the assault. Please note, there are two cameras mounted on the north west side of the listed address, which may have captured the incident. Sgt. Bay was apprised of the incident and advised the Detective Division. The victim and witness responded to Police Headquarters, and were turned over to Det. Carroll. A NJ Victim Notification Form was completed.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleTheft by Deception  2C:20-4Fraud
column13: On Saturday, May 22, 2021 at approximately 1451 hours, the victim and his wife (witness) responded to police headquarters to report fraud. The victim reported he observed an advertisement for the listed vehicle which was being sold for $12,000.00 on Facebook Marketplace on 05/21/2021, under the profile name "Adebisis Lateefat". The victim then contacted the suspect at approximately 0955 hours to express his interest in purchasing  the vehicle. The suspect provided the victim his phone number (929-321-2672) to continue discussing the terms of sale. At approximately 1859 hours, the victim, the witness, and their son, A.M. met with the suspect in the parking lot of CVS (837 Roosevelt Avenue, Carteret, NJ 07008).
