The witness then reportedly checked the vehicle's CARFAX vehicle history report which did not return any results for the vehicle being stolen. The victim reported after checking the CARFAX, he test drove the vehicle in the area of the CVS. During the test drive, the victim drove while the suspect sat in the rear passenger seat. The suspect then advised the victim that he did not have the title, but would be able to provide it at a later date. The victim agreed to pay the suspect $8,500.00 cash for the vehicle and provide an additional $1,000.00 after receiving the title. The victim then drove the vehicle to his home at 222 Elleen Terrace and parked it in his garage (garage #4). The suspect later texted the victim photos of his New York driver's license, a New York State Certificate of Title, and a State Farm insurance card. The victim further reported he located a Texas Buyer's Tag Receipt and the suspect's cellphone in the vehicle.A check of the vehicle identification number revealed that it was reported stolen in Newark, NJ on 05/06/2021. While in headquarters, the victim provided me with the suspect's cellphone, a black iPhone. The phone number for the iPhone was 929-321-2672. The iPhone was placed in a paper evidence bag and secured in evidence locker #2. The handwritten bill of sale, a photo of the suspect's New York driver's license, a photo of the New York State Certificate of Title, a photo of the State Farm insurance card, and the Texas Buyer's Tag Receipt were submitted to BCI. Photocopies were submitted to Detectives. A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed and the victim was provided with a copy.I then responded to 222 Elleen Terrace (garage #4) with the victim and the witness. I observed the listed vehicle backed into the garage. I observed Texas Buyer temporary license plate 10955N5 displayed on the rear of the vehicle. I removed the plate and it was later secured it in evidence locker #3. Photocopies of the plate were submitted to BCI and Detectives. Headquarters notified the vehicle's owner, Olukakorede Adekola, at 1705 hours of the proper procedure for retrieving the vehicle from All Points Towing. Detective D. Carroll was notified by Sgt. Melber. The investigation was turned over to the Detective Division.

P.O. Tanucilli and I responded to the listed location on a reported unwanted party. Upon arrival I observed Mr. Sucuzhanay outside holding his right arm. He reported to me, he entered the listed location to purchase a sandwich. He further reported the manager began yelling at him and told him to leave the store. Upon leaving the store, Mr. Sucuzhanay reported he was then pushed by the manager onto the ground. Mr. Sucuzhanay sustained a medium size scratch on his arm and refused medical attention.  I then spoke the complainant, the manager of the store, Mr. Osama Akhtar. Mr. Akhtar reported to me that Mr. Sucuzhanay was in the store trying to purchase a sandwich. He further reported to me he   told Mr. Sucuzhanay he was not going to serve him due to past incidents with him. Mr. Sucuzhanay got upset and threw the sandwich at Mr. Akhtar, hitting him in the face. Mr. Akhtar then began to yell at Mr. Sucuzhanay and followed him out of the store and pushed him with both hands and Mr. Sucuzhanay fell. Mr. Akhtar did not want any further police action and refused medical attention but wanted Mr. Sucuzhanay dispersed.  Mr. Sucuzhanay wanted the incident documented and was advised on how to sign  complaints  at a later date. He was dispersed from the area.

Suspect #1: Black male, unknown description.Suspect #2: Black male, unknown description.Suspect #3: Black male, unknown description.  On the listed time and date, P.O McCarthy and I responded to 65 Hackensack Ave (Taco Bell) on a report of a male party bleeding at the front door. Upon arrival, we met with the victims, Alexander Yakushev and Gregory Krivoscm. I spoke to Mr. Krivoscm, who reported while he and his friend Alexander were walking down an unknown street, he observed three black males, which he believed were smoking weed. Mr. Krivoscm told the three suspects they shouldn't be smoking weed. At that time an argument ensued which turned physical. Mr. Krivoscm stated after he and Alexander fought the three suspects, they walked to Taco Bell and the three suspects fled at an unknown direction. Mr. Krivoscm stated he was not injured and refused medical attention. Mr. Krivoscm was also unable to provide a description of the three suspects, nor the location of the incident. Sgt. Bay and Sgt. Klosk arrived to assist. I then spoke to Mr. Yakushev, who stated while he and his friend, Gregory were walking down an unknown street, they had an argument with three unknown black males. Mr. Yakushev stated he did not know what the argument was about, but it escalated into a physical altercation. After the fight, he and his friend walked to Taco Bell and the three suspects ran away. I observed Mr. Yakushev with a laceration to the back of his head, and blood on his head and neck. Mr. Yakushev was unable to provide a description of the three suspects, nor the location of the incident. While on scene, Hackensack EMS #1345 arrived and transported Mr. Yakushev to Hackensack University Medical Center for treatment. P.O McCarthy transported Mr. Krivoscm to his home.

column2: Aggravated Assault 2C:12-1bCriminal Trespass  2C:18-3Disorderly Conduct  2C:33-2
column13: P.O. Furcal and I responded to Target (630 Main Street) on a report of an employee, who was just terminated and refusing to leave the store. Upon arrival, I met with Target Loss Prevention officers, who directed me to the electronics section of the store, where the arrestee was standing. Once the arrestee looked in my direction she began walking away. I attempted to speak with her however, she ignored me and began slowly walking around aimlessly through each isle. I advised her that she needed to leave the store, to which she replied "I'll walk whichever way I want." I then followed the arrestee from a close distance, while attempting to direct her to the exit. Once she reached the vicinity of the exit, she suddenly turned around to reenter the store. I stood in front of her in order to prevent her from doing so, as she ultimately was refusing to leave after being toldto multiple times.  As she turned around to walk back in the store she made physical contact with me. I then grabbed her arm to escort her outside and off the property, at which time she violently swung her arm which was holding a cup of ice water and struck this officer in the chest. I then advised her that she was under arrest and told her to place her hands behind her back, which she refused to do. P.O. Furcal arrived and assisted with controlling the now aggressive and combative arrestee, who was now yelling and causing a scene, in front of the large group of patrons inside the establishment. Her arms were physically placed behind her and she was successfully placed in handcuffs. The arrestee was then escorted outside, searched and seated in the rear of Radio Car #119. She was transported to headquarters in R/C #119, which was checked prior to and after transport.        At headquarters a secondary search of the suspect was conducted with negative results for weapons or contraband.        The arrestee was photographed, processed and placed in Cell #5.        She was charged with the following charges on Summons #S-2021-000213:-Aggravated assault of a Police Officer: 2C:12-1b(5)(a)-Criminal Trespass: 2C:18-3(a)-Disorderly Conduct: 2C:33-2(a)        The arrestee was then released without incident along with a copy of her CJP Notice form with a June 7th, 2021 court date.

P.O. O'Neill and I responded to the listed location on a report of an E.D.P. in the parking lot. Upon my arrival, I met with the victim along with the complainant. The complainant stated she observed the victim walking around the rear parking lot speaking to herself. I asked the victim why she was in the parking lot and how did she get there. She stated that we had brought her there and she was looking for her clothes and belongings. The victim was wearing one shoe and appeared to be paranoid about someone stealing her clothing. She could not stand still and appeared to be having third party conversations with herself. I asked the victim if she was feeling depressed, which she started to cry and said yes. I asked the victim if she wanted to harm herself or others, which she nodded with her head up and down and said yes.    Based on the victim's behavior and her statements, I asked the victim if she would like to be treated at a hospital for mental heath. She first said yes, then said no and started to get agitated. Hackensack Ambulance #193 was notified and responded. The victim attempted to walk away and was advised multiple times to stop. For her safety and officer safety, P.O. O'Neill and I placed hand cuffs behind the victims back. While in the attempt, the victim grabbed onto P.O. O'Neill's right forearm digging her nails into her skin. The victim then attempted to spit on us while she was escorted into the rear seat of the ambulance but was unsuccessful.    P.O. O'Neill road in the rear of the ambulance while I followed behind in radio car 138, to New Bridge Medical Center. I contacted 262- Help and spoke with Minauti, who agreed the victim shall be committed involuntarily. Upon our arrival, the victim was turned over to hospital staff without further incident. A firearms ID check of the victim was conducted with headquarters, which was negative on firearms.

This writer responded to the Hackensack Hospital Ped ER unit on a juvenile investigation. Upon arrival, I spoke to the complainant who reported that her husband, the suspect, assaulted their juvenile son, the victim. She reported that while she was putting the victim to bed around 2200 hours, the victim informed her that when he was getting ready for school the suspect became angry and slammed him on the floor and the bed multiple times. The victim reported that his body hurt all over and his nose was bleeding. The complainant waited till morning to take the victim to hospital, due to fear of upsetting the suspect.    The victim was still suffering from abdominal and elbow pain. The complainant stated that the suspect has been abusive in the past to all of their children. Sgt. Deleon responded on scene. Detective Lara-Nunez was notified and responded. TOT Juvenile Division.

P.O. O'Neill, P.O. Small, P.O. Farhi and I responded to 240 Prospect Avenue on a report of a two male suspects attempting to steal a motorcycle on the third floor parking garage. As I pulled into the front entrance of 240 Prospect Avenue. I observed two male suspects walking towards me wearing dark clothing. I also observed one of the suspects holding onto bolt cutters. I exited my vehicle and stated " Hackensack Police, Stop."  I  immediately detained one of the arrestee and secured him into the rear seat of radio car 138. The second suspect dropped the bolt cutters and started to run out of the parking lot then ran across the street into the area of 245 Prospect Avenue.      I immediately gave out the description to the other responding units of a Hispanic male in his 20's, wearing dark color sweat pants with a dark color sweatshirt. Sgt. Knapp, Sgt. Pierce P.O. Rios responded to assist. The second suspect was not located however, after canvassing the area Sgt. Knapp located a stolen vehicle along with a male suspect.  See his supplement report for further.     P.O. Rios responded back to 240 Prospect Avenue, and responded to the third floor of the parking garage at 240 Prospect to inspect the motorcycle.   He observed a metal cable that was cut, which was used to secure the motorcycle. See his supplement report for further.     P.O. Rios then responded to the complainant, who had witnesses the event.  He asked if he was willing to point out the suspect by doing a show up which he agreed to.   P.O. Rios responded to my location. I removed the suspect from the rear seat of my vehicle and placed him under a parking lot spot light. P.O. Rios drove by with the witness, who positively identified the suspect I had detained. I then secured the bolt cutters that was red in color in unmarked radio car 138, which was transported back to headquarters.    Based on the following indicators I placed the arrestee under arrest.The suspect wearing dark color clothing, walking with the other suspect who was carrying bolt cutters used as burglar tools leaving the scene of a crime.The suspect not living in 240 Prospect Avenue and having no reason to be in the parking lot.The damage sustained by the metal lock from the bolt cutterThe witness positively identifying the suspect in a show up.    The arrestee was then searched incident to arrest yielding negative results on contraband. He was seated into the rear seat of unmarked radio car 138, which was checked prior to and after transport with negative results on contraband.    At headquarters the arrestee was finger printed, photographed, and processed. The bolt cutters was secured in locker number 2 as evidence. The cut cable to the lock was photographed using the patrol camera and returned to the victim. A victim notification form was completed. I charged the arrestee with complaint number 0223 S 2021 000218 for the following:2C:20-3a2C:17-3a(1)2c:5-5a(2)The arrestee was released given a court date of 06/07/2021

The following vehicle a white in color Chevy Express van bearing Arizona license plate AJ78896, was parked at Golf and Summit. It was parked in violation of 170-8 no parking certian hours and was issued summons H-939856 for the violation. A computer check on the registration came back as a  stolen vehicle out of Jersey City. I advised headquarters to confirm it was a stolen vehicle and verified the VIn. number.  It came back as a confirmed stolen auto.  I completed an impound report as the vehicle was towed to Tumino's towing. On the vehicle was U-Haul from 20 Poplar St. East Rutherford NJ 201-355-5818.

The complainant stated on the listed date and time she received a text message from her ex-boyfriend, Rodney Cruz, which gave the location of her vehicle.  He also advised the complainant that the key was left in one of the wheel wells.  The vehicle was reportedly located by the complainant on Kaplan Avenue, just East of South Prospect Avenue.  No vehicle damage was reported.  Sgt. Klosk responded and New York Police Department was notified of the recovered stolen vehicle via teletype.

While on patrol in Radio Car #116, I was in the area of Arcadia Road and Essex Street. The ALPR alerted me to a stolen vehicle. The vehicle was located  parked and unoccupied. Headquarters confirmed that the vehicle was stolen out of Jersey City. Jersey City Police Department was contacted and they indicated that they did not wish to have the vehicle processed. A tow truck was requested and Hackensack Autobody responded. The vehicle was removed. See tow report for further.               Sgt. Knapp and P.O. Katsaroans responded to assist.

While patrolling in R/C138, in the area of 60 Berkshire Place, for a possible dispute, the ALPR (Automatic License Plate Reader) altered me on a stolen vehicle bearing New Jersey registration V38JPP on a BMW.  The vehicle was located parked and unoccupied with a key in the ignition.  Sgt. Knapp and P.O. Seretis arrived to assist.   Headquarters confirmed that the vehicle was stolen out of Paterson, NJ.  The Paterson Police Department was contacted, and they did not wish to have the vehicle processed.  A tow truck was requested, and Hackensack AutoBody responded and removed the vehicle.  Also, it should be noted P.O. Seretis located a stolen vehicle in the area of Arcadia Road and Essex Street see his report for further case number 21-044657.  Sgt. Knapp  notified D/Sgt. Tripodi.
vehicle was cleared from NCIC.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: P.O. McCarthy, P.O. Reyes, and I responded to the area of 86 Anderson Street in an attempt to locate a stolen motor vehicle. Headquarters advised the vehicle may be bearing New Jersey registration - Z74MJY and that the last characters of the VIN were "50108." While checking the area P.O. McCarthy observed a white Honda Pilot bearing New Jersey Temporary Vehicle Registration - W528180, parked directly in front of 86 Anderson Street facing West. The VIN number on the front windshield was observed to be, 5FNYF6H30KB037752.        Thereafter a person later identified as Patricia Perez-Lopez approached us and asked if her vehicle needed to be moved. I then asked Patricia Perez-Lopez if the vehicle belonged to her and she replied that it did. Patricia Perez-Lopez stated that she received the vehicle as a gift from her husband on July 10, 2021. Patricia Perez-Lopez had the vehicle key Fob in her possession and stated she had parked the vehicle in front of 86 Anderson Street as she was there for a Bazaar that was taking place. Patricia Perez-Lopez was asked if she can turn the vehicle on to which she complied. While standing near the driver's side door, I observed the VIN sticker on the door jamb frame to be bubbling and peeling. Sgt. Briggs responded to assist with the investigation shortly thereafter.           A Consent to Search Form was read aloud in Spanish. Patricia Perez-Lopez was advised of her right to refuse the search and stop the search at any time. Patricia Perez-Lopez voluntarily and knowingly signed the Consent to Search Form. I stood-by with Patricia Perez-Lopez as Sgt. Briggs and P.O. McCarthy conducted a search of the vehicle which yielded altered vehicle identification numbers. The Frame VIN matched the same as the stolen vehicle (VIN #5FNYF6H98LB050108). See Sgt. Briggs's supplemental report for further. Sgt. Briggs then advised me to place Patricia Perez-Lopez under arrest.            Patricia Perez-Lopez was handcuffed with her hands behind her back, seated in the rear of marked radio car #120, and transported to headquarters as P.O. Reyes followed. The rear seat was checked before and after transported with negative results for contraband.         While in headquarters, a search of Patricia Perez-Lopez was conducted by P.O. Reyes with negative results for contraband. Patricia Perez-Lopez was photographed and fingerprinted by P.O. Reyes. A property sheet and a CJP Notice in Spanish was signed by Patricia Perez-Lopez and she stated she not want to provide a statement to Detectives.         I signed complaints against Patricia Perez-Lopez for violation of 2C:20-7A (Receiving Stolen Property, Third Degree) and 2C:17-6B (Altering VIN, Third Degree). Patricia Perez-Lopez was released on her recognizance thereafter.         Items 5 of 5 secured in Brown evidence bag include:          - One (1) New Jersey Temporary Plate bearing - W528180 along with one (1) license plate bracket color black, bearing Exclusive Auto Gallery on the bottom          - One (1) VIN (5FNYF6H30KB037752) sticker removed from driver's side door jamb (frame)          - One (1) plastic black piece  "HONDA COVER, VIN PLATE "imprinted on it.           - One (1) Temporary Vehicle Registration card for vehicle bearing license plate W528180          - One (1) Plastic black license plate bracket bearing Exclusive Auto Gallery          One (1) Rolex Oyster Perpetual Datejust was a high-end jewelry item seized due to being found in a recovered stolen motor vehicle. Items secured in Evidence Control No. 3798910 pending proof of ownership:            - One (1) Rolex Oyster Perpetual Datejust valued at $13,000.00. Rolex contained inside a red gift box with extra links.All Evidence was secured in Temp Locker #6

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: On 7/11/2021 at approximately 1254 hours, P.O. McCarthy and P.O. Carrillo were out with a possible stolen vehicle in front of 86 Anderson Street.  P.O. McCarthy requested the return on the New Jersey temporary plate W528180 affixed to the recovered stolen vehicle.  A check showed that vehicle is a 2019 Honda Pilot 4 door colored white.  P.O. McCarthy advised that the recovered vehicle matched the description of the 2019 Honda Pilot.  I conducted a commercialized computer database search which yielded that the 2019 Honda Pilot had approximately 30,000 miles when it was in a crash resulting in the vehicle being a total loss/salvage.  The vehicle was only owned in Ohio and was never registered in New Jersey.  A public records search of that vehicle yielded an auction web-site which showed that damage to the vehicle.  I advised P.O. McCarthy of the damage, to which P.O. McCarthy advised that the vehicle appeared to be new and did not have any obvious signs of prior damage.               P.O. McCarthy and P.O. Carrillo advised Headquarters that a potential owner, Perez-Lopez, had approached them and stated that the car belonged to her.  She further stated that the vehicle was purchased at an auction by her husband, Fernandez, who works for Exclusive Auto Gallery in Paterson, NJ.  Perez-Lopez was able to turn the vehicle on with a key fob.  P.O. McCarthy advised me that the vehicle had a New Jersey inspection sticker which had an expiration date of 5/25.  A check of the recovered stolen vehicle showed that the vehicle was purchased in 5/2020.  Based on the purchase date, I was aware that the inspection expiration date would be 5/25.  P.O. McCarthy also advised me that the odometer showed that the vehicle did not have more than 10,000 miles.  P.O. McCarthy also advised me that the public VIN matched the VIN on the temporary plate, but the door frame VIN appeared to be bubbling.                  I responded to the scene and met with P.O. McCarthy, P.O. Carrillo, and Perez-Lopez.  I looked at the door frame VIN and observed that it was both bubbling and peeling.  I also saw that the sticker stated "MFD. BY HONDA MFG. OF ALABAMA, LLC" instead of "AMERICA."  The door frame VIN sticker also stated that the vehicle had 18 inch rims, however the door frame tire sticker stated that the vehicle had 20 inch rims.  I checked the tires and observed that the rims were in fact 20 inch rims. I then began to peel the door frame VIN sticker which peeled right off.  A real VIN sticker would disintegrate on the door as it was being peeled.  Based on the discrepancy with the inspection sticker, the discrepancy with the mileage, the misprint of Alabama instead of America, the initial call from SiriusXM in reference to the stolen vehicle, the difference in rims, the door frame sticker not disintegrating while being removed, as well as my training and experience, I advised P.O. Carrillo to request consent to search (See P.O. Carrillo's original incident report for further).                 P.O. McCarthy and I conducted a search of the vehicle.  I located the Frame VIN which I confirmed was the same as the stolen vehicle (VIN #5FNYF6H98LB050108).  In the engine compartment, I located a small black piece of the vehicle which was broken off.  The black piece had "COVER, VIN PLATE "imprinted on it and the rivet holes on the piece lined up with the rivets on the public VIN.  I also pressed the emergency button near the rear view mirror.  The operator confirmed that the vehicle that I pressed the emergency button on belonged to a Sandra Reyes, whom reported the vehicle stolen.  I advised P.O. Carrillo to place Perez-Lopez under arrest.                The vehicle was impounded by Hackensack Towing.

I was checking the area of 275 Third St for a stolen vehicle that was an LPR hit by the complainant.  I located the vehicle parked in the rear lot of 260 Prospect Ave, the vehicle was locked and both  plates were on the vehicle. A teletype was sent to Clifton pd and it was confirmed as still stolen. Hackensack auto body responded and removed the vehicle. All alarms were canceled on the vehicle

Suspect: described as a light skin black male, wearing all black, younger approximately in his early 20s, thin build, approximately 05'9".      The victim responded to police headquarters on this date to report a suspicious incident/attempted carjacking. The victim reported that she was driving eastbound on Central Avenue near the intersection of First Street when the above described suspect entered the roadway. The victim stopped her vehicle to avoid running the suspect over. The suspect then began to pull on the car door handle on the driver's side in what appeared to be an attempt to enter the vehicle. The door was locked and the suspect was unable to gain entry into the vehicle. The suspect then continued walking southbound on First Street towards the corner store. The victim then responded to police headquarters to report the incident along with the witness.      Det. Ghirardi responded to police headquarters. See his supplemental report for further.

An employee of Simons market 337 Essex St.  flagged me down and stated the vehicle had been parked on the property for several days.  A check of the registration  Az/ae86303 showed the vehicle was reported stolen on 09-05-21 out of Albany, NY.  I advised headquarters and they verified it was still active as stolen.  The vehicle had one plate on it and the key was located on the front driver seat.   Teletypes were sent to notify of recovery and to cancel the alarm. Vehicle was towed by Court house auto body to there tow yard.

I responded to the listed location on a report of a recovered stolen vehicle (IN-3147712). The complainant who is a security agent for Penske Truck Rentals utilized a GPS tracker to locate the vehicle on Orchard Place. A check of the registration and VIN revealed that the vehicle was reported stolen from the PA State Police (NIC/V093209748).       While on scene I was approached by Sabbage Bashar, who stated that he is the property owner at the listed location. Bashar was informed that the vehicle was reported stolen. Bashar stated that he rents the parking spot and a unit to Inch Perfect Logistics, a moving company. He further stated that the company is owned and operated by Vanessa Gonzales. Bashar contacted Gonzalez via cellphone and she stated via speakerphone that she subcontracts individuals for moves who subsequently rent the vehicles on the company's behalf.       I contacted the Pennsylvania State Police and spoke to Trooper Buzzard. He was asked if he wished to have the vehicle impounded and processed which he stated that they did not. NCIC alerts were then canceled for the vehicle.        Kelly Cramer, an employee of Penske Truck Rentals, responded to the scene and took custody of the vehicle.
Vehicle was located by Newark PD at 2009 McCarter Highway. Owner notified and vehicle cleared from NCIC.Nic/ V943258906

On Sunday, September 26, 2021, while on patrol in marked radio car #116, I received a stolen vehicle notification through the Automatic License Plate Reader. I advised headquarters to confirm  the stolen hit confirmation for New Jersey registration, T59NKD. The vehicle was parked facing East near 445 Thompson Street. Headquarters confirmed the hit confirmation out of Rochelle Park. Sgt. Melber responded.            While walking around the vehicle I observed the vehicle to be unlocked, the ignition did not appear to have been tampered with, an after market radio was partially detached from the center console, and various items to be strewn about the floor board and seats of the listed vehicle. The listed vehicle's title also appeared to be on the front passenger's seat.                   All Points Towing responded and towed the recovered stolen vehicle to Bergen County Sheriff's B.C.I. to be processed as I followed. Recovered stolen vehicle was turned over to Det. Schettino #1733. See BCI Case #2021-0786 and Rochelle Park case #I-2021-9469 for further. Bergen County BCI receipt was placed in Hackensack BCI box.
Vehicle was located by Paterson PD file #87298.  The owner was notified and vehicle was cleared from NCIC. Nic/V723311434

The victim responded to Police Headquarters to report a stolen vehicle recovery.     She stated that on 10/1/2021 her vehicle was located in Jersey City N.J. at a local bus stop by a friend of the victim. The vehicle was located at the intersection of Kearny/ Bergen Ave with a ticket on the windshield for parking in a bus zone on 9/28/2021 at 10:23 A.M.      She is reporting that she wants no further action because the vehicle was found in good condition except for a dead battery. She further states that nothing was taken from the vehicle.

This writer received a hit confirmation from the New York City Police Department. It stated that they recovered this vehicle that was reported stolen to the Hackensack Police Department on October 11, 2021.  The vehicle was cleared from NCIC and all alarms were canceled. The owner was notified by DLT. Ryan Weber at 1315 hours that the vehicle was recovered and to contact NYC PD.

This officer was contacted by Mr. Lars whom is the manager of Court House Towing. He stated that on 10/25/2021 he was sent to 107 Hudson Street for a private property violation see OCA: 21-074994. He recovered the listed vehicle and contacted me today for ownership information to start the abandoned auto process. Upon this officer running the vehicle in NCIC it was found to be stolen from Fairview PD under OCA:21-12067 on 9/29/2021. It was noted that the ignition key was broken off inside the ignition, driver side window was found half rolled down, with doors unlocked, No license plates attached to vehicle. NIC: V573310348

While on patrol I observed a highend Mercedes G63 AMG backed into a parking spot at the listed location, a business which was closed, with no front license plate.  I exited my vehicle and located a rear license plate, PA LTK7998.  I ran the plate on my MDT and it showed a possible stolen vehicle match.  I contacted headquarters and dispatch was able to confirm it was stolen through NCIC.  NIC number V573391383,  reported stolen by fraudulent purchase to Pennsylvania State Police Hazelton Barracks on September 29, 2021.      Sgt Meneses and PO Conlon arrived and assisted.  The vehicle was locked, and heavily tinted, unable to see the rear cargo area and did not appear to be a key fob within the vehicle. Hackensack Auto Body responded and removed the vehicle. See tow report.   See page 2.     While the vehicle was being offloaded at the impound lot, the operator arrived and attempted to retrieve it.   I responded to the impound lot along with PO Oneill and Sgt Meneses.  I met with Mr. Joam Batances who stated he purchased the vehicle from an unknown person off the internet for $60,000, and then had a friends girlfriend title and register it in PA under her name for cheaper insurance rates.  PA state police advised to gather his information and they would be in contact to follow up.

While on patrol in the area of 84 Main Street I was approached by an unknown bystander.      The bystander stated that she noticed the listed stolen vehicle had been running unattended since 4pm. I confirmed through police communications that vehicle was reported stolen. Contact was made with the registered owner who arrived on scene several minutes later. She reported that nothing appeared to be missing and that she was not interested having the vehicle fingerprinted. She then took possession of the vehicle at this time.
Vehicle cleared from NCIC Nic/v343459971

While patrolling in R/C138, in the area of Holt Street and Lodi Street, the ALPR (Automatic License Plate Reader) altered me on a stolen vehicle bearing New Jersey registration C87NZC on a white Mercury Mountaineer.  The vehicle was located parked and unoccupied.  Headquarters confirmed that the vehicle was stolen out of Hawthorne, NJ.  The Hawthorne Police Department were contacted, and they did not wish to have the vehicle processed.  A tow truck was requested, and Court Auto Body responded and removed the vehicle. See tow report further.

On 12/02/2021 Hackensack Police Department received a call from Court House Autobody regarding a suspicious vehicle they towed off of private property.  They stated they towed a 2007 black Audi bearing MD Reg (9EL5965) from Jackson Ave.  The plates that were on the vehicle were fictitious.During the time we received the call from Court House Auto Body, Telecommunicator J. Gervasi received a late NCIC hit regarding the vehicle.  The late hit showed that the vehicle was stolen out of Bogota on 12/02/2021 (OCA 2021-014805).  I responded to Courthouse Autobody and verified the VIN on the vehicle which matched the stolen one.  I removed both plates and turned them over to the Traffic Division.  The vehicle was removed from NCIC.

This writer responded to the listed location on a recovery of a stolen motor vehicle. Upon arrival, I met with the victim who stated that he located his own vehicle which was parked in the rear parking lot of 173 South Newman Street near Kenneth Street. The listed vehicle was still running with the keys in the ignition. The victim stated that nothing was stolen from within his vehicle, and that he does not want the vehicle processed.

Sgt. Knapp and I responded to the area of 75 Oak Street to locate a stolen automobile bearing NJ registration D14PEM.  Lexus/Toyota Safety tracked a stolen vehicle to this area and it was located in the impound lot of Bergen Brookside Towing located at 83 Zabriskie Street.  I spoke to Brookside Towing Manager Brian Groschel who advised me that he received a request to tow the listed stolen vehicle at 04:17 hours on 12/30/21 on the Garden State Parkway near mile marker 160.7 located in Saddle Brook, NJ.  He advised that the NJ State Police located the vehicle at that location which was crashed into the guard rail and unoccupied.  The vehicle was not reported stolen at that time and 3 NJSP Troopers had entered and searched the vehicle.The Brookeside Towing Manager also entered the vehicle to drive it onto the tow truck.He explained that the troopers searched the area and did not find any occupants.  Englewood PD was contacted and advised they would be responding to escort the tow to Bergen County BCI for forensic analysis.  The vehicle was turned over to Englewood Detective Sergeant Laraia #206 at 14:10 hours.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Impound
column13: On Sunday, January 2, 2022 at approximately 1516 hours, I responded to 505 South River Street (WAWA) on a report of a parking violation on private property. Upon arrival, I met with manager Angela Winkens (complainant), who reported the listed vehicle had been parked in the WAWA parking lot for several days. The complainant requested to issue a summons.I then responded to the parking lot where I observed the listed vehicle, a beige Hyundai Veracruz bearing New Jersey registration YUD78Z, parked facing north, in a parking space near fuel pump #2. The right rear tire of the vehicle was blown out. An inquiry on the registration revealed that the vehicle was entered into NCIC as stolen on 12/28/2021 by the Mount Laurel Township Police Department.Communications confirmed the vehicle's status as stolen. Court House Auto Body responded and removed the vehicle. See tow report for additional information.

column2: Receiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7Recovered Stolen VehicleWarrant Arrest
column13: On February 15, 2022, I was on duty assigned as the Narcotics Bureau Commander.  I was operating unmarked vehicle R/C 136, in plain clothes with my BWC, badge, and service weapon clearly visible on the exterior of my clothing.  R/C 136 is equipped with emergency lights, sirens, and push bar.     I was traveling north on Prospect Avenue near 30 Prospect avenue, and observed the listed vehicle pass my vehicle traveling southbound on Prospect Avenue.  I observed the license plate of the vehicle and immediately realized that is was a reported stolen vehicle from 51 Newman Street.  The vehicle was reported stolen on this date at 0451 hours.  The vehicle had been entered into NCIC and assigned NIC# V213687142.   After seeing the vehicle, I changed direction and attempted to catch up to the listed vehicle.  The vehicle had made a left turn from Prospect Avenue and began traveling east on Essex Street.  I notified Headquarters via radio that I was following an occupied stolen vehicle and to have some units in the area before I attempt a motor vehicle stop.  Headquarters acknowledged and dispatched P.O. O'Neill, S.P.O. Colombini, P.O. Gretkowski, and Sgt. Klosk.  The vehicle continued east on Essex Street and abruptly made a left turn onto Lehigh Street and then immediately made a right turn into the parking lot of 214-216 Essex Street.  I followed the vehicle and activated my emergency lights as the vehicle was pulling into a parking spot.  I notified headquarters that I had the vehicle stopped. I exited the vehicle and approached the vehicle from the driver's side, identified myself, and ordered all occupants to stay inside the vehicle while I waited for assisting officers to arrive.     Sgt. Klosk S.P.O. Colombini, P.O. Gretkowski, and P.O. O'Neill arrived on scene shortly thereafter, and assisted me with removing the arrestees from the vehicle.  Sgt. Klosk and I removed arrestee 1,  the driver of the vehicle and placed him in handcuffs behind his back.  He stated that he was 15 years old and is now referred to as "C.L."   C.L. stated that his uncle allowed him to use the vehicle when he was ordered to exit the vehicle.  I asked who his uncle was and he stated it was "Carlos".    P.O. O'Neill removed arrestee 2 from the front passenger seat of the vehicle and placed her in handcuffs behind her back.   Arrestee 2 stated that she is 16 years old and is now referred to as "A.A".  P.O. Gretkowski and P.O. Colombini removed arrestee 3 from the rear driver's side passenger seat and placed him in handcuffs behind his back.  He stated he was 14, and is now referred to as "J.L."  They also removed arrestee 4 from the passenger side rear seat and placed him in handcuffs behind his back.  He stated that he is 15 and is now referred to as "A.AL".  I searched the vehicle for any contraband or weapons with negative results.  Multiple tools and other personal items were strewn throughout the vehicle.  All arrestees were searched on scene.  See property reports for more information.   Det. Lt. Weber responded to the scene and notified the owner of the vehicle that his vehicle was recovered.  The vehicle was locked and left in the parking lot for the owner to retrieve later today when he is back in the area.  Det. Lt. Weber took photographs of the interior and exterior of the vehicle.   The arrestees were transported to Headquarters and escorted into the Juvenile Bureau.  They were searched again and turned over to Sgt. Dominguez. Sgt. Dominguez contacted the parent/ guardians of all arrestees.  See his supplement report and JSTC reports for more information.    In Headquarters,  it was determined that C.L. had active warrant #020020290 issued by Judge Francois Magali on 1/18/22. Sgt. Dominguez contacted the Bergen County Sheriffs Office who confirmed the warrant, and will take custody of him.  He contacted A.P. Gwynn of the incident who recommended formally charging all arrestees.   All arrestees were charged with Receiving stolen property / 2C:20-7A ( A third degree crime). Additionally, C.L. was issued summons H-957801 for driving while unlicensed / 39-3-10a. **It should be noted that my BWC fell off my clothing when I changed direction in order to follow    the vehicle.  Once back up Officers arrived on scene I responded back to my vehicle, retrieved the BWC, and activated it**
column14: the vehicle.  Once back up Officers arrived on scene I responded back to my vehicle, retrieved the BWC, and activated it**

column13: On Thursday, February 17, 2022, Officer Butler and I were dispatched to Van Wettering Place and Hudson Street to assist South Hackensack PD on a report of a stolen vehicle. Upon arrival, these officers were met with Captain Kelly #49 of the South Hackensack PD. He stated that as he was driving on Hudson Street his Automated License Plate Reader detected a stolen vehicle parked on the corner of Hudson Street and Van Wettering Place.  The vehicle was a grey 2015 Toyota Camry NJ Registration Z49PMH. We advised headquarters of the plate and VIN and the vehicle was confirmed stolen. Both license plates were on the vehicle. There was no visible forced entry nor any major damage to the car. There was no key in the ignition. Brookside Towing responded and towed the vehicle, see tow report.

column2: Shoplifting  2C:20-11Recovered Stolen VehicleSearch Warrant Execution
column13: Suspect 1: White and/or Hispanic male wearing a black jacket, black shirt, gray pants black sneaker, glasses with a white face mask.Suspect 2: White and/or Hispanic male wearing a black hooded Champion sweater, black pants, burgundy hat and a green shoulder bag.Suspect 3: White and/or Hispanic male wearing glasses, gray adidas hat, black jacket, gray pants and a black face mask.Suspect 4: White and/or Hispanic male wearing a black jacket, black shirt, black pants and a black face mask.Suspect 5: Hispanic Female wearing a black hooded sweater, gray pants, white sneakers, black face mask and was identified as Valentina Valenzuela MolinaOn 3/8/22, I was notified by Patrol, specifically Lieutenant Benny Marino, on a reported shoplifting incident that occurred at Bloomingdales. Bloomingdales is located at 400 Hackensack Avenue, the Shops at Riverside.  Detective John Mora and I then responded to 400 Hackensack Avenue. Upon arrival we met with the Shops at Riverside Mall Security, Bloomingdales Lost Prevention Detectives and Hackensack Police Department Patrol Officers in the north west side parking lot. Upon speaking with Bloomingdales Lost Prevention Detectives Dawn Manna and Henry Aguilar, I was advised the suspect(s) were observed entering and exiting a Black Cadillac Escalade, bearing New York Registration JPZ3190. It was further reported the suspects possibly secured stolen Bloomindale merchandise inside the listed vehicle. One suspect, identified as Valentina Valenzuela Molina, was detained and placed under arrest prior to my arrival. Upon speaking with P.O. Bobby Rivera, he reported the arrestee was not the owner of the vehicle.The listed vehicle was observed parked unattended on the north west side of the mall. Upon inspecting the vehicle, I could see multiple shopping bags located in the back seat and the trunk area. Located inside the shopping bags I observed multiple shoes and clothing that had unknown store tags secured to them. Due to the vehicle possibly having stolen merchandise located inside a tow was requested and Lin-Z Towing responded. The vehicle was secured and transported from 400 Hackensack Avenue to the Hackensack Police Department rear parking lot. The vehicle was parked in the Parking for Prisoner Transport Only parking space. During transport Detective John Mora followed and maintained chain of custody. The area the vehicle was secured was under video surveillance.I later responded to Bloomingdales with Bloomingdales Lost Prevention to view the video surveillance. Upon observing the video surveillance, I observed all five (5) suspects exit the mall and respond to the suspect vehicle. All five (5) suspect then respond back towards the mall. While responding back toward the mall suspect 5 was holding a large dark colored shopping bag. Also suspect 3 was holding a large Nike paper shopping bag. Suspect 2 was also wearing an additional black drawstring backpack. All suspects were then seen entering the mall.Bloomingdale's interior video surveillance captured suspect 1 taking multiple items and walking out of camera view. Additional video showed suspect 1 folded a Burberry hat and place it in his left side jacket pocket. He was later approached by Bloomingdales Lost Prevention Detective Henry Aguilar. Upon Henry Aguilar approaching suspect 1 he recovered the Burberry hat the suspect previously place in his jacket pocket.Bloomingdale's exterior video surveillance captured suspect 5 exiting the mall with a dark shopping bag in hand. Suspect 5 then abandoned the bag and canceled it underneath an unknown vehicle, located in the parking lot. All suspects then fled the area walking on foot. Suspect 5 was then detained in the parking lot by mall security and Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention. Still photographs provided by Bloomingdale's showed the incident occurred on 3/8/22 between 14:07 hours and 14:30 hours. The video surveillance capturing the incident was requested, provided and secured as evidence. Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention later recovered the shopping bag suspect 5 abandoned. The shopping bag was described as a gray and black asphalt medium sized plastic bag. Inside the bag was foil wrapping that was tapped with black and gray tape. Foil wrapping is commonly used to defeat security detectors from activating and detecting anti-theft sensors. An additional black drawstring backpack was recovered, which was also lined with foil wrapping that was tapped with black and gray tape.Located within the recovered bags were the following items:1 Burberry hat, valued at $390.00.1 black and white silk Givenchy scarf, valued at $450.00.1 black Jimmy Choo sunglasses, valued at $330.00.1 black and gold Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.1 black and gold Versace sunglasses, valued at $259.00.1 black and gold Jimmy Choo sunglasses, valued at $ 355.00.1 pink Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.1 black Burberry sunglasses, valued at $241.00.2 black and gold Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.1 green Versace sunglasses, valued at $295.00.1 white Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.The total value of recovered stolen merchandise was $3,955.00. At this time the total value of stolen items was unknown, but the value is reported to be approximately $4,000.00. Forty-four (44) photographs of the recovered items, suspect vehicle and the bags were taken with my police issued cellphone.  All recovered merchandise were released to Bloomingdales. The two bags containing the foil liners were secured as evidence. Bloomingdales Lost Prevention Detective Henry Aguilar responded to headquarters to provide a statement.  See video statement for further. Patrol signed complaints, complaint number S 2022 000144 0223, against Valentina Valenzuela Molina for shoplifting 2C:20-11 and burglary tools 2C:5-5. At headquarters Valentina Valenzuela Molina was escorted to the Detective Division Interview Room to be interviewed. Prior to the interview she was advised of her charges. Valentina Valenzuela Molina was read her Miranda Rights, which she initialed and signed. Valentina Valenzuela Molina waived her rights to have counsel present and agreed to speak with me in regards to the incident. During the interview Detective Mora was present and assisted with translation. Upon speaking with Valentina Valenzuela Molina, she reported responding to the Shops at Riverside for food. She further reported responding with her boyfriend of a year and a half, George Steven Mellado, and his three friends. Valentina Valenzuela Molina was unable to provide any identifying information regarding her boyfriends friends. Valentina Valenzuela Molina described her boyfriend as a tall White male with green eyes. She further reported he was wearing a black jacket, gray pants with Nike sneakers. Valentina Valenzuela Molina reported George Steven Mellado resided in Valley Stream Long Island New York and his date of birth was 9/27/1997. No additional identifying information was provided. See video statement for further.A commercial computerized database search of George Steven Mellado was conducted, which provided the following additional identifying information:Possible SSN: 116-86-4738Possible Address: 379 N Central Avenue, Valley Stream, New York 11580A New York State Intelligence Center Request for Information Form and a New York State Intelligence Center Request for New York State Department of Motor Vehicle Image Form was completed requesting the New York State Intelligence Center provide additional information regarding George Steven Mellado. Both forms were later sent to the New York State Intelligence Center.A TRAK message was generated and sent to multiple agencies in an attempt to identify the unidentified suspects. A search warrant application and order were generated and sent to Bergen County Prosecutors Office Assistant Prosecutor Craig A. Becker for approval. A commercial computerized database search of the register owner, L Hernandez provided a possible telephone number that was associated to him. Upon Detective Koenig contacting the telephone number he spoke with Mr. Hernandez and advised him of the incident. Mr. Hernandez reported his vehicle was stolen, but he didnt report the incident to police. Detective Koenig advised Mr. Hernandez to report the incident to his local police agency. Mr. Hernandez and his wife, Moira Riveros, later contacted me back and reported the vehicle was stolen from 204 Euclid Street, Valley Stream, NY 11580. Both further reported the vehicle was parked on the street, which was a work location. It was reported the incident occurred on 3/7/22 possibly between 19:00 to 20:00 hours. Mr. Hernandez and Ms. Riveros reported they responded to the Nassau County Police Department, Precinct 5, and reported the incident to P.O. Gurrasto. See the Nassau County Police report number 2022CR321120 for further. Mr. Hernandez reported at this time he did not want his vehicle processed for fingerprints.On 3/9/22 the search warrant (warrant number KB-BER-1484-SW-22) was approved by the Honorable Keith Bachman, a Superior Court Judge of Bergen County. The New York State Intelligence Center also provided additional information regarding George Steven Mellado. It was reported Mellado was recently associated with the address 204 E Euclid Street, Valley Stream, New York. An image of Mellado was also provided. The Nassau County Police Department 5th Precinct was contacted prior to executing the search of the vehicle. I spoke with Detective Speichler who was advised of the incident. Detective Speichler reported no conflicts regarding the search of the vehicle.The Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention Manager, Frank Fuentes, was contacted and requested to respond to headquarters. Upon Mr. Fuentes responding to headquarters he turned over a large Nike paper shopping bag, which he reported was recovered after the incident. The bag appeared similar to the one suspect 3 was holding. Inside the bag was foil wrapping that was tapped with gray tape. The bag was secured as evidence.Due to the vehicle being locked and not having the key P.O. Dogali responded to assist with making entry. Entry was made into the vehicle at 17:12 hours. Detective Koenig and Detective Sergeant Tripodi assisted.  During the search Mr. Fuentes from Bloomingdale's was present. Upon searching the vehicle Detective Koenig located the following items:- Republic of Chile Passport number P11697539 belonging to Cristian Daniel Jesus Herrera Jara.- New York State Lynbrook Police Department Uniform Traffic Ticket number Z572C7JMCX issued to Cristian D Herrera.The Chile Passport was located in the center console and the summons was located in the rear driver seat storage pocket. Upon searching the vehicle I located multiple items with anti theft sensors still attached. Some of the items had Nordstrom tags attached and loose Marshalls price tags were also located. Upon searching the third row passenger side area I observed a Burberry Hat, similar to the one Suspect 1 concealed during the incident. Upon showing the Burberry hat to Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention Manager Frank Fuentes he confirmed that item belonged to Bloomingdale's. The Burberry Hat had an anti theft sensor attached and no receipt was located showing proof of purchase. The Burberry hat was then secured. During the search 84 photographs of the vehicle were taken with the Detective Division camera. Mr. Fuentes was unable to confirm any other merchandise located within the vehicle to belong to Bloomingdale's.Concluding the search a copy of the search warrant order and a receipt of what was seized was left on the front passenger seat. A tow was requested, Lin-Z Towing responded and removed the vehicle. See the notes on the tow report.A Hackensack Police Department Property Sheet was completed, which Mr. Fuentes signed. The Burberry hat was then turned over to Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention Manager  Mr. Fuentes.Concluding the search Detective Speichler was advised of my findings. Detective Speichler also provided the Nassau County Police report number 2022CR321120, which documented no further police action was required.I also contacted the registered owner, Leonel Hernandez, who was advised of my findings. Mr. Hernandez reported Cristian Daniel Jesus Herrera Jara was a friend of his and had a spare key to his vehicle. Mr. Hernandez also reported Cristian Daniel Jesus Herrera Jara was allowed access to his vehicle. Mr. Hernandez was explained how to recover his vehicle. The image of Mellado and the passport image of Cristian Daniel Jesus Herrera Jara was compared to the suspects. Due to some suspects wearing masks I was unable to confirm Mellado and Cristian Daniel Jesus Herrera Jara were involved in the incident. The three bags with the foil wrapping were placed into evidence locker 6. See Evidence report for further information.An additional TRAK message was generated and sent to surrounding agencies regarding the multiple items with anti theft sensors observed in the vehicle.At this time the male suspects were unable to be identified. This case will remain administratively closed pending further development.
column14: Henry Aguilar. Upon Henry Aguilar approaching suspect 1 he recovered the Burberry hat the suspect previously place in his jacket pocket.Bloomingdale's exterior video surveillance captured suspect 5 exiting the mall with a dark shopping bag in hand. Suspect 5 then abandoned the bag and canceled it underneath an unknown vehicle, located in the parking lot. All suspects then fled the area walking on foot. Suspect 5 was then detained in the parking lot by mall security and Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention. Still photographs provided by Bloomingdale's showed the incident occurred on 3/8/22 between 14:07 hours and 14:30 hours. The video surveillance capturing the incident was requested, provided and secured as evidence. Bloomingdale's Lost Prevention later recovered the shopping bag suspect 5 abandoned. The shopping bag was described as a gray and black asphalt medium sized plastic bag. Inside the bag was foil wrapping that was tapped with black and gray tape. Foil wrapping is commonly used to defeat security detectors from activating and detecting anti-theft sensors. An additional black drawstring backpack was recovered, which was also lined with foil wrapping that was tapped with black and gray tape.Located within the recovered bags were the following items:1 Burberry hat, valued at $390.00.1 black and white silk Givenchy scarf, valued at $450.00.1 black Jimmy Choo sunglasses, valued at $330.00.1 black and gold Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.1 black and gold Versace sunglasses, valued at $259.00.1 black and gold Jimmy Choo sunglasses, valued at $ 355.00.1 pink Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.1 black Burberry sunglasses, valued at $241.00.2 black and gold Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.1 green Versace sunglasses, valued at $295.00.1 white Versace sunglasses, valued at $327.00.The total value of recovered stolen merchandise was $3,955.00. At this time the total value of stolen items was unknown, but the value is reported to be approximately $4,000.00. Forty-four (44) photographs of the recovered items, suspect vehicle and the bags were taken with my police issued cellphone.  All recovered merchandise were released to Bloomingdales. The two bags containing the foil liners were secured as evidence. Bloomingdales Lost Prevention Detective Henry Aguilar responded to headquarters to provide a statement.  See video statement for further.

column13: On March  18, 2022 at approximately 17030 hrs, I responded to the listed location to investigate a recovered stolen automobile for Clifton PD.  Upon arrival, I made contact with the complainant who was identified as the manager.  The complainant, stated in effect, vehicle #1 was located on this date at 435 Lexington Ave Clifton and was brought back to their shop.  I verified the VIN number affixed to vehicle #1 and confirmed it to be the vehicle in question.  A hit confirmation was sent to the Clifton Police Department regarding the recovery of the vehicle.

On March 31, 2022 while patrolling in the area near 123 Anderson Street, I was flagged down by the complainant Wilmer Loayzaleon. The complainant advised me that he purchased a vehicle off Facebook Marketplace today and checked the car fax and discovered that it was stolen.          While on scene, the complainant brought me to the vehicle while it was parked in the lot of 102 Anderson Street and I advised dispatch over the air of the description of the vehicle. They relayed to me that the vehicle had been stolen out of Bayonne NJ yesterday. While speaking to the complainant, he advised me that he met with the seller of the vehicle at a location and Secaucus and paid $12,000 dollars for the 2015 Honda CRV. The complainant showed me multiple recordings of when he was with the seller and he also had a photo of the sellers NY drivers license. The complainant stated the license along with the title he was given had the name Jones Boo Hassan. P.O. Vazquez and Sgt. Meneses responded to assist.       The complainant stated that when he originally found the car on Facebook Marketplace on 03/30/2022 there was no alert for the vehicle being stolen on the car fax until he checked tonight. Due to the transaction between the complainant and seller occurred in Secaucus NJ, he was advised to respond to their Police Department and report the incident with them. Brookside Towing was contacted and responded to the scene and removed the vehicle. See tow report for further.

On April 7, 2022 I responded to 436 W. Anderson Street on a report of a recovered stolen vehicle. Upon arrival, I spoke with the complainant Anthony Cabrera and MVC Investigator Roxanna Catterson who advised me that complainant purchased a stolen vehicle without realizing it. Sgt. Ziegelhofer responded shortly after. Ms. Catterson advised me that the NJ Motor Vehicle Commission became aware of the incident when Mr. Cabrera went to the DMV on 04/04/2022 to register the vehicle. An employee observed the title of the 2020 Honda CRV and realized it was tampered with. Mr. Cabrera stated that he purchased the vehicle from a man named "Angel" and met him at the Chase Bank located at 300 Main Street in Orange to complete the transaction. They performed a bank transfer of $21,500 on 04/01/2022.          Ms. Catterson stated that she arrived at Mr. Cabrera's home today and discovered that the vin number had been altered throughout the vehicle. She advised me that they were able to discover the original vin number of the vehicle from serial numbers on the engine block. I advised Headquarters and they relayed that the vehicle was stolen out of NY on 03/07/2022. I advised the complainant that because the transaction was completed in the city of Orange, he needed to file the theft report in their jurisdiction. All Points Towing was notified and removed the vehicle shortly after.

On this date I was dispatched to Courthouse Towing, 129 John Street, on a report of a recovered stolen automobile.    Upon arrival I was able to speak to the complaint, Josh Sheffler of Courthouse Towing. He informed me that a vehicle on their Lee Place lot was discovered to be stolen. The vehicle, listed, was towed from 316 Park Street, Hackensack on March 10, 2022 for a violation of parking on private property. The vehicle's registration card shows that the vehicle should have license plate NJ F79MEU. The vehicle did not have that license plate but had NJ DLU-74 (series 9) (a used car dealer plate) affixed to the rear bumper. Police Headquarters contacted Paramus Police who had reported the vehicle stolen, they advised that they did not wish to have the vehicle processed. The fraudulent license plate  was removed and placed in the Traffic Division box at headquarters,  That plate returned as "Not on file."  Headquarters removed the vehicle from NCIC.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: On Monday April 25th, 2022, I was assigned unmarked radio car 132. While driving north on Moore Street, I observed the listed vehicle ( Delaware registration 512613). The listed vehicle was parked on Moore Street facing north on the east side of the street. I further observed the rear license plate of that vehicle barley attached to the rear bumper. A computer check was conducted of the listed vehicle with headquarters. The listed vehicle was reported and confirmed stolen from the state of Delaware, NCIC Warrant number V833861494. Det/Sgt. Dalton, Det/Sgt. Swettis Det. Marza, Det. Ranali P.O. Dominguez responded to assist. At approximately 21:00 hours stationary surveillance was initiated due to the vehicle being parked. At approximately 21:25 Det/Sgt. Dalton observed a male party exit the front passenger seat of the listed vehicle.    The male party was described as a black male, wearing a brown vest, with black hair. The listed party crossed the street and walked into 210 Main Street.  At approximately 10:00 hours  Court House Tow was notified to respond to impound the vehicle.  While standing outside near the listed vehicle, Det/Sgt. Dalton and I observed two male parties exiting from 210 Main Street. One of the male parties matched the description of the party who was seen exiting the listed vehicle. Det/Sgt. Dalton confirmed it was him. Det/Sgt. Dalton unholstered his duty weapon and stated " Hackensack Police" "Stop", which both parties complied. Det/Sgt. Swettis, Det. Ranali, Det. Marza, and Det. Carrillo responded to assist. Both parties were placed in handcuffs and searched, with negative results on contraband.    I advised both parties they were being detained for a criminal investigation, and I advised both parties of their constitutional rights, which both parties stated they understood their rights. The   driver was identified as NO RECORD. I asked NO RECORD who's vehicle he was driving. NO RECORD stated he borrowed the vehicle today from his friend in New York and was going to drive back with it.    The passenger who was identified as Miko Douglas stated he drove to Hackensack with his friend Maleek Poole and was heading back to New York. Based on the following facts, both were placed under arrest and searched incident to arrest with negative results on contraband.  NO RECORD was transported to headquarters in the rear seat of radio car 116, which was checked prior to and after transport, with negative results on contraband. Douglas was placed into the rear seat of radio car 112, which was search prior to and after transport with negative results on contraband and was transported to headquarters.    A search of the vehicle was conducted, which was negative on contraband. Polifly Tow responded and removed the vehicle.    A secondary search of Poole was conducted at headquarters, which revealed the following credit cards in his wallet.1. Chime Visa Credit Card4217 8330 7201 9305 Carmen Berganzo2. Venmo Debit Card5143 7723 2650 8950 Carmen Berganzo3. Wells Fargo Visa Debit Card4737 0280 5218 7989Calyn N Diaz       NO RECORD stated that the credit cards belonged to his freind's and had permission to have them in his possession. I advised him I would be taking the credit card's and debit card's for further investigation and they were placed in evidence. A secondary search of Douglas was conducted. I located a single key Honda key fob, which was secured in evidence pending Mr. Douglas providing proof that the fob belonged in his possession.    Both arrestee's were processed. I signed complainant number     2022 S 0000 against NO RECORD for 2C:20-7 and 2022 S 0000 against Douglas for 2C:20-7.
column14: NO RECORD stated that the credit cards belonged to his freind's and had permission to have them in his possession. I advised him I would be taking the credit card's and debit card's for further investigation and they were placed in evidence. A secondary search of Douglas was conducted. I located a single key Honda key fob, which was secured in evidence pending Mr. Douglas providing proof that the fob belonged in his possession.    Both arrestee's were processed. I signed complainant number     2022 S 0000 against NO RECORD for 2C:20-7 and 2022 S 0000 against Douglas for 2C:20-7.

column2: Assist Other AgencyRecovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: P.O. Farhi and I responded to the Congress Inn located at 370 Route 46 East in South Hackensack on a report of a recovered stolen vehicle out of the City of Hackensack, see report 22-031558.  Upon arrival, P.O. Gambutti advised that they located the stolen vehicle, and checked with hotel staff as to who was driving the vehicle.  After reviewing camera footage, SHPD confirmed the driver of the stolen vehicle had rented room 404.  South Hackensack PD made contact with the renter of room 404 and placed him under arrest for theft of a motor vehicle.  The arrestee was identified as Amro Said Hassan-Abraham, the suspect  believed to have stolen the motor vehicle.  Among the arrestee's property were the keys to the stolen motor vehicle and $2051 in US currency.  South Hackensack PD was aware the cash was possibly proceeds of a crime and will treat the currency as evidence.South Hackensack Polce Department released the keys and vehicle to the registered owner.  Reference motor vehicle theft report 22-031558.Reference theft report 22-031573.

I responded to the listed location to assist Mr. Jules in attempting to locate lost/stolen items that were supposed to be shipped via Inch Perfect Logistics LLC. There have been numerous issues where Inch Perfect Logistics LLC has taken items from victims with a contract to ship them to an agreed upon location without delivering the victim's items. In many cases the victim's items would be stored in storage facilities in either Clifton or 48 Orchard St, Hackensack where the business operated out of.      While going through the storage facilities with the building owner, Mr. Sabbagh and Mr. Jules, a white motorcycle was located. Mr. Sabbagh asked if I could obtain the motorcycles owner information so that the owner could be contacted for it to be removed. A computer check of the  vehicle resulted in it being reported stolen out of Pittsburgh, PA (case # 22-33924).     I reached out to Pittsburgh PD and spoke with Det. Michael Chlystek. Det. Chlystek informed me of the victim's information including phone number so I could contact the victim and inform him of the location of his property.      I then contacted to the victim and informed him that his motorcycle was recovered. The victim confirmed that the motorcycle along with other items were taken by Inch Perfect Logistics LLC to be moved from Pittsburgh to Iowa however, the items weren't delivered. I informed him that the motorcycle would be at Tumino's Towing as well as how to recover it. I also informed him of the procedure to go to 48 Orchard Street to attempt to locate the rest of his items. The motorcycle had one license plate on and appeared to not be damaged.     Tumino's Towing responded and removed the vehicle to their tow yard.      Det/Sgt. Tripodi was advised.      My body camera was not activated due to the battery dying.

While on Patrol in Radio Car #118 I received a LockJack hit "KR7NU" near the area of 515 Essex Street. As I pulled into the parking lot of 515 Essex Street the signal improved. Dispatch was notified and advised me the registration for the stolen vehicle  (NJ/D95CXZ). I located the vehicle parked in the parking lot of the listed location. P.O. Francavilla responded on scene. Lodi Police Department was notified and contacted the victim. The victim responded on scene and stated that he doesn't want the vehicle to be processed. There was no damage to the vehicle or and nothing missing. Vehicle was turned over to the victim.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleLo-Jack Hit - Tracking Signal
column13: While on patrol in Radio Car #118 I received a LoJack hit (TQF6W) in the area of Union Street and Atlantic Street. Dispatch was notified and responded with the description of the stolen vehicle as a white Maserati. I located that stolen vehicle (GA/S1160194) in front of 112 Atlantic Street. Dispatched confirmed the vehicle as Taken Without Owners Consent out of Belleville. See Belleville PD case #22-006092 for further. There appeared to be no damage to the exterior of the interior of the vehicle.Tumino's Towing responded and removed the vehicle to their Tow yard. See Tow report for further. My body worn camera battery died.

At approximately 07:45 hours, While assigned to the desk, under the command of Lt. Klosk, , I received a telephone call from Officer Blake Middendorf of the New Castle Sheriff's Department (State of Delaware).  Officer Middendorf reported that a 2021 Land Rover (SALGS2RU4MA446641)  that was reported stolen out of our jurisdiction (400 Hackensack Avenue) was located in Wilmington, DE, unoccupied.  Officer Middendorf further reported that both New Jersey license plates (H40-PPC) were not located on the vehicle. Located on the vehicle was a single South Carolina Registration (SUV-508) that was affixed to the rear.      This writer contacted the registered owner Ms. Dawn Willis. Ms. Willis reported that she wanted the vehicle to be processed.     Detective Division was notified.    Officer Middendorf was contacted by this writer and informed that the vehicle would be processed.  Per the detective division, I further informed Officer Middendorf that the case Detective (Det. DiMartino) would take possession of the vehicle on Monday, May 16, 2022.  Officer Middendorf reported that the vehicle would be towed from the scene to their Headquarters located at 3601 North Depont Highway, New Castle, Delaware 19720.

column2: Motor Vehicle TheftRecovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: While patrolling in marked radio car 116 in full uniform traveling northbound on Second Street near Carver Park, I observed a Black Land Rover, Range Rover SUV with New Jersey registration dealer plate DDP22 series 14.  I checked the registration, which revealed that it was expired.  The vehicle made a right-hand turn onto Stanley Place, and a motor vehicle stop was conducted near the intersection of First Street.  Sgt. Briggs arrived to assist.  I approached the driver's side as Sgt. Briggs approached the passenger side.  I identified myself as Hackensack Police and requested the driver's license, registration, and insurance card.  Once I had the documents I requested, I advised the driver, now identified as Jarrett Bruce, for the reason for the motor vehicle stop.    After I advised Bruce of the stop, he advised me that the vehicle was a company car that his boss gave him permission to drive.  I conducted a check of Bruce's driver's license, which yielded in his driver's license being suspended in New Jersey.  While further investigating the listed vehicle, the New Jersey registration appeared to be fictitious.  A check of the vehicle's Identification number was also conducted by using the public window number, which is provided on the window plate and driver's side federal VIN.  When a check on the VIN was conducted, it yielded that it was not on file.  Sgt. Briggs and I walked back over to the driver's side door jam and were able to peel the sticker off.  Due to the VIN not being on file and the door jam sticker also being fictitious, we conducted a probable cause search to locate another VIN under the hood of the vehicle on the inner passenger side shock tower.  I read off the VIN number to Sgt. Briggs, who conducted a check of the VIN, which revealed the vehicle was stolen.  We advised Bruce of our findings and placed him under arrest with his hands behind his back in handcuffs. He was searched and placed Bruce in the rear of radio car 116.  I requested a tow truck at this time, and Hackensack Court House Towing responded and towed the vehicle.  Bruce was transported to the rear of police headquarters as Sgt. Briggs followed in marked radio car 105.  The rear seat was checked prior to and after his occupancy with negative results for contraband.        At police headquarters, Bruce was escorted to report room 2 and searched again.  While searching Bruce, I located a South Carolina vehicle title in his right front pocket.   While in report room 2, Sgt. Briggs read Bruce his Miranda rights which he understood and initialed the Hackensack Police Department Miranda rights form.  Bruce spoke with Sgt. Briggs and advised him that he works for a car dealership in Bridgeton, New Jersey and that he asked his boss if he could borrow the vehicle for the weekend, which he allowed him to use.  He also advised Sgt. Briggs that he's been a transporter for the company for approximately eight (8) months now.  The interview was then ended after several more minutes.  The entire interview was captured on our body-worn cameras.     While taking inventory of Bruce's property, three (3) different credit cards were located and secured due to their different names.  The credit cards are listed below and secured. * Visa Reward debit card - Carol Giamietro card number 4343 4025 7862 5382* American Express Platinum- Floren Peremen - card number- 371571509429008* Visa Chase Freedom Unlimited - James FU- card number- 4266841716271896.  I signed complainant number W-0223-2022-000321 against Bruce for the following 2C:20-7A, 2C:17-6B, 2C:21-6C(1), and 2C:21-2.1D.  Bruce was also issued the following motor vehicle violations, E22-014812 39:3-4, E22-014813-39:3-33, E22-014814- 39:3-38 and E22-014815 - 39:3-40, The New Jersey dealership registration, Federal VIN sticker and South Carolina vehicle title were all secured in evidence locker 4.  Bruce was transported to the Bergen County Jail.

column2: Receiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Violation  Private Property
column13: On Tuesday, May 17, 2022 at approximately 0830 hours, I responded to 505 South River Street (WAWA) on a report of a private parking violation. Upon arrival, I met with WAWA manager Angela Winkens (complainant). The complainant stated she wished to sign a private parking summons for a U-Haul truck parked in the rear parking lot.         I responded to the rear parking lot where I observed the listed vehicle, a white GMC U-Haul truck bearing Arizona registration AL68036, parked facing west, along the fence line. I approached the driver's side and observed a male, later identified as Andrew Lugo (arrestee), asleep in the driver's seat. I advised the arrestee that WAWA did not want the vehicle parked on their property and requested his identification. The arrestee provided me a New York ID. I inquired as to how long the arrestee was parked for and if he had any paperwork for the vehicle. The arrestee reported he parked with his friend "Jeffery" and a female in the lot of the WAWA gas station on the previous night. The arrestee then reported they moved the vehicle to its current location at which time "Jeffery" and the female engaged in a dispute. "Jeffery" and the female then left to an unknown location with the key to the vehicle. The arrestee was unable to produce any rental agreement and was not in possession of the key.        A computer check of the registration revealed that the vehicle was reported stolen on 05/14/2022. Communications confirmed the vehicle's status as stolen. I  advised the arrestee to exit the vehicle and placed him in handcuffs with his hands behind his back. A search of the arrestee's person incident to arrest yielded negative results for contraband. P.O. Miller arrived to assist. The arrestee was seated in the rear of radio car #106.         P.O. Sroka and Sgt. Ziegelhofer responded. I opened the rear cargo compartment and observed a large quantity of property. As the search of the vehicle would be extensive, the vehicle was towed to police headquarters by Brookside Auto Body for further investigation. Refer to Detective Ghirardi's supplemental report for additional information.        I transported the arrestee to police headquarters and P.O. Miller followed. The rear passenger compartment of radio car #106 was checked both prior to and after the arrestee's occupancy with negative results for contraband. Once in headquarters, P.O. Miller conducted a secondary search of the arrestee which produced negative results. The arrestee was placed in cell #5.        I signed complaint #W2022000324 against the arrestee for the charge of 2C:20-7A (receiving stolen property).         Communications Officer Gervasi cleared the vehicle from NCIC as stolen. All alarms were canceled.          The investigation was turned over to the Detective Division.

On Wednesday 5/18/22 P.O. Donnerstag and I responded to 340 South River Street on a report of a stolen vehicle. The vehicle, a grey Volkswagen Jetta was stolen from Port Washington Village in New York and parked at the listed location. Carlos A. Cana-Luis purchased the vehicle on 5/11/22. Mr. Cana-Luis reported to Sgt. Rivas of Fairview Police that the purchased vehicle was flagged as stolen when trying to register the vehicle at the DMV. The case number out of Fairview is OCA 22-6591.   Upon arrival, to the listed location P.O. Donnerstag noticed a Volkswagen emblem on a parked vehicle covered in a tarp. Sgt. Knapp was then notified and responded to the location. Mr. Cana-Luis responded to police headquarters at 2216 hours and signed a consent to search form in order to remove the tarp from the vehicle and confirm it to be the stolen vehicle.    The vehicle had no registration on the front or rear bumper. The vin number of the vehicle was reported to headquarters who then confirmed the vehicle to be the reported stolen grey Volkswagen Jetta (Ref Port Washington Village PD Case #2022PW0001178). The recovered stolen vehicle was removed by Bergen Brookside Auto Towing to be held at their towing yard.  Dispatch removed the vehicle from NCIC.

P.O. Francavilla and I responded to the listed location in an attempt to located a stolen motor vehicle.  Upon arrival, we located the listed vehicle (NJ/Y48MTS) parked in space #93 in the rear parking lot of 197 South Main Street.  Dispatched advised Little Ferry Police Department that the vehicle was located. Little Ferry PD contacted the victim, who stated that he does not want the vehicle processed. The victim responded to the scene and the vehicle was turned over to him.

On the listed date at approximately 1620 hours I responded to the rear of 157 Clinton Pl for a parking complaint.  Upon arrival I spoke with the complainant, Clyde Foster who stated that a vehicle was parked in his parking spot numbered 1C.
