I approached the vehicle, a white Nissan Pathfinder and recognized the make and model of a vehicle that had been reported stolen at approximately 0900 hours.  A check of the license plate NJ C77MXJ confirmed that this was indeed the vehicle that had been reported stolen.  The owner of the vehicle previously stated that she wanted it to be processed if located.  I contacted the owner and advised her that her vehicle was located and she stated that she did not want it processed anymore and would like to have it turned back over to her.  The owner responded to the rear of 157 Clinton Pl and took possession of the vehicle.  She stated that she did not notice any new damage and nothing from inside was missing except for the key fob which had been reported earlier.  The vehicle was removed as stolen from NCIC.  This Officer did not notice any cameras in the area of where the vehicle was left.

column2: Recovered Stolen License PlateUnregistered Vehicle  39:3-4Motor Vehicle Impound
column13: While in the area of Marginal and Washington, I observed the listed vehicle to appear to have been sitting several days.  An NCIC check of the NJ Registration C44MZU revealed that both plates were reported stolen out of Elizabeth.  Police Headquarters was advised, contacted Elizabeth and they confirmed the plates to still be active stolen.  The VIN in the windshield was obstructed by a piece of paper but P.O. Marble was able to locate the VIN etched into the windows.  The VIN comes back to the same car as the registration but Elizabeth still has it as confirmed on their end so the plates were removed from the vehicle and secured in the Traffic Division.  The registered owner was issued Summons E22-015672 for 39:3-4.  All-Points Towing was notified, responded and removed the vehicle.  See Tow report for further.  The condition of the vehicle was recorded on my BWC.

Suspect: Black male approximately 6'2" 250lbs with a muscular build, bald head, no facial hair, mid 30s   On Friday 05/27/22 at approximately 10:52 AM, suspect Tony Paden dropped off a Jeep Wrangler at the listed location. While parked in this location, National Insurance Crime Bureau investigator Louis Stanicki noticed the vehicle had the vin removed from the vehicle's door panel. Upon further investigation, all of the vehicle vins were removed. A vin was found on the drivers seat and was entered into NCIC coming back to a salvaged white Jeep Wrangler. He then located on the door panel the final 8 digits of the vehicle's original vin on a sticker that was untouched. Using the 8 digits of the   vin, the vehicle came back to a stolen blue Jeep Wrangler out of Newark. The jeep had visible tracing of blue paint underneath the white paint and the entire bottom of the vehicle was blue.       The suspect had the vehicle towed to the listed location because the vehicle would not start. The suspect provided the complainant with three blank keys and one cut key, none of which worked to start the vehicle. He requested the complainant program the set of keys. He also stated he owned the vehicle. Sgt. Meneses was made aware of the situation on responded the location. Dispatched was contacted and confirmed that the vehicle was stolen out of Newark. Newark PD was advised and stated that Newark PD would respond at a later time.

On June 8, 2022 at approximately 12:02 AM, I was contacted by D/Lt. Smith. He advised me that the Detective Division had made an arrest of the suspect involved in the May 29th, 2022 shooting as well as the June 5th, 2022 robbery. The suspect was identified as J.V. , a 15 year old juvenile.       D/Lt. Smith advised me that the suspect was currently at the Prosecutor's Office. The suspect was transported from BCPO to the Hackensack Police Headquarters by the patrol division. Upon his arrival he was processed and eventually remanded to the Juvenile Detention Center in Teterboro.                   Under the direction of the Prosecutor's Office I signed complaint 0223 JC 2022 000021 and complaint 0223 JC 2022 000022. Due to NJ Courts malfunctions and a delay with the juvenile intake process J.V. was held in our custody past six hours. Assistant Prosecutor Kunz was made aware of this situation.     At 05:30, Det. Katsaroans and I transported J.V. to JDC in RC#125. He was handcuffed with hands to the front during the transport. The rear seat of the vehicle was checked prior to and after transport which was negative for contraband. Upon arrival custody was transferred to Officer Ortiz from the Detention Center.     A copy of the complaints were hand delivered to his guardian Maria Rosado at 161 Herman Street.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Complaint
column13: I responded to the listed location on a report of a motor vehicle complaint. On arrival I observed the listed vehicle (SC-9033LD) parked on Thompson Street near the intersection of Cambridge Terrace. A license plate inquiry was conducted and it revealed that the vehicle was reported stolen out of New York City on today's date. The NCIC hit was confirmed and NYPD did not want the vehicle to be processed. The vehicle was observed to have only one front headlight as the other three were removed. The vehicle's front seats and center console were also removed from the vehicle. The vehicle was removed by Lin-Z towing. See tow report.

column2: FraudCredit Cards: Unlawful Use  2C:21-6Recovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: Suspect 1: B/M, mid-face length dreadlocks, Red zip-up hoodie, Black under shirt, Gray sweatpants, Black sneakers.     Suspect 2: B/M, Black overhead hoodie, ski mask, black sweatpants, black sneakers.     Suspect 3: White/ Hispanic Female, Rectangular eye glasses, Black hoodie, black sweatpants, white and red sneakers.     P.O. Seretis and I responded to the listed location on a report of a possible fraud.  Upon arrival, we met with the complainant, Eric Ansah, who pointed out the suspects who were walking out of the store in the parking lot.  Upon approaching Suspect #1, P.O. Seretis ordered him to stop at which he did not comply. A foot pursuit was initiated.  The suspect fled Eastbound on Essex Street near the 7/11.  He then went into the construction lot on the corner of Newman Street and Essex, at which point we lost sight of him.       We then responded back to the Rite Aid where we met with the complainant.  The complainant reviewed the surveillance footage of the incident, which showed the three above described suspects making the transactions. The transactions were as follows:1.  Foot Locker Gift Card  ($250.00)2.  Nike Gift Card ($500.00)3.  Netspend ($200.00)4.  Visa Gift Card($200.00)5.  Nordstorm Gift Card ($500.00)6.  Visa Gift Card ($200.00)7.  Visa Gift Card ($200.00)8.  Visa Gift Card ($200.00)9.  Visa Gift Card ($200.00)The total of the transaction charges are $2,450.00     We spoke to the loss prevention associate, Mona Scipio, who stated that surveillance footage of the incident would be available at a later date, to be secured.  Upon reviewing surveillance footage on scene, Suspect #2 was observed crossing the street and getting struck by a car.  It should be noted that Suspect #2 was not being pursued during this incident neither prior to or after being struck by a vehicle.  See P.O. O'Neill's report (Case# 22-043506) for further information.       Upon exiting the Rite Aid, we observed the listed vehicle (NJ reg# C33FWZ) idling in the parking lot, with the door open and engine running.   The vehicle was possibly occupied by the suspects prior to our arrival.  The computer inquiry revealed that the vehicle was registered to Caitlyn Mulkeen.  Ramsey PD was contacted to speak to the registered owner of the vehicle to determine whether or not it was stolen.  She advised that the vehicle was being lent to her brother, Patrick Mulkeen, for a period of over a year.  Patrick Mulkeen was contacted who stated his vehicle was in fact stolen and immediately reported it to Hawthorne PD.  The vehicle was impounded by Lin-Z towing (see tow report).         A passerby stated that he saw Suspect # 2 discard the credit cards as we arrived.  The credit cards that were recovered were as follows:Victim # 1 (Patrick N. Mulkeen)1.  Chase Visa Sapphire (#4147 2024 7964 0771) exp: 3/26, S.C. #2752.  Chase Visa Freedom (# 4266 8417 0363 4285) exp: 1/27, S.C. #947Victim # 2 (Tyson Redmond)3.  Chase Visa Southwest (#4266 8416 7820 1565) exp: 5/26, S.C. #9174.  Sacramento Credit Union Visa (#4788 1400 0396 5773) exp: 4/26, S.C. #483Victim # 3 (Marlene Brown)5.  Aspire Mastercard (#5501 1400 0234 3330) exp: 4/23, S.C. # 947Victim # 4 (Marlene Barr)6.  TD Bank Visa (#4482 3300 2074 7440) exp: 7/22, S.C. # 2067.  Care Credit (# 6019 1836 5642 6673) exp: 1/27, S.C. # 4498.  Capital One Mastercard (#5178 0593 5056 6304) exp: 10/24, S.C. # 1039.  TD Bank Visa (#4482 3300 8057 2738) exp. 9/24, S.C. # 21710.  NJ EPPI Card Mastercard (#5154 7711 2902 3817) exp: 9/22, S.C. # 232Victim # 5 (Jose Barrientos)11. Wells Fargo Visa (# 4737 0240 3448 6201) exp. 9/22, S.C. # 79012.  Capital One Platinum (# 5178 0591 8432 1843) exp: 4/26, S.C. # 09313.  Wells Fargo Visa (#4465 4203 6200 0531) exp: 6/23, S.C. # 30814.  Delta Sky Miles Amex (#3792 790449 01000) exp: 8/24 S.C. # 32115.  Care Credit (# 6019 1838 3139 0414) exp: 3/26, S.C. # 68116. Bank of America Visa (# 4427 4372 8833 9147) exp: 9/25, S.C. # 067       The credit cards were logged into evidence.  See evidence report.       Detective Division was notified.

column13: While patrolling in R/C138, in full uniform in the area of 95 Anderson, the ALPR (Automatic License Plate Reader) altered me on a stolen vehicle bearing New York registration T775637C on a black Honda Accord.  The vehicle was located parked and unoccupied.  While waiting for Headquarters to confirm the vehicle was stolen out of New York the owner (arrestee) exited a store and approached me.  At this time Sgt. Bay and P.O. Williams arrived to assist.  I explained to the arrestee for the reason why I was at her vehicle.  She reported to me that she made a stolen vehicle report in Brooklyn, NY approximately two or three days ago.  While further speaking with her she stated she located the vehicle on 06/29/2022 which was towed from construction site and never notified the New York Police Department she located the vehicle.  I asked the arrestee for driver's license, registration and insurance card to confirm she was the owner of the vehicle.  A check for warrants was conducted and headquarters advised me the arrestee had an outstanding warrant from our jurisdiction.  I advised the arrestee of the active warrant and placed her hands behind her back in handcuffs.  The arrestee was escorted to the rear of R/C 138 and transported the police headquarters.  The rear seat of R/C 138 was check prior to and after the arrestee occupancy which yielded in negative results for contraband.     At police headquarters the arrestee was photographed and posted bail and released with a new court date of 07/14/2022.  The vehicle was removed from N.C.I.C. as stolen.      Outstanding warrant0223-W2012-000386 for the original charge of 2C:20-11B(2) issued by Judge Louis J. Dinice on 09/10/2012 for the amount of $1,500.00 in full amount.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7Motor Vehicle Stop
column13: On 7/1/2022, I was assigned Pedestrian Safety in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 150.  I observed a blue Land Rover Range Rover SVR bearing Florida dealer plate PF839B parked unoccupied in front of 262 Main Street.  The vehicle had front tinted windows and and dealer plate had a license plate frame obstructing the word "Dealer. "  I observed the suspect exit a business and enter the vehicle.  I activated my emergency lights and conducted a motor vehicle stop.  Both my body worn camera and mobile video recorder in Radio Car 150 activated.  P.O. Bonsu and Sgt. Peralta responded to assist.  During my conversation with the suspect, he stated that he works for the dealership in Florida and that he is selling the vehicle for them.  I conducted a commercial databasecomputer check of the public VIN, SALWZ2SE7KA8933441, which yielded that the VIN had an unusual history.  I asked the suspect if he had the title, which he stated that it was at his home.  I asked the suspect to open the door which he voluntarily complied.  I observed the federal door VIN sticker appeared to be fictitious.  The suspect was removed from the vehicle and brought to the rear of the vehicle.           Based on the public window VIN having an unusual VIN history, the federal door VIN sticker to be fictitious, as well as my training and experience, I intended to conduct a consent search of the vehicle to obtain the real VIN.  I retrieved a Hackensack Police Department Consent to Search form and completed it.  I explained to the suspect that he both had the rights to refuse a search as well as to terminate a search at any time.  The suspect consented to a search of the vehicle.  I went to the secret VIN location which I observed to be modified and fictitious.             Due to me being unable to obtain the real VIN for the vehicle, the suspect was issued summons #E22-19933 for a violation of 39:3-4.  The suspect was released from the stop.          Court House Towing responded to impound the vehicle.          Due to the secret VIN location being modified, I removed the fictitious federal door VIN sticker which I observed to be a printed sticker glued into place in the door jam.  Based on the confirmation that the federal door VIN sticker was fictitious, the secret VIN being modified, as well as all aforementioned factors which led to the consent search, I had probable cause to conduct a check of the VIN through the OBD2 port.  I then followed the vehicle to the impound yard to conduct the OBD2 check.  Court House Towing personnel plugged into the OBD2 port and retrieved the real VIN (SALWZ2SEXKA860045).  I confirmed that the real VIN was reported stolen out of Colts Neck Police Department.             I then responded to Headquarters to prepare complaints against the suspect.  I signed complaint #W2022-000428-0223 against the suspect for violations of 2C:20-7a and 2C:17-6b.  I mailed a copy of the warrant to his registered address.

I responded to the listed location on a vehicle that has been parked for several days.  An NCIC check of the Arizona registration, AL09477, revealed the vehicle to be stolen out of Saddle Brook from 7/5/2022.  Police Headquarters was advised and sent a hit confirmation which Saddle Brook responded and confirmed.  There was no major damage to the vehicle, 1 license plate (on the rear), no keys and doors were left unlocked.  Bergen Brookside was notified, responded and removed the vehicle.  The vehicles condition was captured on my BWC prior to being towed.  See Tow Report for further.

The owner of the vehicle was confirmed to be Guaranteed Services LLC.  I spoke with their office manager who advised that the vehicle is insured by Preferred Mutual Insurance.  They were advised to contact their insurance to retrieve the car to have the VINs reconstructed.

I responded to 200 Lee Place and met with "Lou" from the National Insurance Crime Bureau.  Lou removed the fraudulent window VIN sticker which was covering the real VIN.  Because the fraudulent sticker was glued down, it was destroyed as it was removed.  I secured this fraudulent VIN sticker in evidence.  Lou also removed the fictitious secondary VIN from its location.  By removing the VIN, the real secondary VIN was visible again.

I responded to 83 Zabriskie Street and met with "Lou" from the National Insurance Crime Bureau.  Lou removed the fraudulent window VIN sticker which was covering the real VIN.  The fictitious window VIN sticker came out in one piece.  The visible fraudulent window VIN sticker was on top of a second fraudulent window VIN sticker (SALWR2RV0JA451878).  Both stickers were secured in evidence.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: On Tuesday, 07/12/2022, Sgt. Briggs and I were assigned Traffic Enforcement in marked radio car #148. While patrolling the parking lot of 405 Route 17 South, we observed vehicle 1 bearing a Florida Dealership registration PK733B, parked idling, in violation 39:3-70.2, in the parking lot in front of Metro PCS. A Police database search of the public VIN (5UXCY8C04M9J02739) returned that the VIN was not a valid VIN. Thereafter, marked radio car #148 was repositioned to block in vehicle 1 from leaving the scene. Our body worn cameras were activated. While attempting to locate the real VIN on vehicle 1, a party later identified as Mr. Raymier Mondesir, approached us and stated vehicle 1 belonged to him. After explaining to Mr. Mondesir that vehicle 1 was possibly stolen, he changed his statement and stated that the vehicle belongs to a client. Mr. Mondesir was detained. A computer search for any outstanding warrants yielded negative. The driver's side door was opened. We observed that the federal VIN sticker was fraudulent. The federal VIN sticker, which beared 5UXCY8C04M9J02739, was removed. Based on the public VIN showing it is not a valid VIN the federal VIN sticker being fraudulent as well as our training and experience, we have probable cause to believe the vehicle was stolen and the original VIN was altered. A probable cause search was conducted to locate the real VIN. The Florida dealership registration was removed from the rear of vehicle 1 and secured in radio car #148. From our training and experience, the vehicle's VIN can also be accessed from the rear of BMWs. The original VIN sticker was tampered, removed and replaced with a different peeling sticker VIN 5UXCY8C04M9J02739, which matched the public VIN.  It should be noted that above this sticker was remnants of the glue from the original VIN sticker.     Mr. Mondesir was asked on how did he start the vehicle. He reported through an application on his phone. Mr. Mondesir refused to demonstrate on how to start the vehicle. Mr. Mondesir was explained that the vehicle is being impounded due to our reasonable suspicion that the vehicle is possibly stolen. Mr. Mondesir was dispersed from the scene. While attempting to start the vehicle, we were able to access the vehicle's real VIN "5UXCY8C08N9J45952" from the vehicle's heads up display/center console screen. A computer search on that VIN indicated that vehicle 1 was stolen out of Lantana, Florida. A probable cause search of the stolen vehicle yielded four (4) cell phones, a bag and a document from Florida in reference to a doctor referral. Within in the bag, two (2) credit cards in various names were located and turned over to Det. Mora.          We attempted to locate Mr. Mondesir with negative results.The stolen vehicle was impounded by All Points Towing.See TOW, evidence and property report.          The stolen vehicle is valued at $93,360.00. The original owner of the vehicle was paid out by Progressive Insurance. Sgt. Briggs will be attempting to notify Progressive.     I signed complaint #W-2022-0223-000448 for violations of 2C:20-7A and 2C:17-6B against Mr. Mondesir.

I contacted Progressive Insurance and notified them that the vehicle was recovered.  Progressive Insurance was advised how to retrieve the vehicle once the fictitious public VIN is removed from the window.

Also located in the recovered stolen vehicle were the following items which were secured as evidence:one United State Postal Service key (serial #99/30650)one ez-pass (#G4*02213220045*)various pieces of mail addressed to 370 West Pleasantview #194, Hackensack, NJ 07601All above mentioned items were secured as evidence.

This writer received a hit confirmation from the Passaic county Sheriff's Department. It stated that they recovered this vehicle that was reported stolen to the Hackensack Police Department on June 16, 2022. The vehicle was cleared from NCIC and all alarms were canceled. The vehicle was missing one license plate and that was re-entered into NCIC, NIC # P057936669. The owner was notified of the recovery at 13:45 hours on this date.

I responded to All Points Towing to remove the fraudulent public VIN sticker from the recovered stolen auto.  I was able to remove the window sticker (it should be noted that the last few characters on the fraudulent sticker were destroyed during the removal process).  The remainder of the sticker was secured as evidence.  Progressive Insurance was notified that the vehicle can now be released to them.
Generated in error

column2: Assist Other AgencyRecovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: I was dispatched on a stolen auto recovery.  The vehicle was located at 430 Jeliff Ave, Newark NJ.  This writer and Lin-Z Towing Services responded to the mentioned location for the vehicle recovery.  Upon arrival,  I met with Newark Police Sergeant Cuncellatia #7151 who pointed out the location of the vehicle and provided a Newark Police Tow sheet with a CC-22-33622.The vehicle was transported to the Bergen County Sheriff B.C.I unit for finger printing.  S.O Delorenzo #1708 Received the vehicle at the BCI rear building.

On 8/2/2022 at approximately 1400 hours, I was on patrol in Police uniform in marked Radio Car 105.  On the first level of the parking deck of 400 Hackensack Avenue (a quasi-public parking garage open to any patron of the mall and regularly patrolled by members of the Hackensack Police Department), I located a black Land Rover Range Rover bearing New Jersey used car dealer plate DQL68.  A public records check of that business (Atlantic Auto Group LLC) showed that the business is permanently closed.  I walked to the front of the vehicle to observed the Public VIN (salgs5se7ma451417) which I immediately recognized as fraudulent.  The Public VIN shows that the vehicle is a 2021 Land Rover Range Rover.  A Police records database check yielded that the VIN is in fact fraudulent.  Based on the window etching on the windows, I believed the vehicle to be either a 2019 or 2020 and not a 2021.             Lt. Weber responded to assist.  I attempted to locate a driver for the unoccupied vehicle, with negative results.              Based on the public VIN being fraudulent, the used car dealer license plate showing that the business is permanently closed, as well as my training and experience, I had probable cause to believe that the vehicle is stolen and the VINs were altered.  I contacted Court House Towing to respond to assist me in gaining entry.  Court House Towing responded and was able to unlock the driver's side door.  I observed the federal VIN sticker in the door jam to be fraudulent.  As I attempting to locate the real VIN, Zhang walked up to the vehicle and unlocked the vehicle with a key fob.  Zhang was asked if he was the owner, which he stated that he bought the vehicle for approximately $40000.00.  I opened the engine hood and observed the secondary VIN to be also altered.  Using the key fob, I started the vehicle.  I located the real VIN (salgs5se3la579409) which was confirmed to be stolen on 4/13/2022 by the New York City Police Department (NIC #V553876607).   A probable cause search of the vehicle yielded no further items of evidentiary value.               I placed Zhang under arrest for possession of a stolen motor vehicle (valued at approximately $90000.00) as well as possession of a motor vehicle with an altered VIN.  Zhang was placed in handcuffs behind his back and searched with negative results for contraband.                Court House Towing impounded the vehicle.             Zhang was transported to Headquarters in the rear seat of Radio Car 105.  The rear seat was checked prior to and after Zhang's occupancy with negative results for contraband.  Zhang was searched again and then processed.  I signed complaint #0223S2022-490 against Zhang for violations of 2C:20-7A and 2C:17-6B.  Zhang was released on a summons with prosecutorial approval from the BCPO.             I secured the New Jersey dealer plate as evidence.             I was able to confirm that Progressive Insurance paid the claim to the owner of the vehicle and that they are now the owner of the vehicle.                 I will attempt to contact Progressive Insurance to notify them of the recovery of the vehicle.  I will also be removing the fraudulent VINs from the vehicle to prepare the vehicle to be released to the owner.

Sgt. Briggs and I responded to the listed location on a report of a recovered stolen vehicle (FL-22ASLL). The complainant, Avis Budget Group vehicles located the vehicle at Polifly Towing Inc.  A check of the registration and VIN revealed that the vehicle was reported stolen from VA.  The vehicle was removed from NCIC.  Lightning Automotive LLC towing towed the vehicle back to Avis Budget Group vehicle.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3
column13: Peter Gennat responded to headquarters for a report of recovered stolen motor vehicle. The victim stated he received a phone call from the Ridgefield Park Police Department at approximately 1745 hours, August 11, 2022, advising that his vehicle "N53PGF" was located in Ridgefield Park appearing to be abandoned. Peter Gennat confirmed that he last parked his vehicle at approximately 1400 hours, August 10, 2022, at his parking space in 90 Essex Street, Hackensack, NJ. He confirmed that nobody had permission to use his vehicle and confirmed it was stolen from the parking lot of 90 Essex Street. The victim wished to have the vehicle processed. A Hackensack Police Department Consent to Search Vehicle Form was completed and signed by the victim.       Detective Mora was notified. See his supplement.      NJ-N53PGF was input into NCIC by Hackensack Police communications.

column2: Motor Vehicle StopRecovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: While on patrol in Radio Car #112, I observed the listed vehicle with tinted front windows in violation of 39:3-74 (Obstruction of windshield for vision) traveling southbound on South Summit Avenue. The vehicle then made a right turn onto West Pleasant View Avenue. I conducted a motor vehicle stop on the vehicle which was bearing a temporary Texas Buyer registration of 0816A96. P.O. Bonsu responded to assist.      I approached the vehicle from the passenger's side and requested his driver's license, registration, and proof of insurance. Upon speaking to the driver, he was identified as NO RECORD via his NJ driver's license. The driver was unable to provide any registration documents forthe vehicle with the exception of the Texas buyers tag that was displayed on the rear of the vehicle. The driver produced his proof of insurance and advised that he was the owner of ROAC Auto Sales based out of Hasbrouck Heights. NJ.      A check of the public window VIN (salws2ru8la885755) revealed no record for the vehicle. A police database search was conducted for the VIN which also resulted in negative results for any vehicle information.      I advised NO RECORD to exit the vehicle to which he complied. NO RECORD stated that the vehicle was shipped to him  on 08/15/2022 from Texas via a transporter hence it had a Texas temporary registration. NO RECORD further explained that he was going to be shipping the vehicle to Lagos, Nigeria.     Based upon the publicly displayed VIN showing no return, the vehicle being shipped to Lagos, Nigeria, and my training and experience, I believed that the vehicle was stolen.     I requested a supervisor to the scene and Sgt. Briggs was apprised of the motor vehicle stop. A probable cause search of the vehicle was then conducted and the secondary vin of the vehicle was located (salwv2sv2ka843865). The VIN was searched and it was found to be a stolen vehicle from Billingsley, Oklahoma. See his supplemental report for additional information.      NO RECORD was then placed under arrest. He was handcuffed with his arms behind his back and searched incident to his arrest with negative results for contraband. He was then escorted into the rear seat compartment of Radio Car #112, which was checked prior to and after his occupancy with negative results for contraband.       The passenger of the vehicle was identified as Devin Dixon via his New Jersey driver's license. A warrant check was unable to be completed on Dixon due the system being down due to system maintenance. Dixon was then dispersed from the scene without incident.       NO RECORD was then transported to police headquarters in Radio Car #112 as P.O. Bonsu followed. At headquarters, a secondary search of the arrestee was conducted with negative results for contraband. The arrestee's property was then inventoried. I photographed and processed NO RECORD without incident.      I generated complaint 0223-S-2022-NO RECORD against NO RECORD for violations of N.J.S.2C:20-7a (2nd degree crime), N.J.S.2C:17-6b (3rd degree crime), and N.J.S.2C:21-2.1D (4th degree crime). NO RECORD was also issued summons E22-024579 for violation of 39:3-74.

On 8/16/2022 at approximately 1103 hours, I was on patrol in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 105.  P.O. Seretis conducted a motor vehicle stop in front of 380 West Pleasantview Avenue with a black Land Rover Range Rover.  P.O. Seretis requested a supervisor and I responded.  I assisted P.O. Seretis with obtaining the real VIN, which was a stolen vehicle.  I removed the fraudulent federal VIN sticker from the door jam.  Court House Towing responded and impounded the vehicle.  I followed the vehicle to Police Headquarters where I was able to remove the fraudulent public window VIN sticker.  The vehicle was then impounded by Court House.  Both fraudulent VIN stickers were turned over to P.O. Seretis to be secured as evidence.  I contacted Ally Bank, who insures the vehicle, and advised them that they can pick up the vehicle.

While assigned Main Street, I observed the listed vehicle parked in front of 348 Main Street and appeared to have fresh damage to the driver side.  I conducted a random inquiry of the registration which showed the vehicle to be stolen out of New York.  I advised Police Headquarters and Sgt. Briggs and P.O. Luppino responded to assist.  While awaiting the confirmation from New York, Mr. Correa came out from his apartment and stated that it is his girlfriends vehicle and explained the situation of when it was stolen and that she went to the 34th Precinct last week when she located the vehicle.  Sgt. Briggs spoke with the owner of the vehicle over the phone and she was instructed to contact our Police Headquarters.  Before the Locate could be sent to New York, it had been removed from NCIC and shows the NIC no longer exists.

While on patrol, I met with registered owner, Valerie Trusty, who flagged me down in the rear of 137 Hudson Street parking lot.  She explained that she just reported her vehicle stolen a few hours ago and her mother called her to advise that she found it parked in that parking lot.  I asked if she wanted the vehicle processed for fingerprints and she said no.  I asked if she knew who took the vehicle and she said no.  She added that she would file charges if the suspect is identified.  The vehicle was located across the street from the location it was stolen.  I asked her if she had any suspects given she has they keys and the vehicle was moved across the street and she said no. I asked her if anything was stolen or broken and she said no.  The registered owner took possession of her vehicle.Dispatch was advised to remove the vehicle from NCIC as stolen.  See supplemental report.
Error

On 8/24/2022 at approximately 1302, I was on patrol in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 105.  While on patrol, I observed a grey Jeep Cherokee parked in front of 55 Linden Street bearing Georgia temporary plate S1237834.  The VIN (1c4pjldb1ld638523, a 2020 Jeep Cherokee Limited) showed that the vehicle was currently registered in California.  While attempting to speak to the registered owner of the 2020 Jeep Cherokee Limited, Inca exited the pharmacy and approached the vehicle.  I advised Inca that I believed that the vehicle was stolen, to which she replied that her daughter rented the vehicle from Facebook Marketplace and that her daughter is currently out of the country.  As Inca opened the driver's side door, I was able to see the last 8 of the real VIN (KD422777).  A check of the last 8 yielded the full VIN of 1c4pjmdx4kd422777 (a 2019 Jeep Cherokee Limited), which was reported stolen out of Englewood, NJ on 3/29/2022.  I removed the fictitious Federal VIN sticker and the real VIN sticker was underneath it.  I also removed the fictitious public window VIN sticker.  The vehicle was impounded by Brookside Towing.  I contacted Farmer's Insurance and advised them that the vehicle was recovered.  Farmer's Insurance paid out approximately $29000.00 for the theft claim.Due to the claim made that the vehicle was rented by her daughter on Facebook Marketplace, Inga was not arrested at this time.  Inga was advised to have her daughter contact our Detective Bureau upon her return to the country for a statement.All evidence was secured in evidence locker #7.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Stop
column13: On 8/30/2022 at approximately 1334, I was on patrol in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 105.  While on patrol, I observed a gray Dodge Challenger parked in front of 200 Central Avenue bearing NJ/ F30LJJ.  The vehicle had no front license plate, an expired inspection, front tinted windows, as well as a license plate device used to flip a license plate to a different license plate.  The VIN associated with the license plate (2C3CDZAG9GH231989) came back to an SXT Challenger with a 3.6L non turbo motor.  Guerrero approached the vehicle and turned the vehicle on.  I conducted a motor vehicle stop based on the title 39 violations.  P.O. Almonte responded to assist.  While speaking with the driver, he advised me that he bought the vehicle a few years ago and it was not a HELLCAT, but rather an SXT with a front bumper swap.            I asked Guerrero to step out of the vehicle, which he complied.  I observed the public window VIN to be 2C3CDZAG9GH231989.  I observed the federal VIN sticker to peel off.  Based on the vehicle appearing to be a HELLCAT trim, the federal VIN sticker peeling off, as well as my training and experience, I had probable cause to believe that the vehicle was stolen and had a re-vin of the SXT.  I was able to retrieve the real VIN, which was 2C3CDZC95GH344451.  This VIN was confirmed to be stolen on 8/26/2018 in Elizabeth Port, NJ.            Guerrero was placed under arrest, placed in handcuffs behind his back, searched, and placed in the rear seat of Radio Car 105.  I conducted a probable cause search of the vehicle with negative results for contraband.  The secondary VIN was found to be modified.  The passenger was dispersed from the area being that the fake VIN was registered in Guerrero's name.  The vehicle was impounded by All Points Towing.              Guerrero was transported to Headquarters.  The rear seat of Radio Car 105 was checked prior to and after Guerrero's occupancy with negative results for contraband  Guerrero was searched a second time.  Guerrero was processed.  I signed complaint #0223S2022-569 against Guerrero for violations of 2C:20-7a.  I also issued Guerrero the following summonses:Summons #E22-26335 for a violation of 39:3-74Summons #E22-26336 for a violation of 39:3-4Summons #E22-26337 for a violation of 39:3-33Summons #E22-26338 for a violation of 39:3-38Summons #E22-26339 for a violation of 39:3-33ASummons #E22-26340 for a violation of 39:3-77Summons #E22-26341 for a violation of 39:8-1Guerrero was released on the summonses.All Points Towing transported the vehicle to Headquarters where I removed the public window VIN.  I also defaced the altered secondary VIN.  All Points removed the vehicle to their impound yard.All evidence was secured in evidence locker #7.I notified USAA Insurance that the vehicle was ready to be picked up from All Points Towing.

While patrolling in R/C138, in the area of Main Street and Coles Avenue, the ALPR (Automatic License Plate Reader) alerted me on a stolen registration bearing New Jersey registration (X91MLY) on a white Ford Explorer.  The vehicle was located parked and unoccupied.  Headquarters confirmed that the registration was stolen out of this jurisdiction.  P.O. Bonsu arrived on the scene to assist.  At this time, the registered owner exited his apartment and I spoke with him.  He advised me that the New Jersey registration was on his Jeep, which was reported stolen in June this year.  He reported that his Jeep was recovered in Dumont, NJ crashed after a pursuit, and the suspect was arrested.  The vehicle was then processed by the Bergen County Sheriff's Department B.C.I Unit.  After the vehicle was processed, he reported it was towed to a body shop, where it was deemed a total loss.  He removed the New Jersey registration from the JEEP and reregistered it to his new vehicle, a 2014 Ford Explorer.  The vehicle registration was cleared from N.C.I.C as stolen.

While on patrol in marked Radio Car #120, I observed a black Mercedes Benz CLA 250 bearing "Web Temporary Permit" CB4467J parked facing north in front of 32 Berkshire Place. The temporary marker did not have a state listed on it, was issued by "Web Temporary Permit," and was unevenly cut and laminated causing me to believe it was fictitious. A computer inquiry of the Vehicle's Identification Number revealed the vehicle was stolen out of Teaneck, NJ, on September 8, 2022. I advised headquarters via the radio who contacted Teaneck PD. Teaneck PD confirmed the vehicle was stolen out of their jurisdiction. The vehicle was stolen from Teaneck PD's impound lot and does not have a registration. At the direction of Teaneck PD, DeGraw Auto Body responded and towed the vehicle, see tow report. The fictitious temporary marker was secured and placed in the Traffic box.

On 5/17/2022 at approximately 1500, I was at Court House Towing (200 Lee Place).  While there, I observed a black Mercedes Benz C63AMG bearing A46PND (VIN #55swf8gb1ku315004) with heavy front end damage in their lot.  An employee of Court House Towing stated that they impounded the vehicle from South Hackensack due to it being reported stolen by Pennsylvania State Police after it was located by an employee of Geico Insurance.  The Court House Towing employee stated that something felt weird with the vehicle.  I observed the public window VIN to be fictitious.  A Police database check confirmed that the VIN was in fact fictitious.   It should be noted that the New Jersey license plate on the vehicle with the fictitious VIN was registered to the suspect who resided in Hackensack at that time.         I was able to locate a NJTR-1 crash report taken by the Paterson Police on 4/8/2022 at 0012 hours (Crash occurred at Market Street/E 42nd Street, Paterson NJ).  In the crash report, the owner, who was the driver of the vehicle, was the suspect. I spoke with TFC. Colm Hirschmann from the Pennsylvania State Police, who entered the vehicle as stolen.  TFC. Hirschmann stated that somebody attempted to title the fictitious VIN through the Pennsylvania DMV, which prompted him to report the vehicle stolen until the real VIN could be determined.Due to the vehicle appearing to be a high-end re-vin, I contacted Agent Stanicki from the NICB to confirm the real VIN.  Agent Stanicki reached out to me and advised me that the secondary VIN on the vehicle was completely removed.  Agent Stanicki confirmed with Mercedes Benz that they never produced a vehicle with the VIN that was on the vehicle.  Agent Stanicki was able to locate the real VIN on the vehicle (55swf8gb1ku315942).  This VIN was reported stolen by Hertz Rental on 10/5/2019 in Florida.  The real stolen vehicle was removed from N.C.I.C. by Agent Stanicki.Progressive Insurance paid out the insurance claim to Hertz Rental in the amount of $55663.00.I reached out to Detective Sgt. Donatello from the South Hackensack Police Department and advised them of the circumstances surrounding the vehicle.  Det. Sgt. Donatello stated that their investigation was complete and they had no intention of signing complaints against anyone.Based on DeLosSantos being the registered owner of the vehicle, DeLosSantos being involved in a crash in the vehicle where he was the driver, the fact that I observed the vehicle in Hackensack bearing a fictitious public VIN, the vehicle being confirmed stolen, as well as my training and experience, I signed complaint #0223W2022-000588 against DeLosSantos for violations of 2C:20-7a and 2C:17-6b.  I mailed the complaint to his registered address in Clifton, NJ.The vehicle was recovered by Progressive Insurance therefore no evidence was able to be recovered from the vehicle.I uploaded to Infoshare the Paterson, NJ crash report, all NICB paperwork in reference to the vehicle (both real and fictitious VINs), the Pennsylvania State Police incident report, the South Hackensack Police incident report, and the South Hackensack Police impound report.

column2: Theft by Extortion  2C:20-5Criminal Attempt  2C:5-1Harassment  2C:33-4
column13: I responded to Hackensack Police Headquarters on a report of Harassment. Upon arrival, I was met with the complainant, James A Jones. Mr. Jones stated that he matched with someone on an online dating web called "Summer". The person he matched with was named "Christina" online, who claimed to live in Manhattan, New York. He was speaking with Christina for about a week. Both parties exchanged explicit photos over text message. He stated that Christina messaged him stated that if he does not send her $200, she will expose him and post his photos on social media. Christina is unaware of his home address or any other personal information, except for his phone number. Mr. Jones stated that he never video called Christina and is unsure whether Christina is a real or fake online account scamming users on that dating app. Christina's phone number is 929-369-8641. Both parties do not have each other befriended on any social media platform, and have no other common forms of connection or communication.  I advised Mr. Jones to block Christina's phone number. He was advised that this incident will be documented.

While on patrol, I observed Vehicle 1 parked facing southbound in front of 80 Arcadia Road bearing fictitious Georgia temporary plate S1304581.  A check of the Georgia temporary plate yielded that the temporary plate expired on 09/22/2022.   I issued the vehicle summonses H958957 and H958958 for violations of 39:3-4 and 39:3-33.  As I was placing the tickets on the windshield I observed the public window vin sticker appear to be also fictitious.  I requested a tow truck to responded and  Tumino's Towing responded.  Sgt. Briggs arrived to assist.  While waiting for the tow truck to respond a check of the public VIN and temporary plate VIN did not match.  Based on various exterior numbers on the vehicle, we believed the vehicle to be a 2019 or 2020, not a 2021.  A public records check of the Vin yielded the vehicle was salvaged total lose with extensive damage.       Based on all of the above factors as well as both mine and Sgt. Briggs training and experience, we had probable cause to believe the vehicle was stolen with a fraudulent vin. The tow truck driver opened the door and I observed the Federal VIN Sticker to be fictitious with remnants of glue around the sticker. The secondary VIN was also Fictitious. A component number was located and ran in a police data base which yielded the following VIN 1N4AA6AV6KC374117.  A check of this VIN yielded that it was stolen on 06/15/2020 in New York, NY.  The vehicle was impounded and all fictitious VINS were removed.  The total approximate value of the vehicle is $35,410.00.Due to the numerous fictitious VINs, the NICB will be contacted by Sgt. Briggs to attempt to confirm the real VIN for the vehicle prior to clearing the vehicle from NCIC.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleCDS/Distribution  2C:35-5Receiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: Sgt. Briggs and I were assigned to the pedestrian safety detail in Radio car #107. As we were driving northbound on Main Street near Mercer Street, we observed a white Jeep Grand Cherokee bearing a Florida dealer plate (FL-PI5825) with a large tree style air freshener obstructing the view of the driver, in violation of 39:3-74.  A motor vehicle stop was conducted Sgt. Briggs exited the patrol vehicle to look at the VIN of the vehicle which was obscured. At this time the driver of the vehicle, Frank Vasquez was located within the vehicle. A motor vehicle stop was conducted on Main Street near Mercer Street. P.O. Gallorini and Detective Han responded to assist.       Vasquez was asked to step out of the vehicle which he voluntarily complied. Vasquez then stood by in the rear of the vehicle, while Sgt. Briggs attempted to locate the VIN of the vehicle. Sgt. Briggs then confirmed that the vehicle was reported stolen. Vasquez was then placed under arrest with both arms behind his back. He was searched incident to his arrest and a clear plastic bag that contained 13 smaller clear baggies.  These 13 clear baggies containing suspected crack cocaine. The plastic bag that contained the baggies of suspected crack cocaine were secured.  The arrestee also had US currency in the vehicle which was secured.      Sgt. Briggs stayed on scene to await the tow truck.  The vehicle was then impounded. See tow report.       Vasquez was then transported to police headquarters as Detective Han followed. The rear seat compartment of Radio Car #107 was checked prior to and after the arrestee's occupancy with negative results for contraband. At headquarters the arrestee was searched, photographed and processed without incident.  The arrestee was placed in cell #1 awaiting remandment to the Bergen County Jail.      The suspected crack cocaine was transported to the Bergen County Prosecutor's Office where it was field tested and confirmed to be cocaine. The fraudulent VIN # was removed from the vehicle and placed into evidence.        Complaint 0223-W2022-612 was generated by Lt. Natale against the arrestee for violations of 2C:20-7a, 2C:17-6B, and 2C:35-5a(1). The arrestee was then remanded to the Bergen County Jail.       Vasquez was issued the following motor vehicle summonses: -E22029963 for violation of 39:3-35-E22029964 for violation of 39:3-4-E22029965 for violation of 39:3-74-E22029966 for violation of 39:4-48.1The 13 baggies containing crack cocaine were weighed which yielded 15.2 grams with a street value of approximately $608.00 .  The crack cocaine was secured in evidence control bag #0333829.Sgt. Briggs and I counted the US currency which was $250.00.  We completed the Request for Distribution of Forfeited Property form which was signed by Sgt. Briggs, the arrestee, and myself.  The $250.00 was secured in evidence control bag #3793328.The US currency was turned over to P.O. Morton.  All other evidence was secured in evidence locker #7.Geico Insurance was notified about the impoundment of the vehicle and advised how to retrieve the vehicle.
column14: Geico Insurance was notified about the impoundment of the vehicle and advised how to retrieve the vehicle.

column13: This officer observed the listed vehicle parked in violation of No Parking Certain Hours across the street from 110 Grove. The vehicle did not have any license plates displayed. This officer checked the vehicles VIN in NCIC. The results showed that the vehicle was reported stolen in Philadelphia, PA on 4/13/2021 (OCA: 2021-07-009099). Headquarters confirmed with Philadelphia PD that the vehicle was stolen. Bergen Brookside Towing responded and removed the vehicle. This officer captured the vehicles damage and overall condition on my BWC. See Tow Report for further.

column2: Assist Other AgencyRecovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: Robinsville Police Department contacted our Police Headquarters to report that they were contacted by the registered owner of a stolen tractor trailer bearing Maine registration 3242857. They were advised that the listed trailer was tracked through GPS and was currently located at 535 South River Street in Hackensack, New Jersey.    P.O. Competiello and I responded to the listed location in an attempt to locate the listed trailer. Upon searching the area, the trailer was located on the Southern portion of the parking lot. All Point towing was notified, Moments later All Point towing responded and removed the vehicle from the lot. The trailer was checked prior to it being towed, which yielded negative results for any items. The trailer was towed to 145 Hopper Ave. Waldwick, NJ 07463 and the Owner was notified.

Suspect's description: White male, short and skinny, possible transgender (female to male), gray hooded sweatshirt, black jacket and black pants. The victim has seen the suspect in the neighborhood on several occasions but is unfamiliar of who the person is.       I responded to 165 Sussex Street for a assault. I activated my body worn camera. The victim, Marilin Abreu-Rosario, speaks Spanish. Due to language barrier, Ms. Jackie Santos was on scene and assisted with translation. She did not witness the incident. The victim reported while walking to her vehicle, which was parked in the parking lot of 165 Sussex Street, the suspect tackled her onto the sidewalk, north side of the business, by grabbing her lower extremities. She further reported her car key which was in her hand at the time was stolen from her by the suspect. The suspect then fled on foot north on Railroad Avenue. P.O. Duardo searched the area and yielded with negative results. P.O. Luppino arrived to assist. The victim reported that the suspect did not display any weapons nor made any aggressive statements. The victim further reported that the suspect did not attempt to steal her vehicle. Sgt. Peralta and Detective division was notified.         The victim reported that she injured her head and right arm on the concrete sidewalk. Hackensack ambulance #1341 responded, treated and transported her to Hackensack University Medical Center. P.O. Luppino followed the ambulance to the hospital. A New Jersey Victim notification form was completed. The victim would like to make recorded statements after her medical evaluation.     It should be noted, the victim reported that the suspect attempted this same method of robbery three (3) weeks ago at 165 Sussex Street. She was able to defend herself from the suspect. She did not report the incident.    Det. Han was advised and responded.

Suspect: Caucasian male, blue eyes, about 5'2, slim built.    On October 20th, 2022, at approximately 08:30 hours I was assisting Detective Han translate a voluntary statement from the victim, Marilin Abreu-Rosario, for case #22-082453 .  During the translation, the victim stated that the incident that occurred today wasn't the first time it had occurred.       The victim stated that about a month ago at approximately 05:50 hours, she was walking eastbound towards her vehicle that was parked at 165 Sussex Street, when she was assaulted.  The victim states that the unknown suspect jumped from behind her, grabbed her buttocks and groped her.  The victim quickly elbowed him with her right elbow and the suspect fled eastbound on Sussex Street towards the railroads.  The unknown suspect did not take anything from the victim.  The victim never reported the incident due to her being in a rush to go to work.The victim was given a copy of the victim notification form today.

Suspect(s): Unknown        On Wednesday, October 26, 2022 at approximately 7:26 a.m., I responded to 268 Kipp Street on report of a theft. Upon arrival I spoke with the victim, the owner of vehicle 1. He stated his car was broken into and his wallet was taken. He stated he parked vehicle 1 NJ Reg H15-RLX in parking space 56 in the parking garage at 268 Kipp Street on 10/25/22 at approximately 8:00 p.m. When he returned to the vehicle on the next morning, he found his vehicle had be broken into, rummaged through and his wallet missing.     The victim further stated someone attempted to use his T.D. Bank card, and Visa Card at Rite Aid 219 Essex Street, Hackensack on 10/26/22 at approximately 2:55 a.m. and 3:10 a.m. but all transactions were declined.  The victim did not want the vehicle processed and the outside of the vehicle was wet due to rain. I checked the rest of garage for other vehicles possibly burglarized with negative results. Lt. Levis was advised. A Victim Notification Form was completed. No vehicle insurance information was provided. Per the victim there is a camera at entrance of garage. The victim also stated he left his vehicle unlocked.DSgt. Tripodi was notified.Items taken from vehicle are as follows:1 WalletVictim's N.J.D.L.Visa credit cardTD Bank cardChase Bank cardEstimated cost of the wallet is $30.00Cost of burglary is approximately $30.00

column2: Motor Vehicle TheftCriminal Attempt  2C:5-1Weapons/Unlawful Purposes  2C:39-4
column13: Suspect #1: Black male, tall thin build, black ski mask, khaki colored hooded sweatshirt, blue jeans, white sneakers, black gloves, and a handgun in his waistband.           Suspect #2: Black male, tall thin build, black ski mask, black hooded sweatshirt, black pants, and white sneakers.           On October 27, 2022 at approximately 1920 hours, I responded to 415 Hudson Street Apt 1E on a report of a possible theft involving a motor vehicle. I met with the complainant, Julian Diaz-Luna, in the parking lot of the complex. The complainant reported while inside of his apartment, he looked outside of his window and observed 2 unknown black males in the parking lot. He reported observing Suspect #1 holding what appeared to be a key and attempting to gain entry into NJ-G75HNF via the driver door, while Suspect #2 stood by on the Northwest end of the parking lot appearing to be a lookout. NJ-G75HNF was parked facing North in the parking space located in the Southeast corner of the parking lot.          The complainant reported that he was familiar that NJ-G75HNF's owner was a white male. The complainant confronted Suspect #1 verbally from the window asking him what he was doing near the vehicle. Suspect #1 stated, "oh is this your car?." The complainant reported he answered stating, "no," and when doing so, Suspect #1 stated, "if it's not your car then don't worry about."         The complainant then advised Suspect #1 that he was going to call the police, and he heard Suspect #2 yell, "yo let's the fuck outta here." The complainant further reported he then observed Suspect #1 appear to adjust a handgun in his waistband near his groin area and sprint fleeing North and then East out of the parking lot and out of his sight. The complainant reported he then heard what he believed was the two suspects flee in an unknown vehicle due to hearing a loud vehicle screech sound on Hudson Street. The complainant stated he did not observe the vehicle the suspects fled in but believed they fled North on Hudson Street. The complainant believed the suspects were attempting to steal the vehicle.      Upon observing NJ-G75HNF, I observed no apparent signs of forced entry. I made contact with the vehicle's owner/victim, Eric Kneisler. He was advised of the reported incident and responded to his vehicle to look for any signs of forced entry or theft. The victim confirmed no signs of forced entry, and nothing inside of the vehicle appeared disturbed. There was nothing missing and the vehicle was also confirmed to start and function properly.        Sgt. Swetits was notified and responded on scene.      The victim did not wish to have the vehicle processed at this time. The victim was unsure at this time if he wishes for to sign complaints if the suspects are identified. I did not observed any security cameras facing the area of the incident. Security cameras may be available nearby.     Approx. value of the vehicle: $30,000.00        A New Jersey Victim Witness Notification form was completed and the victim was issued a copy for his records.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7Motor Vehicle Stop
column13: While on patrol in Radio Car #120, I observed the listed vehicle (PA-LPE1957) traveling southbound on River Street near the intersection of Salem Street with tinted windows in violation of 39:3-74 (Obstruction of windshield for vision).  A license plate inquiry was conducted on the vehicle which returned no record. A motor vehicle stop was conducted and Sgt. Briggs responded to assist. I approached the vehicle from the passenger's side and requested the driver's license, registration, and proof of insurance from the driver who was later identified as Ramy Rincon Jr. I asked the driver to step out of the vehicle which he complied. As he was stepping out of the vehicle, Sgt. Briggs observed the VIN on the door to be fictitious. Based on the vehicle having a fictitious federal VIN sticker, a probable cause search was conducted to locate the real VIN number. A component number was located and run through a police database which returned to a VIN # (2C3cdxej9gh285674). The vehicle that the VIN returned to was reported stolen by Fairfax County Police in Virginia.       The driver was placed under arrest and handcuffed with his arms behind his back. He was searched incident to his arrest with negative results for contraband. A probable cause search of the vehicle was conducted with negative results. The arrestee was placed into the rear seat compartment of Radio Car #120 which was checked prior to and after his occupancy with negative results for contraband. The arrestee was then transported to police headquarters as P.O. Duardo followed. At police headquarters, I processed the arrestee without incident.       Lin-Z Towing responded and towed the vehicle to police headquarters for further investigation. At headquarters, Sgt. Briggs removed the fictitious VIN #s from the vehicle. See his supplemental report for additional information. The vehicle was then impounded. See tow report.      The approximate value of the vehicle was estimated at $40,000.00.     At police headquarters, I processed the arrestee without incident. Complaint 0223-S-2022-000664 for violations of N.J.S.2C:20-7A and 2C:17-6B was generated by Lt. Zisa on my behalf. The arrestee was then released from custody without incident. The driver was also issued summons H-959902 for violation of 39:3-33A.

I assisted P.O. Seretis on a motor vehicle stop involving a stolen vehicle with a fictitious VIN.  The fictitious federal VIN sticker, which was put on upside down, was removed on scene and turned over to P.O. Seretis After the vehicle was impounded, I removed the public VIN sticker, which was fictitious.  I observed the secondary VIN in the engine compartment to be removed by a grinder.  Another secondary VIN was located and was intact.  I removed the Pennsylvania license plate which was inside of a plate concealer.  Geico insurance was notified of the recovery and advised how to retrieve the vehicle.

The victim responded to the Hackensack Police Department to report a criminal mischief that occurred in September, 2022. The victim stated he traveled to Florida on September 7, 2022. When the victim returned to his residence on September 16, 2022, at approximately 1430 hours, he observed two marks on his front door frame that appeared to have been caused by a screwdriver. The victim then entered his residence and discovered the interior door knob was off and on the floor by the front door. The exterior door knob was intact and did not appear damaged. The victim did not believe anyone entered his residence as it appeared in good order and no items were missing. The estimated cost of damage to the victim's door was $20.00 and he did not want to pursue complaints.      The victim began observing unknown persons entering apartment 3D in October, 2022. The victim believed unknown criminal activity was occurring within that apartment. The victim and his neighbor placed a front doorbell camera on their doors. The victim's neighbor captured an unknown white female roaming the third floor with the resident of 3D. The victim believed this to be suspicious. I advised the victim to contact the Hackensack Police if any suspicious persons are observed.

I was dispatched on a report of burglar alarm / suspicious incident at the Toyota of Hackensack.  While traveling to the mentioned location dispatch gave the description of a male going under vehicles possibly committing a theft.  The information above was provided to our dispatch from Stealth Monitoring (security and surveillance service ) Operator Mike.  Upon my arrival to the Toyota dealership I witnessed a male running east towards Foschini Park wearing a ski mask, a camouflage coat and gray pants.  Officer Price and I were able to apprehend the suspect at the little league baseball field located at the entrance of Foschini Park.  The male surrendered with out incident.  After the male was placed inside my vehicle he stated to this writer, "My friend is the one who has the bag" " Not me".  At this time It was known that more then one male was at the mentioned location attempting to commit a theft.  Officer Garrett and Officer Scarpa canvassed the rear lot for damages to vehicles and additional suspects with negative results.The arrestee was transported to headquarters in the rear of radio car 119. Sergeant Meneses followed for transport.  The rear seat was checked prior to and after the arrestee's occupying radio car 119  for anything left behind with negative results. The arrestee was searched at headquarters and then processed.  Lt. Detective Smith responded to the scene and was advised on this incident. Complaints were signed against Devonte Harris for 2C:5-1a(3).  He was placed under Warrant number W 0223 2022-000680.

I responded to the dead end of Simons Avenue on a report of 2 black males exiting a vehicle and walked away.  Upon arrival, I checked a blue Mazda CX5 bearing NY registration GVZ1481 and received an NCIC hit for a stolen vehicle out of Yonkers City PD in NY.  The vehicle was confirmed stolen by dispatch (NIC V894481022).  There was no hold for fingerprints.I spoke to the complainant who wished to remain anonymous.  He stated he observed two black males exit the vehicle and he thought it was suspicious so he started to take pictures of them.  Those pictures were emailed to Hackensack PD detective bureau.I searched the vehicle and did not locate any contraband.  The condition of the vehicle was dirty, but it did not appear to be damaged or broken.  No key fob was located.  Two license plates bearing the same registration were still affixed to the vehicle.  Court House Towing responded and towed the vehicle to their impound lot.An expired insurance card was located in the glove compartment bearing Progressive insurance company policy number: 945817879, NY branch, insurance code 678.
Vehicle located in Paramus and removed from NCIC.Clear Nic/V914482485

On November 29, 2022 at approximately 1211 hours I responded to 136 State Street on a reported burglary to auto. Sgt. Briggs also responded to the scene. I spoke with the victim, Justin Glazer, who reported that he had parked his vehicle, bearing NJ K95MYB, facing East on the South side of 136 State Street at approximately 1845 hours on November 28, 2022. At approximately 1200 hours on November 29, 2022 he went to his vehicle and noticed that the plastic cover on the rear of the steering wheel was broken and tampered with. The estimated cost of repair is unknown at this time. The victim reported his car was locked when he parked the vehicle on November 28, 2022. There were no damages to the exterior vehicle. The victim was inside the vehicle prior to my arrival and may have contaminated the crime scene. When asked if he wanted the vehicle to be processed for fingerprints he declined. The insurance policy code for vehicle 1 is 134 and the policy number is 942267479. A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed. The victim wants to sign complaints if the suspect is identified.   There are no surveillance cameras on the exterior of 136 State Street however the complainant stated there are cameras across the street which may have captured the event.

I observed the listed vehicle parked facing west in front of 34 Fairmount Avenue, in violation of 170-8.  An NCIC check of the NY registration, KYZ5007, revealed the vehicle to be stolen out of our jurisdiction on 11/1/2022.  Police Headquarters was advised and confirmed the vehicle to be stolen.  Both registrations were on the vehicle, no keys with the vehicle and the ignition appeared to be in tact.  All-Points Towing was notified, responded and removed the vehicle without incident.  The vehicles condition was captured on my BWC.  The registered owner did not wish to have the vehicle processed.          The NY registration also came back as surrendered, so both registrations were removed and secured in the Traffic Division.  See Tow Report for further.

I responded to Garden State Plaza Parking Garage near the AMC Theatres on the second floor to secure evidence. Upon arrival I met with P.O. Cleary #474 who was being relieved. At this time the evidence was turned over to me. All Points Towing arrived on scene and towed vehicle from the listed location to BCI. I then followed to secure the evidence. Evidence was received by Det. Sgt. Schettino #1733.     A Receipt Evidence form was submitted by Det. Sgt. Schettino.

Suspect 1: Unknown Male possibly wearing a face mask, a black jacket and gray pants.Suspect 2: Unknown Male possibly wearing a face mask, a black jacket and black pants.On 11/29/22 the photographs of the suspects were requested from Patrol. It was reported an anonymous complainant captured two suspects exiting a suspicious vehicle, New York Registration GVZ1481. Patrol later responded and located the suspicious vehicle at the dead end of Simons Avenue, unknown exact location. A DMV check of the suspicious vehicle was conducted by Patrol, which confirmed it was stolen (NIC # V894481022).The recovered stolen vehicle was entered into the Auto Theft Task Force (ATTF) online portal. On 11/30/22 Patrol emailed me six (6) photographs. Upon observing the photographs, they were blurry, but two suspects were captured. Due to the quality of the photograph(s) the suspects were unable to be identified. On 12/5/22 I responded to the area of 484 Simons Avenue to check the area for video surveillance regarding a recovered stolen vehicle that was located on 11/22/22. Upon checking the area, I observed 484 Simons Avenue and 479 Simons Avenue had exterior video surveillance cameras. Upon responding to 484 Simons Avenue, I spoke with a resident, who couldnt fully understand English. My telephone number was provided to the resident who reported her husband spoke English and would contact me later. Upon responding to 479 Simons Avenue, I spoke with a resident, who also didnt speak English. An in-house computer search of 479 Simons Avenue provided information for a possible resident. The telephone number listed for the possible resident was contacted and resulted negative. A voicemail was left requesting a call back.I later received a call from the resident of 484 Simons Avenue who reported his video surveillance camera was motion activated and did not capture the suspects. It was also reported 479 Simons Avenue video surveillance camera was also motion activated and did not capture the suspects.At this time the suspects were unable to be identified. This case will remain administratively closed pending further development.

While on patrol and taking photographs for a criminal mischief investigation (See Case# 22-099490), I observed Vehicle 1 parked in the southwest corner of the third level of the parking garage with heavy damage to both front tires. A computer inquiry of the registration showed that the vehicle had been reported stolen out of Teaneck on 11/29/2022. Police Headquarters was advised and sent a hit confirmation which Teaneck responded and confirmed. The registered owner did not wish to have the vehicle processed. Both plates were affixed to the vehicle and no key was observed with the vehicle. Hackensack Auto Body  was notified, responded and removed the vehicle.  The condition of the vehicle was captured on my BWC prior to being towed.  See Tow Report for further.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7
column13: On Wednesday, December 14, 2022, the Narcotics Bureau was contacted by Carteret P.D. Special Investigation Unit (SIU) regarding a auto crime cell operating in Hackensack and throughout the tri-state area. Carteret P.D. further advised D/Sgt. Dalton that on 12/13/22, a victim responded to the Carteret P.D. to file a police report. See original case report as transcribed by PO Sanfilippo (Carteret PD.) The victim reported that on 12/10/22, he purchased a 2021 Honda CRV for $22,000.00 in United States Currency (USC) in the parking lot of Coach House Diner from an unknown Hispanic male (UHM), later identified Dariel ACEVEDO. On 12/13/22, the victim attempted to register the vehicle at DMV, at which time he was advised that the vehicle was re-vinned and confirmed stolen. As a result, the Narcotics Bureau and Carteret P.D. Special Investigations Unit initiated a joint investigation into ACEVEDO and any additional co-conspirators. On 12/14/22, at the direction of the Hackensack Police Department Narcotics Bureau and Carteret P.D., an Undercover (UC) posed as the victim's son-in-law and made phone contact with ACEVEDO to facilitate the purchase of a second vehicle. ACEVEDO advised the UC that he would meet the UC at the Coach House Diner located at 55 Route 4 east to sell him a white 2022 Honda CRV for the negotiated price of $22,000.00 in USC.     At approximately 1145 hours, members of the Carteret Special Investigations Unit responded to the Hackensack Police Department. A briefing was held in the Detectives Bureau prior to the UC buy. The purpose of the briefing was to inform all law enforcement personnel of the prearranged plan for the UC to purchase a White, 2022 Honda CRV. After the briefing, all personnel responded to 55 Route 4 East (Coach House Diner) and established stationary surveillance. It should be noted that a Law Enforcement inquiry revealed ACEVEDO had numerous active ATS warrants.     At approximately 1317 hours, a white Honda CRV being operated by ACEVEDO arrived in the lot of Coach House Diner bearing a fictitious NJ temporary tag (NJ/S537129.). Upon the UC making contact with ACEVEDO, members of the Carteret Special Investigations Unit and the Hackensack Narcotics Bureau moved in and detained ACEVEDO. I observed the public vin that was displayed on the outer portion of the vehicle near the driver side windshield, which I believed to be fraudulent. That fraudulent vin near the windshield appeared to be a sticker which was the same vin number that matched on the fictitious temporary New Jersey registration that was affixed to the rear of the vehicle. Based on the totality of the circumstances, and my training, education and experience, I have first hand knowledge that cloning of vins is a way to mask the true identity of stolen cars. Based on the aforementioned, and the fact that ACEVEDO recently sold the same make and model to the initial victim which was confirmed stolen, I had probable cause to believe that the vehicle in question was likely stolen.      As a result, a probable cause search of the vehicle was conducted by D/Sgt. Dalton and I. Upon entering the vehicle, I observed the same fraudulent vin throughout the entire vehicle, including the secret vin located underneath the floor board of the front passenger side floor. Upon further inspection I observed welding marks "Tooling" around the entirety of the secret vin which is not consistent with factory manufacturing. This raised my suspicion even further believing a after market alteration to the vehicle, specifically the secret vin had occurred. I was then able to chisel out the fake vin (2HKRW2H83NH962007) which was stamped on a peice of metal and welded to the vehicle. Once removed, I observed a layer of Bondo which is a putty body filler commonly used to fill voids, repair dents, fill holes. I have direct knowledge that Bondo is used when specifically altering a vehicle for criminal activity such as hidden compartment "traps" and re-vinning vehicles. Once I scrapped the Bondo off it revealed the true   vin number (2HKRW2H81NH669237) to the vehicle.         It was determined that the listed vehicle was re-vinned and confirmed stolen out of the City of New York NIC# V144604630. ACEVEDO was arrested by the Carteret Special Investigations Unit along with the Hackensack Narcotics Bureau for receiving stolen property, 2C:20-7. Search incident to arrest yielded an unknown amount of United States Currency in ACEVEDO'S left Jean pocket. It was later determined the USC totaled $1,256.13, which is believed to be illicit proceeds derived from illegal activity and seized. Additionally, ACEVEDO was charged for original incident which occurred on 12/10/22 for fencing stolen property, 2C:20-7.1b(1) and receiving stolen property, 2C:20-7.     Shortly thereafter, Hackensack Auto Body responded to take possession of the vehicle and one key fob. See tow report for further.      Prior to the listed vehicle being towed, Carteret PD seized the following paperwork as evidence.- Fraudulent New Jersey Temp Tag - Suspected Fraudulent New York State Motor Vehicle Title - Fraudulent Federal Vin- Two (2) suspected fraudulent New Jersey ID Cards - Fraudulent Metal Vin- Fraudulent Bill of Sale issued by New York State.        *See evidence report for further details*          ACEVEDO was issued the following motor vehicle summonses, 39: 3-33/fictitious plates, 39:3-4/unregistered, 39:3-40/suspended and 39:6B2/failure to produce insurance. These summonses were issued and mailed to mailing address provided by ACEVEDO.         D/Sgt. Dalton advised communications and requested a marked unit respond for prisoner transport. Shortly thereafter, PO Seretis responded, took custody of ACEVEDO and placed him in the rear of Radio Car #120. Radio Car #120 was checked prior to and after transport yielding negative results for any contraband.       At Police Headquarters, communications conducted a warrant check on ACEVEDO which revealed five (5) active ATS warrants. They are as follows:1. Warrant #C53082 was issued on 06/23/2022 in violation of 39:3-40 out of River Edge, NJ. 2. Warrant #E21004987 was issued on 11/24/2021 in violation of 39:4-115 out of Fort Lee, NJ. 3. Warrant #C053082 was issued on 03/22/2022 in violation of 39:3-4 out of River Edge, NJ.  4. Warrant #C053083 was issued on 03/22/2022 in violation of 39:3-10 out of River Edge, NJ.  5. Warrant #E21004986 was issued on 11/24/2021 in violation of 39:3-10 out of Fort Lee, NJ.     ACEVEDO was processed, photographed and placed in cell #1. ACEVEDO was subsequently transported to the Bergen County Jail on Warrants #W2022000732 and #W2022000733.Detectives Note: In order to protect the UC's identity, and as per Carteret PD, body worn cameras were not activated. See Carteret PD Detective Reyes' follow up report for further.    On Thursday, December 15, 2022, I signed an additional complaint on summons # S 2022 000736 against ACEVEDO for removal or alteration of the Vehicle Identification Number in violation of 2C:17-6B.       **All times mentioned are approximate and any statements are noted in sum and substance**

Warrant #E21004987 was issued on 11/24/2021 in violation of 39:4-115 out of Fort Lee, NJ. 3. Warrant #C053082 was issued on 03/22/2022 in violation of 39:3-4 out of River Edge, NJ.

column13: On this date I received a locate message from Paterson PD for NCIC #V704534351 which was located in that jurisdiction. Paterson PD contacted the owner of the vehicle. The NCIC entry was cleared on this date.

On Tuesday, December 28, 2022 at approximately 0522 hours, while on patrol, I observed a unoccupied, black Honda Pilot, bearing NJ registration C98JRL, parked facing south in front of 391 Park Street. The front passenger door and trunk of the vehicle were completely open.      P.O. Estrada responded to assist. After a closer inspection, I observed the vehicle to still be running with the key in ignition. Contents of the vehicle's glove box were scattered across both the front driver side and passenger side seats. There were also construction tools that I observed to be scattered throughout the interior of the vehicle.              A computer check of the vehicle's registration was conducted by communications and produced results for registered owner, Cristinei Vergara out of Teaneck, NJ.     After a check of the area, It had appeared that contents from the vehicle were ejected onto the roadway of Passaic Street, between Union and Park Street. All items that could be recovered were placed in the trunk of the listed vehicle.      No driver or occupants of the listed vehicle were located. Teaneck PD was apprised of the incident and to notified the registered owner. The registered owner responded to the scene and recovered the vehicle shortly thereafter.

On January 2nd at approximately 00:19 hours, P. O. Farhi and I were dispatched to the listed location (Area A garage) on a report of an unknown male party exiting a vehicle near space 109, which a window was observed to have been broken. Upon arrival, I located said vehicle, a black four door 2011 Hyundai sedan in space 112 with the rear driver's side window completely shattered out. A perimeter was set and a sweep of the garage was conducted for the suspect and any additional vehicles damaged. The search yielded negative results and the registered owner was ultimately contacted and responded. The registered owner, Mr. Shrestha, stated that he did not wish to have the vehicle processed at this time and decline to pursue prosecution. It should be noted that no items were reported taken from inside the vehicle, however, the vehicle's                Cont. page 2steering column and ignition were completely dismantled as appeared that the unknown suspect was attempting to steal the vehicle.Estimate cost of the damage was approximately $1,500.00.Insurance: 134 - Progressive Policy # 908405952

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Complaint
column13: I responded to the listed location on a motor vehicle violation - private property.  The complainant stated he found the vehicle parked in his parking spot, space 8, yesterday 01/02/2023, at approximately 4:30 p.m. The vehicle was still parked today 01/03/23 so he contacted police. The vehicle did not have a license plate attached so I ran the VIN, #5NEPB4ACXBH122967, and an NCIC response returned said vehicle was stolen.  I requested confirmation from dispatch who confirmed  the vehicle was stolen out of Pennsylvania. Tumino's Towing was notified and responded.  Vehicle driver side door was locked but passenger door was unlocked.  Vehicle had paperwork from used car dealership within, All State Auto Sales.
