Minor scratches and small dent to the rear bumper was the only visible damage. The ignition did not appear to be tampered with.

This operator received a delayed NCIC notification for a stolen auto by the Paterson Police Department.  I contacted Paterson Police and they confirmed the vehicle was reported stolen by the owner at approximately 2330 hours.  The NCIC Hit Confirmation was sent.  Upon receiving the confirmation, an NCIC Locate was sent.

P.O. Duardo, Sgt. Briggs and I responded to the area of Kipp Street and Polilfly Road upon being advised by P.O. Reyes that the victim's phone was pinging to that location. Upon searching the area, Sgt. Briggs and I located the black 2017 Honda Pilot bearing NJ Reg: P64RFG in the 286 Kipp Street underground parking lot. The vehicle was off and unoccupied at this time. Dispatch was notified of the recovered vehicle. P.O. Reyes advised Sgt. Briggs and I that the victim stated she would like to have the vehicle processed. Detectives were notified. I stood by with the vehicle keeping constant visual contact as I awaited detectives to respond.   Det. Han and Det. Mora responded to 280 Kip and assumed custody of the vehicle.  The vehicle was towed by Court House Auto Body to Bergen County BCI.  Det. Han and Det. Mora followed the vehicle while being towed.

I responded to 308 Second Street, Hackensack Auto Wreckers for a recovered stolen vehicle.  Upon arrival I met with the complainant, the owner of Hackensack Auto Wreckers, Sally Locicero. She stated that her company towed the listed vehicle bearing NJ registration V46PPX yesterday in front of 432 Clifton Ave, Newark, NJ at approximately 1130 hours.  The victim, Rosalyn Soto reported her vehicle stolen with the Newark Police Department yesterday.  Today, I observed the vehicle which was not in driving condition.  The vehicle was missing parts and had started to be disassembled.  The vehicle was located in the junk yard of 308 Second Street.  I spoke with Det. Valentin #11136 of Newark Police, who advised me that the vehicle was entered as stolen yesterday into NCIC (Newark PD report #23-003616//NIC #V074702030).    Vehicle printouts and information related to this case were tagged with a case number and placed into the detectives mailbox at the front desk. DSgt Tripodi was aware.

While on patrol in Radio Car 141, I observed the listed vehicle partially parked along the curb and also in violation of "No Parking Any TIme".  As I got closer to the vehicle I recognized that it matched the description of a vehicle that was stolen in our jurisdiction earlier in the week.  A computer check confirmed that the vehicle was stolen.  Both plates were still affixed to the vehicle however I did not observe the keys.   The vehicles condition was captured on my BWC.  The registered owner was notified and responded to take possession of the vehicle.     Upon receiving possession of the vehicle the owner stated that the following listed items did not belong to him;tie-dye hair wear kit-OGX coconut Conditioner-OGX Coconut Shampoo-2 Pack Dove Original bar soap-2 Pack Dove Sensitive skin soap-Dove Deodorant Stick-twin pack dove dry spray deodorant-3 pack Bic razors "Flex 4"-2 instax mini Fugi film-1 "Milk and Honey" book-1  pair of grey scissors-1 1 steak knife-1 up&up pore strips-1 16oz Cetaphil facial cleanser - 1 Duralast jump pack/air compressor (serial #94030174 00 ms 2140 00541)I was advised by Sgt. Ziegelhofer to secure all items that did not belong to the owner of the vehicle.  Unknown value of the recovered items.  All items were secured in Evidence Locker # 5.
Vehicle recovered by PO Marble. All alerts were cleared and RO was notified.

column2: Receiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7Recovered Stolen VehicleJuvenile Complaint (Criminal)
column13: On Tuesday, January 31st at approximately 16:43 hours, P.O. McCarthy and I were dispatched to the listed location of 360 Essex Street on a report of a located stolen auto. While en route to the area, dispatch advised that the possible stolen vehicle, a black Honda CRV, which was stolen last week was now in the area of the Popeyes (Essex & Prospect). Upon approaching the intersection westbound on Essex in unmarked RC 138, I observed the possible vehicle traveling northbound on Prospect Avenue, followed by another black colored SUV bearing NJ Temp tag X884534, which dispatch confirmed was the complainant (registered owner's son). Once I was able to observe the registration on the CVR, it was confirmed that the vehicle was stolen and had been entered into NCIC. I continued to follow the vehicle northbound on Prospect Avenue before turning west on American Legion, then northbound on Summit Avenue. As I await an additional unit prior to activating my emergency lights, the said stolen vehicle then made a right hand turn eastbound on Central Avenue, then southbound on Prospect Avenue, before finally turning right onto American Legion west.      I activated my emergency lights (no visible traffic or pedestrians) and conducted a motor vehicle stop. As I exited my RC, I un-holstered my duty issued firearm, which was pointed downward at the ground and concealed behind my right thigh as I ordered the driver, a unknown Black male, to place the vehicle into park and show me his hands. Once the vehicle was in park, I opened the driver's side door, physically removing the unknown suspect from the driver's seat and placing him up against the exterior of the vehicle, while P.O. McCarthy placed him in handcuffs (behind his back). A search incident to arrest was conducted, which yielded negative results. The suspect was immediately uncooperative and refused to provide his name or age, other than stating "I'm under 18 and I know my rights, been to your headquarters plenty of times." Based on the belief that the suspect was indeed an juvenile, no further investigative questions were asked on scene and his was placed in the rear of RC 118 for transport to headquarters.   P.O. Rios remained on scene with the recovered stolen auto, the complainant and registered owner; see his supplement report to original OCA 23-008341 for further.  Once at headquarters, the juvenile suspect remained uncooperative and was turned over to Detective Katsaroans pending criminal complaints. He was ultimately identified as N.N. (age 16). See Detective Katsaroans supplement for further.

P.O. Dogali and I responded to 417 Maple Hill Drive for a suspicious incident. Upon arrival we met with the complainant who reported at 02:45 hours, that two unknown males attempted to open her vehicles car doors. The complainant showed us a RING doorbell video which depicts two unknown males wearing hooded sweatshirts approach her vehicle in her driveway, pull the door handle (which was locked), and walk away. The video then showed the two males approach her second car parked directly in front of her house, pull the door handle and walk away. No damage was observed to the vehicles and the doors were locked. The complainant wanted to have this incident documented.  The complainant was advised to send the video footage to P.O. Dogali's department e-mail address.

P.O. Dogali and I responded to 421 West Anderson Street for a suspicious incident.  Upon arrival, we met with the complainant who reported a suspicious incident that at 01:47 hours.  She reported that two unknown males (one wearing a dark hooded sweat shirt and one wearing a light colored sweat shirt) attempted to open her car which was parked in front of her house. The complainant showed us RING camera video footage of the two unknown parties pulling the door handle on her vehicle. The video of the RING camera footage was sent to P.O. Dogali's Hackensack Police Department e-mail. There was no damage to the vehicle.  The video footage was forwarded to REMU and Detectives.

I responded to the listed location for a suspicious incident. Upon my arrival, I spoke with the complainant who stated the alarm on the forklift started going off at 17:15 and the ignition on the machine was tampered with. The complainant further stated the forklift is no longer working because a piece of metal is logged in the ignition and can not be removed without taking the ignition apart. The approximate cost to fix the machine is $400.00. The forklift serial #B974V01694N)      The complainant informed the security cameras for the location are not operational at this time. I asked the complainant about having the forklift processed and he declined.      At this time the suspect is unknown. If the suspect is identified the complainant wishes to file charges.

On February 15, 2023 P.O. Rodriguez and I were dispatched to 295 Washington Avenue on a report of a welfare check. I was advised by Headquarters that Albana Maliqi who is a school administrator for Bergen Arts and Science Charter School contacted them in reference to this incident. She stated that Anthony Garcia who is a student at the school rushed out of school this morning stating that he believed his brother D.G. had a gun to his head and that he needed to see him. She also provided the address of the family which was 295 Washington Avenue.Upon arrival , I was met by the victim D.G and his baby sitter Carmita Altamiran at the home. D.G. stated that he was walking in the area of Main Street near the restaurant Pollo Mario at approximately 08:45 hours when the suspect approached him. The suspect was described as a black male in his 40's with a beard wearing a black bubble jacket and a black beanie. He was also approximately 5'8 in height with a possible tattoo on his neck.At this time the suspect demanded the victim to hand over all of his belongings to him. The victim stated that the suspect told him this multiple times before he began to lift the bottom of his jacket. Once the suspect began this motion, the victim immediately began running away from the location. Let it be noted that the victim did not observe a weapon of any kind during this incident. The victim was able to run to the Pizza Hut located at 53-55 Essex Street where his older brother Anthony picked him up and brought him home.P.O. Rodriguez spoke with Ms. Altamiran who stated that she was baby sitting D.G today while his parents were working since he was suspended from school today. Ms. Altamiran advised us that D.G. snuck out of the home without her noticing. While on scene, D.G's father Jorge Garcia-Vega arrived home and we advised him of the situation.Sgt. Meneses along with Detectives Antista and Mora responded on scene to conduct their investigation. While speaking with Mr. Garcia-Vega, he refused to provide a recorded statement at this time and only wanted the incident documented. A victim notification form was completed and a copy was provided to him. Once at Headquarters a Handle with Care form was also completed in reference to D.G.
Vehicle was recovered by NYPD 46th precinct 718-220-5210 Voucher #200108748.Vehicle was cleared from NCIC and RO was notified Nic/V744783918

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleReceiving Stolen Property  2C:20-7CDS/Possession: Influence  2C:35-10
column13: On February 26, 2023, at approximately 02:00 hours I responded to 170 Prospect Avenue, to assist in setting up an exterior perimeter. The purpose in setting up this perimeter was to contain the suspect Reggie Scott, who was observed by security staff breaking into parked vehicles in the parking garage. P.O. Farhi entered the parking garage with P.O. Alvarez in an attempt to apprehend Reggie Scott. P.O. Farhi broadcasted over the police radio that he was in a foot pursuit with the suspect, Reggie Scott. P.O. Farhi stated Scott was running through the parking garage, headed towards American Legion Drive. I responded to the north side driveway of 170 Prospect Avenue, and observed Scott, running north towards American Legion Drive. I immediately exited my patrol vehicle and ordered Scott multiple times to stop, to which he failed to comply.     Scott attempted to jump over a fence, but failed and began to run back toward my direction.  At this time I was able to use a take down technique to bring Scott to the ground and handcuff him with his hands behind his back. Scott was advised he was under arrest and searched incident to arrest. I verbally read Scott his Miranda warnings out loud, which he stated he understood and was captured on BWC. On Scott I located United States Currency ($300), a single cigarette, and a lighter. Scott was asked where he obtained the money from. Scott stated he took money from the Jeep, along with a lighter and a single cigarette. Scott then uttered out loud that his girlfriend was waiting nearby in a vehicle for him and that's why he ran.  Other officers responded, and I remained with Scott until he was transported to Hackensack University Medical Center. See P.O. Farhi's report for further.      Following Scott's transportation, I conducted a search of the immediate area for any evidence or other burglarized vehicles. While searching the exterior north side of the parking garage of 170 Prospect Avenue, I observed a female party sitting in the passenger seat of a black Toyota Camry bearing New Jersey Registration (XKYP41).  Believing this could be Scott's girlfriend, I made contact with the female party who was later identified as the arrestee, Ebony Peak. Sgt. Dalton and P.O. Lyak responded to assist. I asked Peak who owned the vehicle, which she stated she was unsure. I further asked her the reason why she was sitting inside the vehicle, which she could not explain. A computer check of the registration of the vehicle was conducted with headquarters, which reveled the license plate to be confirmed stolen, NIC/P618133544 from South Hackensack. A computer check of the vehicle's public identification number 4T1C11AK8MU562724, was conducted with headquarters, which reveled the vehicle to be confirmed stolen NIC/V274776802 from the City of Hackensack                          (see OCA 23-17036).      Peak was removed from the vehicle and I placed her in handcuffs behind her back. A search incident to arrest reveled (3) three blue pills stamped 30, suspected to be oxycodone, which was located inside of her jacket. A search of the vehicle was conducted, which reveled the following.1. Two (2) New York license plates (KLA1137) - Belonging to the stolen vehicle2. A black metal crow bar located on the passenger side door3. A wallet with an identification card belonging to Reggie Scott 4.. In the wallet with Scott's ID were two credit cards: Chase Freedom Visa 4158987183742668 issued to Simon MontaquizaSears credit card 5049940230238874 issued to Claire Walkin. 5. A Citizen Ero Drive watch with a black leather band 6. 2 Stolen license plates New Jersey Registration (XKYP41)    Headquarters was notified to have a tow respond. Tumino's Tow responded and removed the vehicle. The stolen license plates were removed from the vehicle.             The evidence was secured in radio car 116 and transported to headquarters. The black metal crow bar, Chase Freedom Visa card, Sears credit card, Citizen Ero drive watch, and the two (2) stolen New Jersey license plates were placed into evidence locker number 5.      At headquarters Peak was fingerprinted, processed, and photographed. Sgt. Dalton authored complaint number S 0223 000098 0223 against Peak for the listed charges.1.2C:35-10A(1) 2.2C:5-53.2C:20-7 (2) counts     All use of force reports were completed.    Peak was released on the summons with a pending court date of 03/13/2023 at 8:30 am.
column14: The evidence was secured in radio car 116 and transported to headquarters. The black metal crow bar, Chase Freedom Visa card, Sears credit card, Citizen Ero drive watch, and the two (2) stolen New Jersey license plates were placed into evidence locker number 5.      At headquarters Peak was fingerprinted, processed, and photographed. Sgt. Dalton authored complaint number S 0223 000098 0223 against Peak for the listed charges.1.2C:35-10A(1) 2.2C:5-53.2C:20-7 (2) counts     All use of force reports were completed.    Peak was released on the summons with a pending court date of 03/13/2023 at 8:30 am.

column13: I recovered the listed stolen vehicle at 170 Prospect Avenue,  which was reported stolen out our jurisdiction. For further see report number 23-019027A.

On Thursday, March 2, 2023 at approximately 1319 hours, the complainant responded to police headquarters to report a suspicious incident that occurred at an earlier time on this date.      The complainant reported that at approximately 0930 hours this morning, she called her "AOL" service provider to inform them of her PC being hacked. At that time, she was assisted by the suspect, who the complainant found to be suspicious when questioned about her bank account information. The suspect then advised that the complainant's PC had been hacked, and was recently used to view "child pornography" and other pornographic web sites at approximately 0400 hours on this date.          To be noted, that the complainant stated that she did not provide any of her bank information to the suspect. The complainant advised that she had not observed any fraudulent activities to any of her accounts at the time this report was taken.     The complainant wished to have the incident documented and was advised how to obtain a copy of this report.

I responded to the listed location on report of a suspicious phone call. Upon my arrival I met with the complainant who reported that on 3/3/23 at about 1330 hours she received a phone call from the a party claiming to be from Amazon asking if she purchased a phone for $999.99. When the complainant said she did not the caller transferred her to the suspect who claimed to be from the Federal Trade Commission. Believing that the suspect's identity was legitimate, the complainant text him a picture of her drivers license, she also informed the suspect that she has 3 bank accounts at Lakeland Bank.     The suspect continued a charade that the complainant was involved in money laundering and multiple cases of fraud and in order to be cleared she would have to send $30,000.00 in cash to Florida (no specific address was provided). The complainant then went to Lakeland Bank located at 9 Polifly Road and with the suspect still on the line attempted to take out $30,000.00 between her two checking accounts. The bank informed her that a withdraw of that amount who have to be requested ahead of time and that they could not complete her request. The complainant then left the bank and was told by the suspect that today at 0900 hours he would contact her again for her to take out the funds and ship them in a magazine via UPS.      I advised the complainant not to answer any further calls from the suspect, to monitor her credit report for unauthorized accounts and to verify with her bank that nothing was withdrawn or checks cashed/written from her accounts.      Suspect was not able to successfully get any money from the complainant .

While on patrol in the area of Camden Street traveling west from Main Street, I observed a white Kia Optima parked in the rear of 277 Main Street.  I am aware of a white Kia Optima being stolen from our jurisdiction over the weekend and pulled into the parking lot to check the registration.  The vehicle I observed is the vehicle that was reported stolen, NJ J84KTT.  The vehicle was parked facing west in the parking lot of 275/277 Main Street.  The vehicle does not have the keys with it and both license plates are on the vehicle.  The vehicles condition was captured on my BWC.  The owner and complainant were both contacted several times with negative results and were unable to be notified that their vehicle was located.  All-Points Towing was notified, responded and removed the vehicle.  See Tow Report for further.

On Friday, March 17, 2023 at approximately 0902 hours, P.O. Competiello and I responded to the intersection if Euclid Avenue and Main Street on a recovered stolen vehicle. P.O. Estrada and P.O. Caneja responded to assist. Upon arrival, we spoke with Leon Mcfadden (Registered Owner) who reported that he forgot where he parked his vehicle on 3/16/2023, which lead him to believe the vehicle was stolen. The vehicle was reported stolen to the Englewood Police Department. We confirmed he was the registered owner of the silver Cadillac CTS bearing New Jersey registration U14HRE. The listed vehicle was incorrectly reported stolen. Englewood PD was advised of our findings.

On this date I was conducting a check of Newmen Street specifically the area of202 Essex Street (7-Eleven). While driving through the parking lot my attention was drawn to vehicle 1 which was manually being pushed into a parking space by E.G. I also observed a b/m sitting in the driver seat. As I got closer to the vehicle I was able to identify the driver from previous incidents as I.M. While speaking with E.G. as to why he was pushing vehicle 1 he stated his friend, pointing to I.M.,ran out of fuel and he was helping him push the car in a space. At this time I conducted an NCIC check of vehicle 1's registration, which reveled vehicle 1 was reported stolen from Lodi, NJ on this date. Headquarters was advised of my location, and dispatched units to assist. During my radio transmission my attention was drawn to I.M., who know became nervousto my presence. I.M. then exited the vehicle holding a set of car keys and was quickly trying to walk away shouting, "I going upstairs to get my mother." Knowing that I.M. does not reside on Newmen Street  (Colt Arms Apartments), I shouted to him in a calm voice to come back over to the vehicle, so I can help you secure the car. I stated this to I.M. while I was waiting for back up to arrive and I did not want to alert him that I knew the vehicle was stolen. Also standing next to me was E.G. who was also telling I.M. to return. As I.M. came within arms reach of me I grabbed both juveniles by their jacket sleeves and escorted them to my marked unit.   While still on scene awaiting back up to arrive, I.M. broke free of my grip and fled on foot Northbound on Newman Street out of sight. Headquarters was advised and had additional units canvass the area. E.G. remained on scene and was secured in the rear of my vehicle. While seated in the rear of my vehicle, E.G. uttered, "Was that car stolen, I just came out of 7-Eleven and I.M. was there."   Headquarters advised that registered owner does not wish for the vehicle to be processed. I requested the on-call duty tow respond for the recovery. Sgt. Meneses arrived on scene to assist.  I transported E.G. to police headquarters followed by P.O. Sheikh for short term custody. At headquarters, E.G.'s mother,  Everhart McMillan, was contacted to respond.  McMillan arrived within minuets. A copy of  McMillan's driver license was taken, and a short term custody report was completed.  McMillan at this time denied E.G. to speak with detectives in regards to the incident. Detective Antista was contacted and advised. E.G. was turned over to his mother without further incident, investigation to continue.

On Wednesday, March 22, 2023, while on patrol in marked radio car #104, I was flagged down at approximately 0552 hours, in the area of Essex/Union by a female, later identified as Rosario ELIZONDO SOLIS. ELIZONDO SOLIS reported she was walking East on Essex Street, to the bus stop located near 100 Essex Street, when she felt a male suspect attempt to grab her Adidas backpack, which contained her credit cards and other personal belongings. ELIZONDO SOLIS shouted at the suspect, "Hey, hey!" At that point, the male suspect was startled and ran East on Essex Street prior to ELIZONDO SOLIS losing sight of the male suspect as he proceeded North on Union Street.  The victim did not report the suspect using any type of force or make any threats.                     ELIZONDO SOLIS reported the area near the the bus stop is poorly lit and does not contain street lights. ELIZONDO SOLIS described the suspect as Hispanic male, 5'03'', 40 years of age, wearing a blue hooded sweatshirt and glasses. No further description was able to be provided. ELIZONDO SOLIS reported that no proceeds were taken nor was she injured during the incident.ELIZONDO SOLIS reported that she would be able to identify the suspect and was willing to sign complaints.           Sgt. Swetits was apprised. I checked the area thereafter with negative results for the suspect.  Sgt. Tripodi was notified.

This operator received a call from NYPD PO Ubben #22865 inquiring on a vehicle from us in NCIC as stolen.  Verbal confirmation was provided awaiting a NCIC Hit Confirmation.  We received a Hit Confirmation Request from NYPD Interoffice Correspondence Unit.  This operator confirmed the vehicle as stolen and received an NCIC Locate.  Vehicle is secured at NYPD PSA7 Headquarters 737 Melrose Avenue Bronx, New York.  Contact number is 718-292-6161 extension 0/  Their message file number is 3059.  The voucher number for the vehicle is 2001219011.

On April 12, 2023, at approximately 1822 hours, Det. Dominguez and I responded to the parking lot of 400 Hackensack Avenue (in front of the Cheesecake Factory) to assist Lt. Briggs with a suspected stolen vehicle. The vehicle Lt. Briggs located is a 2020 dark blue colored Mercedes Benz G550. Lt. Briggs advised me that while on patrol in fully marked police uniform, he observed the vehicle parked in the parking lot unoccupied bearing a New Jersey 30-Day Non-Resident Temporary Plate 609415T. While verifying the information on the temporary registration, he discovered no return on the listed VIN W1NYC6BJ6LX345718. He believed the vehicle was possibly stolen and re VINed. He inputted the VIN into a computerized commercial database and discovered a suspicious vehicle history. He also advised me that based on his education, training, and experience he knew how to interpret the vehicle history as fraudulent, and where to locate the correct VIN for the specific vehicle model.          Lt. Briggs located the original factory VIN W1NYC6BJ8LX345414 on the exterior of the vehicle. I observed the original VIN as well. An NCIC inquiry of VIN W1NYC6BJ8LX345414 via Hackensack Police Communications revealed the vehicle to be a stolen vehicle reported out of Southhampton Town Police Department. The date of entry is 02/13/2020 and the NIC number is #V001774813. Communications made notification to the originating agency.       While on scene, the vehicle's owner responded to the vehicle. I spoke with the owner and he was advised the reason for a law enforcement presence. He provided a United States Passport and was identified as Carey Robertson (DOB 05/19/1975, ROBERTSON hereafter). ROBERTSON was advised that the vehicle was confirmed to be stolen and re VINed. I asked ROBERTSON where the vehicle was purchased, and he reported it was purchased at a dealership in Queens. He could not provide the name of the dealership. He further reported that he obtained the vehicle through a "friend of a friend" who provided him with what he believed was Mercedes-Benz Certified Vehicle paperwork. ROBERTSON reported to Det. Dominguez that he also traded a Cadillac Escalade as part of his vehicle purchase. He reported that he makes payments on the vehicle and the payments are approximately $2,000.00 USC per month. ROBERTSON was advised that the vehicle was going to be impounded due to being confirmed stolen.     After further speaking with ROBERTSON on scene, I did not believe ROBERTSON was aware of the vehicle being stolen and re VINed. It could not be confirmed at this time that ROBERTSON knowingly received stolen property. ROBERTSON was provided our office extension number. ROBERTSON provided us with the key fob, gathered his belongings, and left the scene.      The vehicle was transported to Headquarters by Tumino's Towing. Lt. Briggs photographed all four sides of the vehicle, the public VIN, and the federal certification label.  He removed all fictitious VINs from the vehicle.  The vehicle was secured in the Old Police Garage, pending appropriate insurance company, and dealership notifications. The single key fob was secured in the Crime Suppression Bureau office during this time.      Fraudulent VIN stickers were recovered as evidence. See Evidence Report.            See Tow Report.

On April 13, 2023, at approximately 1837 hours, the complainant, Stuart Sherer, responded to Hackensack Police Department Headquarters to report a fraud. The complainant reported that at approximately 1000 hours today, he received a notification on his computer stating his computer has been hacked and to contact Microsoft at the following number: (602) 962-5355. The complainant reported he contacted the number and spoke with a male representative who told him his bank account and phone has been hacked through a gambling organization. He further reported that the male representative told him to get gift cards in the amount of $2,000.00 and he would give him instructions to follow. The complainant reported that while he was at shop rite buying the gift cards he realized that it was a scam and did not buy the gift cards.         The complainant was advised to notify his bank of the incident.        Sgt. Detective Tripodi was notified and advised he would be following up with the complainant for further.

column2: Motor Vehicle StopMotor Vehicle ImpoundRecovered Stolen License Plate
column13: While on patrol in the area of Essex Street/Newman Street in marked R/C 104 I observed a vehicle bearing NY/KWZ6508 double parked. A computer inquiry was conducted for the aforementioned registration which came back as stolen. I requested headquarters to conduct an NCIC check to verify the information for the listed registration. While waiting for headquarters return the listed vehicle drove east on Essex Street and into the McDonald's parking lot (193 Essex). Headquarters verified the license plates of the vehicle were reported stolen at which time a motor vehicle stop was conducted. Moments later P.O. Debonis responded to assist.        I spoke to the driver of the listed vehicle (Yem Wadnipar Contreras) who reported he had bought the vehicle approximately (1) month ago from, Ismail Gomez Lucena, who allowed him to take the vehicle with the license plates when he initially purchased the vehicle. He further stated he did not have a valid driver's license and the vehicle was uninsured. A tow was requested for the listed vehicle, Moments later All Points Towing responded and removed the vehicle from the property. (2) license plates were removed from the vehicle, transported to head quarters and placed in the traffic box. A computer inquiry revealed there were no other license plates registered to this vehicle. Mr. Contreras was issued the following summons:-39:3-10 Driving without a license-39:6B-2 No liability insurance on motor vehicle-39:3-4 Driving or parking unregistered motor vehicle.

On this date P.O. Estrada and I were dispatched to the listed address on a report of a car theft in progress. Upon arrival we met with the vehicle's owner (victim). The vehicle was parked on Anderson Street facing West. The victim stated that the vehicle had been moved to the West approximately 10 feet. A key was also observed in the vehicle's ignition. The victim believes that the key may be an old key, that can start the vehicle but will not allow the vehicle to be moved when placed in drive. The victim stated that he has had new keys programed to the vehicle in the past, making the key in the ignition obsolete. The victim did not wish to have the vehicle processed. The victim also stated that nothing appears to be missing from the vehicle and that the key found in the ignition may have been in the vehicle. He does not remember if he had locked the vehicle or not.    A Ring doorbell and security camera was observed at 450 West Anderson and a Ring doorbell was observed at 458 West Anderson.    Sgt. Capone was advised.    A NJ Victim Notification Form was completed and provided to the victim. The victim will sign complaints if the suspect(s) can be identified.

On Thursday, June 15, 2023 at approximately 0717 hours, I responded to 478 Washington Avenue on a reported criminal mischief. Upon arrival, I met with the victim who reported that she parked the listed vehicle facing north in front of the 494 Washington Avenue. She further reported that upon returning to the vehicle at approximately 0612 hours, damage to the front-driver side door handle was observed. Sgt. Williams responded to assist.     I noticed that there was damage to the key hole mechanism of that door handle with it's cap cover displaced. It appeared that the suspect had attempted to force entry to the vehicle but was unsuccessful. The victim stated that there was no other damage to the vehicle. She also stated that nothing appeared to be stolen or out of place within the vehicle. There were no other parked vehicles in the immediate vicinity that appeared to be burglarized. I observed a doorbell camera on the residence of 494 Washington Avenue, where the vehicle was parked. It is unknown at the time of this report if that camera was operational and captured the incident. There were no known suspect(s) at the time this report was taken.     The victim stated the approximate cost to repair the damages to the car door handle is $300.00. The victim was advised that the incident would be documented and how to obtain a copy of this report. A Victim Notification Form was completed and a copy was given to the victim.     To be noted, the scene was unable to be processed due to evidence being contaminated by the victim's husband who moved the vehicle prior to my arrival.     Vehicle insurance information: Geico / Policy # 4534-48-95-64 / Code # 100 / expire 09/12/23

Sgt. Dalton, P.O. Koenig and I responded to 199 Russell Place (HackensackUMC EMS Headquarters) for a suspicious male. The witness, an Emergency Medical Technician for HackensackUMC EMS, called the Hackensack Police Department when she observed the suspect walk into the EMS headquarters parking lot, which is surrounded by perimeter fencing, and attempt to gain entry into the building. Upon my arrival, I met with the witness as Sgt. Dalton and P.O. Koenig searched the surrounding area for the suspect.      The witness stated she was sitting in an ambulance which was parked in the headquarters parking lot. While sitting in the ambulance, she observed an unknown Asian male (suspect), who appeared to be in his twenties and was five feet five inches in height with a skinny build, enter the parking lot. The suspect was wearing a gray hat, grayish/blueish hooded sweatshirt, blue jeans and had a red duffle bag. After entering the parking lot, he walked up to a white Toyota Camry, bearing NJ / R47SBR, and attempting to open the driver door, but the vehicle was locked. He proceeded to the door to the ALS area and attempted to open the door, but it was also locked. Following the attempt to open the door to the ALS area, the suspect then attempted to open the locked door to the main area of the EMS headquarters, but was unsuccessful.      The witness exited the ambulance causing the suspect to see her and run from the parking lot. The witness observed the suspect attempt to open the rear door of 52 First Street (Hackensack Digestive Disease Associates) after fleeing the parking lot, but was unsuccessful in his attempts. The suspect then fled north on First Street and the witness lost sight of him.      Sgt. Dalton and P.O. Koenig were unable to locate the suspect at this time. Paramedic Supervisor Tito Rodriguez responded and stated he advised the owner of the Toyota Camry of the incident. Paramedic Anna Simmons, who's husband owns the Toyota Camry and was in possession of the vehicle, stated no damage was observed to the vehicle at this time. It was unknown at this time if HackensackUMC wanted to pursue complaints against the suspect if identified. Paramedic Simmons did not wish to pursue complaints at this time.

I responded to 380 W Pleasantview Ave on a report of Criminal Mischief. Upon arrival, I was met with the complainant. He stated that he parked his rental vehicle at 03:00 hours at the parking lot of the  above mentioned address and when he returned to his vehicle at 08:00 hours, he noticed that the rear right window of the vehicle was shattered. He also noticed that the plastic cover by the ignition/steering wheel area was removed, suspecting that the burglar attempted to steal the vehicle. There were no unknown objects or tools inside the vehicle. Nothing was missing or taken from inside the vehicle. He stated that the cost of the damages possibly range between $300 and $800. He contacted the rental company Enterprise and advised them of the incident. Enterprise did not want the vehicle processed. The vehicle is self insured. I was unable to view camera footage of the incident at this time. Sgt. Meneses was on scene.

P.O. Miller and I responded to the area of Central Ave and First Street on a report of a possible stolen vehicle in that area. Detective Sgt. Hampton from Hillsdale PD stated that ALPR located the stolen vehicle in the above mentioned area. The vehicle is a red 2014 Mercedes Benz CLA, NJ Reg L60NXJ. Upon arrival, we canvassed the area. I located the stolen vehicle at approximately 10:30, parked in front of 102 First Street facing north. The vehicle was turned off and unoccupied. After checking the license plate, I confirmed that the vehicle was stolen. I was unable to locate any keys inside of the vehicle. A bystander stated that that he saw 3 black juveniles exit the stolen vehicle and walk north on First Street several minutes prior to my arrival. No further description was given. Detective Sgt. Hampton arrived on scene. He stated that the owner of the vehicle wanted the vehicle processed. All Points Towing arrived on scene and towed the vehicle to BCI for processing.

On Friday, June 30, 2023 at approximately 0900 hours, I responded to 55 State Street (Walsh & Walsh Esqs. LLC) on report of fraud.      Upon arrival, I met with the complainant, who is also the legal secretary of the establishment. The complainant reported that she submitted a $45,000.00 check through mail on the date of 06/22/2023, which she believed was intercepted at some point during transit. The complainant further reported that she received a call from TD Bank on yesterday's date 06/29/2023, advising that there was an attempt made to deposit that check into a TD bank account. TD Bank advised the complainant that all funds were withheld due to suspicion of fraudulent activity.           The complainant provided a copy of the fraudulent check, in which the payee's name and address were altered from the original. A fraud packet had been completed by the complainant in regards to the incident. All funds that were withheld by TD Bank are in the process of being returned to the company's primary bank (M & T Bank).      To be noted, no monetary loss was suffered by the listed establishment at the time this report was taken.

While on Patrol in radio car #141, I was traveling North on South State Street near the intersection of Essex Street.   I got a LPR hit for the listed vehicle (traveling South on South State Street) as being stolen.  I confirmed the hit in NCIC and attempted to catch up to the vehicle.  The vehicle was located parked, unoccupied, on the corner of English Street and South State Street.  Detective Dominguez and Detective Rios responded to my location in an unmarked police vehicle and we began surveillance on the vehicle.  Detective Rios observed a Hispanic male (Later Identified as the registered owner) enter the vehicle and began West on English Street.  I conducted a motor vehicle stop, which revealed that the driver of the vehicle was in fact the registered owner.  He advised that he reported the vehicle stolen in Queens NY when his vehicle was repossessed.  He further stated that he advised the precinct however it was never removed from NCIC.

On July 1, 2023 I responded to 133 Ross Avenue on a report of a criminal mischief to an auto. Upon arrival, I met with the victim who advised me that his 2022 Honda Accord was damaged by someone attempting to burglarize it. This morning when walking to his vehicle he discovered damage to the key mechanism of the driver side door. The cover was popped off and the key mechanism was pushed into the vehicle. The victim entered his vehicle and advised me that all his items nothing was taken. The victim stated he has a ring camera on his home but did not catch the incident due to his bushes obstructing it. The vehicle was parked in front of his home on Ross Avenue pointing east. Sgt. Briggs responded on scene shortly after.The victim provided me with all necessary vehicle information consisting of the registration and insurance (#26252267). A victim notification form was completed and a copy was provided to the victim. I advised the victim a report would be generated and that Detectives would be following up in the near future.

On Wednesday, July 5th, 2023, P.O. Koenig and I responded to 170 South Park Street to locate a possible stolen vehicle. The vehicle is a Green 2019 Toyota RAV4, NJ Reg A57RNM. Upon arrival, we canvassed the area. I located the stolen vehicle at approximately 06:47, parked by the dumpster on the northeast side of the building. The vehicle was turned off, ignition intact and unoccupied. After checking the license plate, I confirmed that the vehicle was stolen. P.O. Koenig was unable to locate any keys inside the vehicle. Headquarters advised that the owner of the vehicle wanted the vehicle processed. Tumino's Towing arrived and towed the vehicle to BCI for processing. See tow report.
Vehicle cleared out of NCIC Nic/485120251

The listed vehicle was parked facing north in front of 346 The Esplanade, in violation of the street cleaning ordinance, 170-8.  The vehicle was bearing NJ Registration B52RHR which revealed "No Record Found."  An NCIC check of the public VIN revealed it was a stolen vehicle out of Jersey City.  The VIN shows that NJ Registration of L11PJK belong on this vehicle, however, they were not recovered with the vehicle.   Police Headquarters was advised and confirmed the NCIC hit with Jersey City Police Department.         Both fictitious B52RHR license plates were removed from the vehicle and secured in the Traffic Bureau.  Court House Auto Body was notified, responded and removed the vehicle.  The vehicles overall condition was captured on my BWC.  See Tow Report and Evidence Report for further.

On Sunday, 07/09/2023, I was patrolling the area in assigned radio car #111 with P.O. Small. While patrolling the area of Kenneth Street near the intersection of Mary Street, I observed vehicle 1 bearing Florida license plate QZUD63 parked on Kenneth Street facing north. The vehicles gas cap was unsecured and damaged. A computer search of the vehicle yielded that it was stolen out of Rutherford, NJ. Communications confirmed the Stolen HIT and attempted to contact the registered owner. The registered owner could not be reached. The vehicle doors were unsecured. The vehicle yielded negative forkeys. Only one (1) license plate was on rear of the vehicle. The vehicle cost is unknown at this time. We observed a surveillance camera on the southwest corner of 185-195 Kenneth Street. See TOW report.  The registered owner contacted Headquarters and was advised how to retrieve their vehicle.

On July 18, 2023, at approximately 0946 hours, I responded to 233 Hamilton Place for a report of an abandoned auto. Upon my arrival, I observed a Black Hyundai Elantra bearing NJ-E49RTJ parked facing East on Hamilton Avenue, in front of 233 Hamilton Place.  I observed the driver side window to be down, rear driver side window to be smashed, and the ignition was tampered/altered. A computer search of the vehicle resulted in it being stolen out of Newark, New Jersey.       Sgt. Dalton responded. Communications confirmed the vehicle to be stolen out of Newark, New Jersey. Newark Police Department reported they did not want the vehicle processed. Sgt. Dalton and I did a search of the vehicle which resulted in negative for contraband/weapons.       Tumino's Towing responded and removed the vehicle from the roadway. See Tow Report.

column2: Suspicious PersonCriminal Attempt  2C:5-1Hindering Apprehension  2C:29-3
column13: Sgt. Williams , PO Garrett and I responded to the listed location.  Upon arrival, we spoke  to the suspect who stated that he was walking home when he was approached by the witness. The suspect explained to us that he was homeless and that he was walking around before he found somewhere to sleep. We  were approached by the witness who stated to us that he had witnessed the suspect walking up and down different driveways on Allen Street, the witness then saw the suspect pulling on  the car door of a Honda Odyssey, bearing NJ C17PWW. When the suspect noticed the witness, the suspect hid behind the vehicle.  At this point we arrived on scene. When I asked the suspect what he was doing  he stated that he was innocent and that none of that had happened. I then spoke to the victim which immediately went to check his vehicle. The victim stated that his vehicle was secure and that there was nothing missing. The suspect was then placed under arrest and taken to police headquarters without further incident.  A victim notification form was filled and given to the witness. The suspect was charged with Criminal intent 2C:5-1. At headquarters the suspect was processed under a false name that was provided by the suspect. The suspect had provided a name and date of birth of  Bernando Quoroz, 11/01/1995 the suspects real name is Hernando Garcia Morales date of birth 11/01/1985. The suspect also had a outstanding warrant for his arrest out of The Bergen County Sheriff Department for failure to appear. The suspect has been additional charged with Hindering 2C:29-3(7).

column2: Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Recovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: On Monday, August 14th, 2023, I responded to the listed address on a suspicious incident report. Upon arrival, I met with Leonard Gueye, the owner of Hook N Run Automotive. He reported that his worker, Rafael Gil, parked Vehicle 1 on Green Street on 08/11/2023, and when his employee arrived at approximately 08:00 hours today, the vehicle was missing from the parking lot.      He further reported receiving a phone call between the hours of 10:00 to 11:00 from Town Auto Mechanic at 152 Railroad Ave. regarding the missing vehicle being parked in front of the business. He also reported calling Police Headquarters to report the missing vehicle before receiving the phone call from the mechanic shop. I notified headquarters for a supervisor and Sgt. Swetits arrived on the scene.      I then spoke to Rafael Gil, the employee who parked Vehicle 1 on Green Street, via phone call. He reported that he parked vehicle 1 on Green Street at approximately 15:10 hours on 08/11/2023. He further reported that on 08/14/2023 at approximately 08:35 hours, the vehicle was nowhere to be found when he arrived at Green Street. He also reported that at approximately 08:50 hours, he called and notified Mr. Gueye that the vehicle was missing.     Mr. Gueye reported that after the call from the mechanic shop, he responded to the area and observed Vehicle 1 as the missing vehicle. Unfortunately, the complainant had been inside the vehicle before our arrival, which contaminated the ability to obtain fingerprints.     The complainant reported that a Hand Truck Dolly with an approximate value of $300.00 was missing from the back of the van. He also reported new damage to the passenger's side door and sliding door, with an estimated cost of $500.00Progressive Insurance. Policy Number: 0202516-5  Code:413The complainant would like to sign complaints if the suspect was to be identified. It should be noted that a camera located on the north side of the building may have captured who exited the vehicle.

column2: Forgery  2C:21-1Theft by Deception  2C:20-4Criminal Attempt  2C:5-1
column13: On August 17, 2023, P.O. Han, P.O. Lopez and I responded to TD Bank, 111 Main Street, on a report of two females attempting to cash a fraudulent check. Upon arrival, I met with the Complainant, Lilibeth R. Gomez, who is the Store Supervisor. The Complainant stated that the Suspect, Leslian Diaz Cruz, came in to the bank to open a new bank account. She further stated that the Suspect attempted to deposit a fraudulent check upon opening the new bank account. The Suspect was also with her 15 year old sister, E.V.C.             The Complainant stated that she thought that it was odd for a 18 year old from Hackensack to present a check to be deposited, a close to $6,000.00 of a check, from a school district in Ohio. The Complainant cross referenced the check in a system that they use for all checks and it resulted to be a fraudulent check.  The check (Check #399385) was issued by Kenton City School District, 222 W. Carroll Street, Kenton, Ohio 43326.  The check was in the amount of $5,960.00 and it was paid to the order of "Leslian Diaz Cruz, 264 Main Street, Hackensack, NJ 07601".              P.O. Han spoke to the Suspect who stated that she applied for a job via online using "Snag A Job". She went through an interview via text message and was instructed that she would be receiving a check to purchase the supplies she would need for the secretary position. The Suspect stated she received check in the mail along with an instruction letter.             The Suspect was instructed to deposit the check into her bank account and she would receive a $200.00 bonus.  She responded to TD Bank to open a new bank account because she did not have a bank account.              At this time, Sgt. Meneses responded and notified Det. Mora about the incident.  The Suspect was then placed under arrest for Forgery and Criminal Attempt with the underlying offense of Theft by Deception.  She was handcuffed with her hands behind her back.  I conducted a search incident to arrest which yielded negative result in finding any contraband.  She was transported in the rear seat of Radio Car #106.  The rear seat camera was activated during the transport.  The rear seat was checked prior to and upon arrival at Headquarters without finding any contraband.  P.O. Han was with me during the transport and P.O. Lopez followed.  P.O. Lopez also transported E.V.C., who was not in custody, in the rear seat of Radio Car #108 so that she can be turned over to the care of her aunt, Alejandra Polanco-Cruz.  E.V.C. was transported without incident.  Upon arrival at Headquarters, E.V.C. was not in a secured detention area and she was safely turned over to her aunt.  Juvenile Short Term Custody Report was also generated by P.O. Lopez.                            At Headquarters, I conducted a second search of the Arrestee which resulted negative findings of any contraband.  In addition, Det. Mora and I obtained statements from both the Complainant and Arrestee in the Detective Division's Interview Room.  See Det. Mora's Supplemental Report for further information.              I processed and photographed the Arrestee.  Complaint Summons #0223-S-2023-00442 was generated and signed against the Arrestee with the original charge of Forgery, 2C:21-1a(3) and Criminal Attempt, 2C:5-1a, with the underlying offense of Theft by Deception, 2C:20-4a.               The original fraudulent check and instruction letter were turned over to Det. Mora for further investigation.

On Sunday, August 20, 2023, at approximately 14:55 hours, I was on patrol in marked radio car #115 in the rear lot of 500 South River Street when I observed the listed vehicle (NJ/H66SES) parked facing north (unoccupied).  I conducted a computer inquiry of the vehicle's registration which yielded positive results for a stolen motor vehicle out of Hoboken, New Jersey.  I notified headquarters of my location and to confirm that the vehicle was stolen.  Headquarters confirmed that the vehicle was stolen.  I requested a supervisor and Sergeant Sean Briggs #273 responded.       Upon further inspection of the vehicle,  I observed that there was damage to the front and rear passenger side wheels.  The vehicle was possibly disabled.  Sgt. Briggs viewed the video surveillance footage from Hackensack Liquors.  At approximately 11:38 hours, on this date, a Hispanic male party and two female parties are seen exiting the vehicle and fled the scene running south in the parking lot of 500 South River Street.  The male party is seen again moments later return to the vehicle wiping the driver side door down with a towel.  I requested a tow truck and Court House Towing responded.  See Tow report for further information.  Vehicle Insurance information: Geico, #4292764828

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Stop
column13: On Monday, 08/29/2023, I was assigned with P.O. Caero, in radio car 104 on the quality of life detail. While on patrol in the area of Essex Street and Lehigh Street, driving east on Essex Street, I observed a white in color (UHAUL) rental van double parked on Lehigh Street facing south in violation of city ordnance 170-7(Prohibited Parking). I conducted a U turn in an attempt to issue the listed vehicle a summons for the offense. The driver of the listed vehicle then made a right turn onto Essex Street towards First Street. I was able to position my vehicle directly behind the listed vehicle. A computer lookup of the listed vehicle Arizona Registration (AL65930)  was conducted, which reveled the listed vehicle to be stolen out of New York City Police Department NCIC# V59532591, which was entered stolen on 08/24/2023.       A felony motor vehicle stop was conducted on Essex Street and Summit Avenue. Using the public announcement microphone, I ordered the driver to shut off the vehicle and to place both hands out the window, which he complied. I then ordered the driver out of the vehicle, which he complied. I advised the driver who was later identified as the arrestee, Onan Perez, he was being detained due to the vehicle being reported stolen. Headquarters confirmed the vehicle to be stolen. I advised headquarters to have a supervisor respond. Sgt. Swetits responded and was briefed. The arrestee was read out loud his MIranda warnings in Spanish by P.O. Caero, which he stated he understood each of his rights.              Headquarters was advised to have a tow respond to impound the vehicle.  search of the vehicle was conducted with negative results on contraband. The arrestee was placed in handcuffs behind his back and searched incident to arrest, with negative results for contraband. The arrestee was placed into the rear seat of radio car 104. Shortly after, the arrestee started to complain of difficulty breathing due to having a possible asthma attack. The arrestee was removed from the vehicle and uncuffed. The arrestee requested for his prescription asthma inhaler, which he was provided and used.       Sgt. Swetits advised headquarters for an ambulance to respond. Hackensack Ambulance # 1532 responded along with Hackensack ALS #101 and the Hackensack Fire Department. The arrestee was then transported to Hackensack University Medical Center for further treatment. P.O. Caero rode in the rear of the ambulance, while I followed from behind. P.O. Scangarella, stood by with the vehicle, which was impounded by Polifly Towing. The arrestee was then turned over to hospital staff with P.O. Caero.  At headquarters Sgt. Dalton approved complaint number 0223 S 000464 for 2C:20-7A. Summons number E 23 023172, 170-7 was also issued to the arrestee. The arrestee was served his defendants copy at Hackensack University Medical Center along with a CJP notice. He was advised on his court date of 09/11/2023 at 8:30 AM.

While on patrol, I observed vehicle 1 parked unoccupied facing eastbound in front of 233 Hamilton Place bearing a New York temporary plate ZJA1709 with an expiration date of 08/22 on a black 2022 Dodge Durango .  A check of the New York Temporary plate yielded that the temporary plate was reported stolen out of New York City on 09/05/2023.  I radioed to police headquarters and advised them of the findings and to confirm that the vehicle was stolen out of New York City.  While police headquarters were waiting on confirmation from New York City Police Department, I requested a tow truck to respond.  See New York City Police Department case number 2023-014-012007 for  further information.  At this time, Sgt. Briggs and P.O. Anguizaca responded to assist.  While waiting for  Tumino's Towing to respond, I issued the registered owner motor vehicle summons number H-962081 for 39:3-33.  Tumino's responded and towed the vehicle.  Police headquarters contacted the registered owner and notified him that his vehicle was recovered.  The vehicle was cleared from N.C.I.C as stolen.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleSearch Warrant Execution
column13: Det. Rios applied and was approved for a search warrant for the vehicle that I had impounded on 9/8/2023 for having a fictitious VIN.  On 9/15/2023 at approximately 1707 hours, Det. Rios, Det. Dominguez, and I executed the search warrant on the vehicle.  P.O. Rios photographed the vehicle prior to the search.  During the search, the real VIN (JTJYARBZ9J2104375) was discovered.  The real vin was confirmed to be stolen from Miramar Police Department in Florida on 2/9/2019.  The secondary VIN was found to be modified also.  I removed all fictitious VINs from the vehicle.  The vehicle was photographed by Det. Rios.  Also located was a bank receipt involving a $1922.00 cash deposit into a bank account.  No other items of evidentiary value were located in the vehicle.The vehicle was then impounded by Tumino's Towing (due to them being the original tow truck that impounded the vehicle).  All fictitious VINs were secured as evidence.  Crime Suppression Detectives will be submitting the search warrant receipt as well as a copy of the search warrant order to the original driver of the vehicle.  I secured all fictitious VIN stickers and the bank receipt in a white envelope, which I secured in evidence locker #7.The vehicle is now owned by WindHaven Insurance Company, who insured the vehicle at the time of the theft.  The approximate value of the vehicle is $32650.00.   I will be advising WindHaven Insurance of the recovery of the vehicle.Due to Raymier Mondesir titling the vehicle in his name using a fictitious title and bringing the vehicle to New Jersey, I generated complaint #0223W2023-000511 against Mondesir for violations of 2C:20-7a, 2C:17-6b, 2C:28-7a(1), 2C:20-10.1, and 2C:18-2B.  Based on the driver stating that the vehicle was a "gift" from her "husband, Ray," the title being applied for by Raymier Mondesir, as well as my previous interactions with Raymier Mondesir, I am not charging the driver at this time for possessing a stolen vehicle.Arrest to follow.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleLicense Plate-Lost/StolenNCIC Record
column13: Received a NCIC Hit Confirmation Request from Ridgefield Police for the stolen vehicle.  The NCIC Record was confirmed as active.  Ridgefield Police were advised to impound vehicle.  The license plate was not on the vehicle.Vehicle was towed to ABC Towing 1580 Route 46 Fort Lee, NJ 07024 (201-944-4383).  Owner will have to obtain a release from Ridgefield Police in order to retrieve his vehicle.The license plate that was on the vehicle at the time of theft was NJ/5KMZ8.  The plate was not recovered.The vehicle was removed from NCIC as a Stolen Vehicle and the license plate was entered into NCIC as stolen.Vehicle NIC# V225395960License Plate NIC# P368361673Unable to reach owner.  Voicemail not setup.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleSearch Warrant Execution
column13: On 9/21/2023, I prepared a search warrant application and search warrant affidavit for the impounded vehicle bearing New Jersey temporary tag Z526985 for having a fictitious VIN.  I contacted AP Karen Gwynn and advised her of the circumstances of the impound and application for the search warrant.  AP Gwynn was e-mailed the search warrant application as well as my affidavit.  On 9/22/2023, AP Seth Victor e-mailed me the search warrant which was approved by Judge James X. Sattely.               P.O. Almonte and I responded to 160 River Street to try to locate Mr. Dais to obtain the keys.  The concierge directed us to Apartment 412.  P.O. Almonte and I made contact with the resident of Apartment 412, Ashley Dais, who stated that the Land Rover belongs to her father, Oscar Dais.  Ashley Dais stated that her father's name is on her apartment lease and that he parks his Range Rover at the building due to him being on the lease.              P.O. Almonte and I responded to the vehicle to execute search warrant #JS-6602-BER-SW-23.  Photographs of the vehicle, registration, and fictitious VIN were taken beforehand with the patrol camera.  Court House Towing responded and made entry into the vehicle due to fact that I was unable to obtain the keys.  After opening the vehicle, we began the search.  I immediately identified the federal VIN sticker as fictitious.  I was able to peel the sticker off without the sticker self-destructing.  Photographs of the sticker were taken.  I then located the confidential VIN, which displayed SALWG2RU6KA863169.  The real VIN was confirmed to be stolen on 11/26/2022 in New York.  I then removed the public VIN in the windshield.  The original VIN was still in place.               P.O. Almonte and I searched the remainder of the vehicle.  In the upper left corner of the windshield was a Castrol oil change sticker with the plate "PA-MDX6255."  This license plate returns to McLeish through the Pennsylvania DMV. On the front passenger seat was a MCM women's purse.  In the center console I located a black Costco card with the name and photograph of Oscar Dais.  In the lower glove box, I located the temporary registration card and insurance card for the fictitious VIN, both in the name of Oscar Dais.  In the passenger door map compartment was a small bottle of Jimmy Choo "I want Choo" perfume bottle.  On the floor in the back seat was a claim paper and a w-9 with the name of Ayanna Dais.  Also on the floor was a black "Off-White" hooded sweatshirt.  In the trunk I located a pair of Jordan 7 GS "Hare" sneakers (304774-125) size 7Y.  All items were seized as evidence.               At the completion of the search, the vehicle was removed from the garage and impounded by Brookside Towing.                The vehicle was insured and now owned by Geico Insurance.  Geico paid out approximately $30,413.00 to the original owner from when the vehicle was stolen.                 I secured the following items as evidence in a brown paper bag:New Jersey temporary tag Z526985New Jersey temporary registration card for Z526985StateFarm insurance cardFictitious federal VIN stickerCastrol oil change stickerW-9 tax paperwork with the name Ayanna Zoe Dais (SSN #117903064)Arden Claims Service LLC settlement claim affirmation form with the name Ayanna DaisCostco card with name and photo Oscar Dais.The following items were secured pending forfeiture (Total approximate value is $1560.00):Jimmy Choo "I Want Choo" perfume bottle (valued at approximately $70.00)"Off-White" hooded sweatshirt (valued at approximately $300.00)MCM Munchen purse(H0063) (valued at approximately $990.00)Jordan 7 "Hare" GS (304774-125) size 7Y in a Jordan 11 box (valued at approximately $200.00)I completed all forfeiture paperwork.  All seized items were secured in evidence locker #7.I prepared complaint #223S2023-526 against Dais for violations of 2C:20-7a, 2C:17-6b, and 2C:28-7a(1).  I mailed the defendant's copy to the address on his license.

The vehicle was parked in the rear of 245 Anderson Street with a smashed out rear passenger window.  I observed the ignition to be popped.  A check of the New York license plates yielded that the vehicle was stolen on 9/25/2023 from NJ Institute of Technology Police at 0228.  The interior was wet from the persistent rain and the hood was cold.  The vehicle was impounded by All Points Towing.  The owner of the vehicle was notified.  An entry in the ATTF website was created for the recovery.  Headquarters sent a stolen vehicle confirmation to NJ Institute of Technology Police.P.O. Caneja responded to assist.

On 09/30/2023 at approximately 2211, I was on patrol in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 110.  While on patrol in the area of 90 Main Street, I observed a white Land Rover / Range Rover bearing Florida QXTI23 parked in the parking lot of 90 Main Street running with an occupant inside.  The parking lot of 90 Main Street is a quasi-public parking lot being used by a few different businesses in the area.  The parking lot is also improperly used by patrons of Koala Lounge.  As I pulled into the parking lot, Owusu observed my Radio Car.  Owusu immediately exited his vehicle and walked southbound on Main Street to City Lobster.  I conducted a check of the Florida Plate, which was registered to Davis.  A check of the VIN (salgs2rexks577363) associated with the vehicle yielded unusual vehicle history, commonly associated with a stolen vehicle that has a fictitious VIN.  I approached the vehicle to look at the public VIN in the windshield.  Based on my training and experience, I immediately recognized the public VIN sticker in the windshield to be fraudulent as it was the wrong type of material and lacked the necessary security features.        I requested a tow truck to open the vehicle so that I could conduct a probable cause search to locate the real VIN.  As All-Points Towing responded, Owusu exited Koala lounge and approached me.  I asked him if he had the keys to the car, which he affirmed.  He handed me the keys.  I advised Owusu that the vehicle was stolen and asked who it belong to, to which he stated his best friend, Davis.  I conducted a probable cause search of the vehicle.  The secondary VIN (salgs2re3ka537728) was located and confirmed to be stolen out of Brooklyn, NY.  I conducted a probable cause search of ly associated with a stolen vehicle that has a fictitious VIN.   I approached the vehicle to look at the public VIN in the windshield.  Based on my training and experience, I immediately recognized the public VIN sticker in the windshield to be fraudulent as it was the wrong type of material and lacked the necessary security features. the rest of the vehicle.  In the trunk, I located a large sized Keepall Bandouliere bag containing various clothing items and a pair of Nike Dunk low Industrial Blue (#DV0834-101 size 8.5).  No identification was located in the bag.  On the back seat, I located a medium sized OnTheGo Louis Vuitton bag containing a small blue box with small earrings (possible diamond earrings) and various clothing items.  No identification was located in this bag either.  Based on the vehicle being stolen with a fictitious VIN, higher-end purses in the vehicle, no identification with the belongings, a third party being in possession of the stolen vehicle, as well as my training and experience, I seized the two bags, shoes, and earrings as possible proceeds of criminal activity.          All Points Towing impounded the vehicle.  The vehicle was towed to Headquarters where I removed the fictitious VINs from the vehicle.  All Points then took the vehicle to their facility.          I secured the fictitious VIN stickers and the Florida registration for the fictitious VIN in a white envelope.  I secured the two earrings in the blue box in evidence control bag #5626419.  I secured the Nike sneakers in a brown bag.  I secured the earrings, sneakers, and medium sized OnTheGo bag in the large sized KeepAll bag.  I then secured all items in evidence locker #9.          Investigation to continue as I will be retrieving the Florida title application to see who initially titled the fictitious VIN.         I will be signing complaints against Davis for 2C:28-7 after I retrieve the title application with the possibility of additional charges for 2C:20-7a and 2C:17-6.

On Sunday, October 1, 2023, at approximately 1141 hours, I responded to 548 Hudson Street for a report of a blocked driveway. Upon my arrival, I observed a black Infiniti QX60 blocking the driveway of the residence. A computer search of the vehicle resulted in it being stolen out of Wayne, New Jersey. I spoke with the complainant, Theresa Smith. The complainant reported that she observed the vehicle to be parked blocking her driveway this morning but was advised by a relative that the vehicle was parked there at approximately 0100 hours.      Sgt. Williams responded. Communications confirmed the vehicle to be stolen out of Wayne, New Jersey. Wayne Police Department reported they did not want the vehicle processed. Sgt. Williams and I did a search of the vehicle which resulted in negative for contraband/weapons.       Brookside Towing responded and removed the vehicle from the roadway. See Tow Report.

On October 4, 2023, P.O. Rivera and I responded to the listed location on a report of parking complainants. Upon arrival, the parked vehicle bearing Arizona registration AM01395 was ran on info cop and it returned with the results of stolen. I notified dispatch to confirm the vehicle was stolen, Hackensack Auto Body responded and towed the vehicle.        It is to be noted that vehicle only had one license plate.

I responded to the listed location on a report of a recovered stolen vehicle.  Upon arrival I met with Ross Paladino from Polifly Towing, who stated he had recovered a stolen vehicle from Little Ferry, NJ.  Polifly Towing responded to 460 Liberty Avenue, Little Ferry, NJ 07643, to tow a vehicle that was on private property.  According to the complainant, Little Ferry Police Department does not ticket vehicles on private property.  When the complainant got back to the listed location, he contacted Little Ferry PD and asked them to run the VIN to make sure it was not a stolen vehicle.  Little Ferry PD was able to confirm the vehicle was reported stolen from Garfield, NJ.  The vehicle was recovered with only one plate in rear of the vehicle.  Dispatch was also able to confirm the vehicle was reported stolen from Garfield, NJ.  Garfield PD was contacted and did not want to proceed with finger prints.  The vehicle was left at the listed location.  The rear plate of the vehicle was secured into evidence in the traffic mailbox.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleSuspicious IncidentSuspicious Vehicle
column13: Suspects: 3 Males wearing ski masks and backpacks.     P.O. Tabares, P.O. Carrillo, Sgt. Briggs and I responded to the area of Polifly Road and Route 80 West on a report of a black Jeep Grand Cherokee dumped in the intersection by three (3) males in ski masks. The three (3) males were reported to have fled the area southbound on Polifly Road. P.O. Tabares and P.O. Carrillo checked the area for the three male parties. P.O. Francavilla responded to assist in checking the area.     Upon arrival, I observed an unoccupied 2021 black Jeep Grand Cherokee bearing NJ Reg: F10RRH parked in the middle of the roadway with its hazards on. As I approached the vehicle, I observed the front driver side tire appearing to be locked, with possible damage occurring while the vehicle was still in transit. A computer check of the vehicle's registration confirmed the vehicle to be properly registered with all visible VINs also returning to the vehicle. While on scene, I was advised by Sgt. Briggs, the vehicle was attempted to be reported stolen in Paterson, NJ; however, Mr. Ewen (the operator of the vehicle and company employee) was advised by the Paterson Police Department that due to not being the registered owner, he was unable to file a stolen motor vehicle report. Mr. Ewen responded to the scene and turned the vehicle key over to tow company.     Due to the vehicle being recovered stolen, parked hazardously in the roadway, and being disabled, a tow was requested to remove the vehicle. The vehicle was removed by Court House Towing. See Tow Report.      The listed vehicle was not entered into NCIC as stolen prior to the vehicle being recovered. Mr. Ewen was advised to receive a notarized letter allowing the vehicle to be released back to the business.    The details of the recovered motor vehicle were entered into the Auto Theft Task Force website.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleTampering: Public Records  2C:28-7Motor Vehicle Impound
column13: On 10/15/2023 at approximately 1007, I was on patrol in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 110.  I observed a Chevrolet Tahoe bearing Georgia temporary tag S1677137 parked more than 6 inches from the curb, in violation of 39:4-135, near 307 Prospect Avenue.  A check of the Georgia temp tag yielded that the VIN (1gnlcdec4kr281899) registered to a Gregory Ariste.  A public internet search yielded that the vehicle sustained heavy front end damage to the front end.  I exited my vehicle to look at the public VIN.  I immediately recognized the public VIN sticker to be fictitious based on my training and experience.  P.O. Almonte responded to assist.  Lin-Z Towing responded to impound the vehicle.  I located the secondary VIN (1gnskbkc0lr238055), which is on the outside of the vehicle, and confirmed that it was reported stolen out of NYPD.  Lin-Z towing opened the vehicle so that we could perform a probable cause search.  The following items were located in the vehicle:$157.00 in US currency in the center console and backpack located in the rear seat floor6-$100.00 gift cards (all of which were purchased in cash at the 7-11 on Polifly Road) located in the center console5 IPhones SE boxes with phones inside ($429.00 each)9 IPhones SE ($429.00 each) 1 Iphone 13 mini ($629.00)1 Iphone 6 ($649.00)5 IPhone SE empty boxes (Receipts for these paid in cash)1 IPhone X with blue case ($999.00)1 Apple Watch Series 5 with bands ($529.00)various SIM cards from various phone carriers3-Vanilla gift cards (balances of $0.00, $35.00, and $4.91)1 Gold Chain "bust down"1 gold bracelet "Bust down"1 silver necklace1 ring with a clear gemstone2 gold earrings with 24 small diamonds each1 gold Michael Kors watch (13atm, 251708) (Valued at approximately $275.00)two small replacement strands of diamonds (1 with 9 stones, 1 with 32 stones)1 Kith New Era NY Yankees hat (valued at approximately $180.00)1 New Era NY Yankees (Valued at approximately $42.00)1 New Era Green Philadelphia Athletics hat "Champions" (Valued at approximately $44.00).All above items were securedI also located approximately 36 grams of marijuana in various packages throughout the vehicle.  I located various items including New York State legal paperwork, credit cards, and receipts with Luis Morillo's information on them.  I removed all fictitious VINs including the federal certification label which was secured as evidence.  I also removed the fictitious Georgia temporary tag, as the VIN is fictitious.  The vehicle was impounded by Lin-Z.  Based on the vehicle being stolen with a fictitious VIN, the US currency (Both cash and gift cards), the receipts showing that most of the seized items were purchased in cash, the numerous cell phones, the numerous SIM cards, the various pieces of jewelry, the presence of 36 grams of marijuana throughout the vehicle in various packaging types, as well as my training and experience, I seized all of the previously listed items for forfeiture due to my belief that they were proceeds of criminal activity.  P.O. Almonte and I counted the US currency.  I completed all forfeiture paperwork.I signed complaint #0223S2023-581 against Morillo for violations of 2C:20-7a, 2C:17-6b, and 2C:28-7a.  I completed the recovery form in the ATTF website.The following items were secured in evidence locker #7:The fictitious VIN, GA temp tag, and GA registrationThe jewelry located in the vehicleThe iphones, boxes, watch, and sim cardsThe New Era hatsThe US currency and gift cardsThe forfeiture paperwork Morillo responded to Headquarters to try to get the car back.  Morillo was placed under arrest for the charges.  Morillo was processed and released with the court date.

column2: Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Recovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: The victim responded to Police Headquarters to report that his motor vehicle had been stolen. The victim stated that he last saw his vehicle approximately 10 days ago parked in the rear of 296 Main street. A computer check was done and it was determined that the vehicle was towed from the rear of 296 Main Street to Top Gun Towing. The victim was advised to contact the tow yard.

column2: Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Recovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: Suspects description: Suspect 1 gray hooded sweatshirt and black pants. Suspect 2 black hooded sweatshirt and black pants.      I responded to 99 Campbell Street for a motor theft that occurred at approximately 18:20 hours. The complainant stated the vehicle was parked and running in the driveway of 99 Campbell Street. When two suspects ran up to the vehicle, got in the vehicle, and drove away. The complainant further stated he captured the incident on the security cameras at the location and will e-mail me a copy of the footage. The complainant advised me the vehicle was located at Ackerson Street and Fair Street prior to my arrival at approximately 18:35 hours. The complainant and the victim did not want the vehicle to be processed, and nothing was taken from the vehicle. I completed a New Jersey Victim Notification form, and a copy was given to the victim.   Det. Tripodi was notified.

On November 22, 2023 at approximately 1120 hours I responded to C&L Auto Repair located at 141 Johnson Ave on a report of a stolen motor vehicle.  Upon arrival I was met by Ramon Garcia-Hernandez who stated one of his customer's vehicles was just stolen.  He stated that the suspect left behind a white scooter on the side of the building which he believed was stolen.I observed a white Honda scooter bearing NJ Reg (3PFG7) with a punched ignition. The registration which came back to a 1996 Honda Elite Scooter which was stolen earlier this morning out of this jurisdiction.  The scooter was not operable prior it it being stolen nor was it at this time. Mr. Garcia-Hernandez stated that the suspect which he described as a Hispanic male in his late 20's to earlier 30's wearing a white hooded sweatshirt, a grey winter cap and dark pants pushed the scooter south bound on Johnson Ave. into his lot.  The suspect asked to borrow tools and then went back to the scooter.  The suspect was lurking around the property for approximately 50 minutes before stealing a Mercedes Benz (ref case # 23-101963).The registered owner, Christopher Langford was notified and responded to the scene.  He stated that he wanted the vehicle processed and sign a consent to search form.  Hackensack Autobody was notified and responded to the scene.  The scooter was towed to Bergen County Sheriffs Department BCI Unit for processing.  Officer N. Marza towed the tow from the scene to the BCI building.The vehicle was removed from NCIC as stolen.

column2: Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Recovered Stolen Vehicle
