column13: On November 22nd, 2023 at approximately 1120 hours, I responded to C&L Auto Repair located at 141 Johnson Ave. on a report of a stolen vehicle.  Upon arrival I was met by Ramon Garcia-Hernandez who stated one of his customer's vehicles was just stolen from his lot. He stated the suspect pushed a scooter into his lot and then stole a Mercedes Benz that was left running.Mr. Garcia-Hernandez stated that he rents a garage bay at this location.  He stated he was working on his friend's silver 2004 Mercedes Benz S430 which was bearing an unknown NJ temporary tag.  He parked the vehicle on the south side of the building and left the vehicle running with the keys inside of the vehicle. At approximately 10:15 hours, the suspect which he described as a Hispanic male in his late 20's to early 30's wearing a white hooded sweatshirt with a logo on the front, a grey winter cap and dark pants came northbound on Johnson Ave. pushing a white scooter.  The suspect pushed the inoperable scooter into the lot of 141 Johnson Ave. and asked one of the mechanics for tools.  The employee gave the suspect a mallet and went back to work.  Mr. Garcia-Hernandez stated that the suspect lurked around the property for approximately 50 minutes.  He purchased a Black and Mild cigar from the gas station attendant and then went back to the scooter which was now near the parked Mercedez Benz.  At approximately 1110 hours, Mr. Garcia-Hernandez saw the suspect inside of the Mercedez Benz and asked him what he was doing.  The suspect told him that he was just taking it for a test drive and proceeded off the property with the vehicle.  The suspect made a left turn onto Johnson Ave. heading northbound to an unknown location.Mr. Garcia-Hernandez got into his vehicle and checked the location to see if he could locate the vehicle.  He was unable to locate the vehicle and responded back to the scene.  While on scene, Mr. Garcia-Hernandez was unable to provide a plate or Vin # to the vehicle at the time of the incident. He stated that temporary tag on the vehicle did not belong on that vehicle.  He further stated that the vehicle belonged to his friend Richard. Richard Banks was contacted via telephone who stated that the vehicle did not belong to him.  He stated that it belonged to one of his friends who just purchased the vehicle.  Mr. Bank's friend did not register the vehicle nor did he switch over the title.  Mr.  Banks was eventually able to provide a Vin # WDBNG70JX4A398383 which came back to Manahawkin Motors LLC.  Hackensack Police Dispatch broadcasted the vehicle over SPEN and entered the vehicle into NCIC as stolen.Det. P . Domingiuez was notified and responded to the scene.  He was able to review the surveillance footage showing the suspect.  Sgt. Butler also was notified and responded to the scene.While on scene, I ran the NJ Reg (3PFG7) that was on the white Honda Scooter.  The scooter was confirmed stolen out of this jurisdiction (Ref case # 23-101847).  The scooter that the suspect was seen pushing to the scene was towed to the Bergen County Sheriff BCI building for processing by Hackensack Auto Body.Prior to the report being complete, Hackensack Police was notified by NY/NJ Port Authority Police regarding the stolen vehicle.  They stated they found the vehicle abandon and unoccupied near the George Washington Bridge.  They towed the vehicle to their impound lot. The approximate value of the stolen vehicle is $10,000.00.

Suspect description: Unknown suspect approximately 5'7" in height, approximately 190 lbs in weight wearing a gray colored jacket, blue jeans and a black full face helmet.On 12/5/23 I responded to 310 Prospect Avenue on a reported attempted motor vehicle theft. Upon arrival I met with the victim, Tomas Lara, and the victim's son, Ryan Gomez. The victim then escorted me to the area his motorcycle was located. Upon observing the victim's motorcycle, New Jersey Registration 5LLH6, it was leaning on the wall at parking space number 233 with its headlights activated. The victim reported on 12/5/23 at approximately 20:18 hours he was driving in the parking garage of 310 Prospect Avenue, towards his assigned parking space. While driving towards his parking space he passed the suspect who was operating a motorcycle, which was identical to his. The victim reported his motorcycle was new and no other tenants in the building had his type of motorcycle. Upon responding to his parking space, Parking level G1 spot A72, the victim confirmed his motorcycle was stolen. The victim then turned around to follow the suspect. The victim then located his motorcycle abandoned in the parking garage, by space number 233.  the victim reported the suspect was able to start his motorcycle by bypassing the ignition switch. Upon inspecting the motorcycle I observed the carbon fiber ignition cover was lifted, which gave the suspect access to the ignition wire(s). The victim reported his motorcycle was not tampered with and it was unknown if the suspect was wearing gloves. The value of the motorcycle was $17,500.00. At this time the estimated value of damage to the victims motorcycle was unknown.  A supervisor was requested and Sgt. Butler responded. The Detective Bureau was later notified and Detective Sgt. Tripodi was advised of the incident. The victim was offered if he wanted to have his motorcycle processed, which he voluntarily accepted. The victim was explained of the process, which included a tow cost. A City of Hackensack Consent to the Taking of Latent Prints Form and a City of Hackensack Consent to Search Form were completed and read to the victim, which he signed. A tow was requested and Polifly Towing responded. Due to the motorcycle being in the parking garage and the parking garage having a low height clearance, making it inaccessible for the tow truck,  the motorcycle was pushed, by the victim's son, to the parking garage exit / entrance. The motorcycle was then towed to the Bergen County Sheriff's Department B.C.I. and turned over to Bergen County Sheriff's Department B.C.I. Detective Ham #1801, on 12/5/23 at 22:00 hours. See the Bergen County Sheriff's Department case number 2023-1156 for further. While first speaking to the victim he advised me he was currently armed with a handgun and had a concealed carry permit (Permit # 0223 00022). The victim also presented his identification card (confirmation # 22346688861 / SBI # 616882H). The victim also wanted to indicate on 10/22/23 he was shot multiple times during a robbery attempt, which occurred in Paterson New Jersey. The victim further reported during the robbery attempt he discharged his firearm, killing the suspect who shot him. The victim reported it was unknown if this incident had any connection with the incident that occurred in Paterson New Jersey.  A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed. Video surveillance cameras were present in the parking garage of 310 Prospect Avenue. See tow report for further.

While patrolling the area of Blanchard Terrace I observed Vehicle 1, parked facing east, with what appeared to be a lowered window. Upon further inspection, I discovered the window had been broken and the interior of the vehicle in disarray. The ignition system had been tampered with, the glovebox was ripped open and various panels in the car were pryed apart. I radioed headquarters this information and P.O. Vasquez responded to assist. The window vin was obscured, possibly on purpose. Using the VIN number on the door frame, headquarters confirmed the vehicle was out of New York. Tumino's Towing was dispatched to recover the vehicle.

On Tuesday, December 19, 2023, at approximately 10:54, I responded in marked radio car #117 to 102 Sussex Street for a report of a recovered stolen motor vehicle.  Upon arrival, I met with the complainant who stated that he purchased the listed vehicle off of Facebook Marketplace.       Headquarters confirmed that the vehicle was reported stolen on 11/02/2023 out of Paterson NJ.  The complainant stated that he met with a male party on 11/30/2023 in the area of 415 Howe Avenue in Passaic NJ to purchase the vehicle.  He further stated that he paid the party $3500.00 in cash and $500.00 through a Zelle transfer.  The Zelle transfer was paid to the name Flor Almonte and had two phone numbers associated with the bank account (973-836-3784 and 973-847-6647).  The complainant was given a fraudulent title which was secured as evidence along with the vehicle registration (see evidence report for further).  The complainant showed me photographs of the male party that he took on his phone when he purchased the vehicle.  The complainant was advised to send the photos to my departmental e-mail.  Sgt. Briggs was advised and responded on scene.The vehicle was towed by Court House Towing. See Tow report for further.The vehicle was entered in the Auto Theft Task Force web site as a recovered stolen vehicle.  The stolen motor vehicle checklist was completed and submitted to detectives.

column2: Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Recovered Stolen VehicleBurglary  2C:18-2
column13: I responded to the listed location on a reported motor vehicle theft. Upon arrival, I spoke with the victim. He stated that on 12/22/2023 at approximately 17:00 hours, he had parked his vehicle in front of 203 Anderson Street, facing east. He further stated that when he returned to the area on 12/23/2023, he noticed that his vehicle was missing. The victim stated that no family members or friends had access to the vehicle and that he was in possession of both key fobs. Sgt. Williams arrived on scene to assist and began canvassing the area for the vehicle. While gathering additional information, Sgt. Williams advised that he located the vehicle in front of 290 Hamilton Place, facing west.               I arrived at Sgt. Williams' location and confirmed that the vehicle in our view belonged to the victim. I then responded back to the victim's address and transported him to his vehicle. After confirming that he did not want the vehicle processed, the victim took inventory of his belongings inside the vehicle. It should be noted that the steering column had been ripped off and the ignition system was heavily damaged. The victim reported that he was missing his Apple Watch, valued at $350.00, but confirmed all other possessions were accounted for.            A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed and provided to the victim. A Motor Vehicle Theft checklist was also completed. No cameras were located in the area of the original theft.            The victim was advised on how to obtain a copy of this report.

On 1/12/2024 at approximately 0115, I was on patrol in full Police uniform in marked Radio Car 110.  While in the area of Mercer Street next to 150 Main Street, I observed a 2023 Honda CRV bearing Pennsylvania plate MJJ2525 parked.  A check of the plate yielded that the vehicle was entered stolen by the Pennsylvania State Police for being titled with a fictitious title.  I conducted a check of the VIN (5j6rs6h92pl056323) through a commercial database and I immediately recognized the VIN to be fictitious.  I then looked at the public windshield VIN which I observed to be fictitious.  P.O. McCarthy, P.O. Lopez-Amaya, and P.O. Anguizaca responded to assist.                 Hackensack Towing responded to impound the vehicle.  Based on the vehicle having a fictitious Vin, Hackensack Towing unlocked the vehicle.  A probable cause search was conducted and the confidential VIN was located (5j6rs6h90pl010117).  The VIN was reported stolen on 10/13/2023 by the New York City Police Department.   I removed all fictitious VINs from the vehicle.  The vehicle was impounded by Hackensack Towing.  Located in the vehicle was an insurance card and the fraudulent Pennsylvania registration.

On this date I was dispatched to the listed location on a report of a recovered stolen motor vehicle. The complainant, Lilybeth Urena, was able to track the vehicle utilizing an app from Mercedes Benz. A check of the license plate and VIN confirmed that the vehicle was reported stolen out of Ridgefield Park, NJ. The registered owner of the vehicle, Rafeal Charles (the complainant's husband) arrived on scene. The R.O. informed me that he did not wish to have the vehicle processed for evidence. Headquarters   contacted the Ridgefield Park Police Department and they authorized the release of the vehicle to the R.O. The R.O. reported that no damage was observed on the vehicle and that no items, other than loose change and possibly the key fob, were missing from the interior of the vehicle. A Ryobi Leaf Blower was located in the vehicle, it was secured as found property, See Property Report. Headquarters notified Ridgefield Park PD so that the vehicle, NCIC #V625770275, could be removed as a stolen vehicle, prior to the vehicle being released. See Ridgefield Park PD's OCA 2024-00559 for further.

I responded to the listed location on report of an attempted burglary. Upon my arrival I met with the victim who pointed out damage to the drivers side keyhole to vehicle one. The victim informed me that yesterday (1/26/24) he noticed white powder on the inside of the key hole location and noticed damage to the face of the locking mechanism. The victim estimates the damage to be about $200.00.      The victim informed me that he noticed the damage to the vehicle yesterday (1/26/24) but continued to drive it throughout the day contaminating the scene and therefore unable to have it processed. The victim also stated that it appears that no access was gained to his vehicle and nothing appeared to be missing from it.      The vehicle was parked in parking space # 90 which is on the East side of the building.      A victim notification form was completed which the victim initialed and was given a copy.

On this date Sgt. Peralta, P.O. Caneja and I were dispatched to the listed location on a report of a recovered stolen motorcycle. The motorcycle was reported stolen in Ridgefield Park. Upon arrival we were able to locate the motorcycle, no registration, parked in the rear lot of 288 State Street. The owner of the motorcycle, Abdulkafi Najjar, was on scene with the motorcycle. Shortly after our arrival Det. Vansaders #163 of the Ridgefield Park Police Department arrived on scene. The motorcycle was turned over to the detective. The detective believes that Youssef Belkhir may be a suspect in the theft. According to residents on scene, the suspect may reside in room #6 of that building. There is not further pedigree information on the suspect at this time.

On this date P.O. DeBonis, P.O. A. Rios, P.O. A. Lopez and I were dispatched to the listed location on a report of an attempted theft of a catalytic converter.  Upon arrival we met with the victim, Francesco Cutri. He informed us that at 0552 hours he heard a noise coming from the area of his vehicle. which was parked on the street in front of his house. He further stated that he went to investigate and observed 2 males, dressed in all black with black masks, near his vehicle, One of the males was under his vehicle, which was jacked up, using a power tool to cut the catalytic converter. Once confronted the two males lowered  the car from the jack, and entered a dark colored sedan, possibly a Honda. The vehicle was operated by a third male, also dressed in all black. The victim attempted to take a picture of the vehicle with his cellphone, it was at this time one of the males pushed the victim, causing him to stumble back but not lose his balance, the victim did not report any injury. Once in the suspect vehicle, the suspects fled backwards south on Kent Street, The victim did not observe which direction on Mary Street the suspects turned. The victim stated that the suspects all spoke Spanish.    A neighbor, Israel Compre  151 Kent Street, captured the incident on his doorbell camera. The captured video is not clear. The neighbor was instructed to forward the video to my departmental e-mail. Video cameras were also observed at 150 Kent Street as well as 156 Kent Street.    A canvas of the area proved negative for the suspects.   A NJ Victim Notification Form was completed and provided to the victim.    Sgt. Butler was notified and contacted the detectives.    The victim did not wish to have the vehicle processed for evidence. He also declined to provide a statement to detectives.    Insurance information: New Jersey Manufactures Insurance, Code #426, Policy # F111946-0   The vehicle's catalytic converters were not removed but damaged due to the attempted removal. Cost of repair is not known at this time.

column2: Criminal Attempt  2C:5-1Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Criminal Mischief - Vehicle - 2C:17-3
column13: On Sunday, February 11, 2024 at approximately 1035 hours while traveling north on Thompson Street I observed a purple charger with the right rear window missing. As I approached to investigate I got flagged down by Kimberley Jones (victim) who reported that an unknown individual had shattered her right rear passenger window. The victim reported that she parked vehicle bearing NJ Reg. G87NAH on Friday, February 9, 2024 at approximately 1645 hours and returned on 2/11/2024 when her neighbor informed her of the broken window. The victim reported that this was the second time that her rear window had been broken. The victim further reported that she wished to have her vehicle processed. A supervisor was requested and Sgt. Briggs responded.     The victim reported that she had a security camera facing the listed vehicle's location and footage is available. No other cameras were observed in the area. The victim did not know if any items were stolen at this time due to the vehicle needing to be processed.      The listed vehicle was parked curbside on Thompson Street, facing north, approximately twenty (20) feet from Cambridge Terrace. The shattered window was located by the right rear passenger door which was held together by the window's tint.      The victim reported the amount to fix the right rear window at approximately $300.00.     A New Jersey Victim Notification Form was completed and a copy provided to the victim. A Hackensack Police Consent to Search Vehicle for was completed and signed by the victim. A tow was requested to transport the vehicle to Bergen Coutny Sheriff's B.C.I.     Court House Towing responded and towed the listed vehicle. At B.C.I. I met with Bergen county Det. Lasala #1866. See B.C.I. case #2024-0132 for further.     Release vehicle to Court House Towing.No insurance information available at this time.

On February 15, 2024, P.O. Han and I responded to Green Street south side parking lot, located across from 144 Green Street, on a report of 2 recovered stolen motor vehicles.   See OCA #24-014451 for the other vehicle's information.       Upon arrival, I spoke to the Code Enforcement Officer, Dean Matalian, who located the vehicles.  Vehicle 1 was found parked in Space 19 facing west with the following listed parts missing:     1. All four tires and rims.     2. Hood.      3. Front bumper.     4. Front driver side fender.     5. Front passenger side fender.     6. Airbag in the steering wheel. Vehicle 1 also has unknown amount of damage caused during the removal of above listed parts.  See Tow Report for further information.      Sgt. Meneses was notified and responded to the scene.  Det. Dogali also responded for further investigation.

On February 15, 2024, P.O. Han and I responded to Green Street south side parking lot, located across from 144 Green Street, on a report of 2 recovered stolen motor vehicles.   See OCA #24-014448 for the other vehicle's information.       Upon arrival, I spoke to the Code Enforcement Officer, Dean Matalian, who found the vehicles.  Vehicle 1 was found parked in Space 13 facing west with the following listed parts missing:     1. All four tires and rims.     2. Hood.      3. Front bumper.     4. Front driver side fender.     5. Front passenger side fender.     6. Airbag in the steering wheel.      7. Front passenger side door.     8. Rear passenger side door.Vehicle 1 also has unknown amount of damage caused during the removal of above listed parts.  See Tow Report for further information.      Sgt. Meneses was notified and responded to the scene.  Det. Dogali also responded for further investigation.

While on patrol, I observed the listed vehicle parked on Clarendon Place facing south, just south of Anderson Street.  I knew the vehicle to be stolen as P.O. Mazzaccaro was actively taking the report for it being stolen.  I advised Police Headquarters of my location and Sgt. Briggs was dispatched due to the registered owner wanting it to be held for fingerprinting.  The vehicle had both front and rear passenger side windows shattered and the ignition was damaged.  The vehicle has no major damage and both license plates were still on the vehicle.  The overall condition of the vehicle was captured on my BWC.  Hackensack Auto Body was notified, responded and towed the vehicle to the Bergen County Sheriff's Department BCI Garage while I followed with my dashboard camera activated.  The vehicle was turned over to BCSD BCI Detective M. Anastasio #1766.  See BCI Case 2024-0161 for further.  I completed a Recovered Vehicle Form on the NJ Auto Theft Task Force site.  See Tow Report for further.

On Wednesday, February 21, 2024, at approximately 19:35 hours, P.O. Fahri and I responded to 113 Main Street on a report of a stolen vehicle that was reported earlier today. Sgt. Dalton also responded. Upon arrival, I observed the vehicle to be unoccupied. A check of the listed vehicles registration was conducted along with its vehicle identification number. The results of the search confirmed that it was the same vehicle reported stolen.     It should be noted that the vehicle was originally reported stolen from in front of 91 Main Street (Koala Lounge) which is only a few addresses away from where it was recovered. Lt. Klosk spoke with the victim over the phone and she confirmed that she changed her mind from her original report and now wanted the listed vehicle processed by  Bergen County Bureau of Criminal Investigations. Soon after, All Points Towing responded and removed the listed vehicle to BCI garage, while I followed. Upon arrival to BCI, the vehicle was turned over to Det. Dana Caratozzolo #1858. See BCI case number 2024-0165 for further.         ** Note: Consent to Search form still needs to be signed by victim and BCI needs to be provided with a copy**

On 2/27/2024, I was requested by Detectives to assist with conducting a search of a 2019 Honda CRV that was suspected to have a fictitious VIN.  Detective Sgt. Bay, P.O. Morton, and I responded to the Old Police Garage to execute the search on a 2019 Honda CRV (VIN: 5j6rw2h84l029122) bearing Georga temporary tag S1808216.  I activated my body worn camera.  I opened the door and I immediately recognized the federal certification label to be fictitious due to my training and experience.  I then checked the secondary VIN, which I also recognized was fictitious.  A component number was located in the vehicle, which I was able to confirm belonged to a 2019 Honda CRV (VIN: 2hkrw2h82kh658226) which was reported stolen on 2/12/2024 from New York.  I removed all fictitious VINs from the vehicle and provided them to Detective Sgt. Bay to be secured.  Upon removing the public VIN label sticker, the real VIN sticker label was still present showing the correct VIN.  The search was concluded.

On 2/28/2024 at approximately 1600, I was on patrol in Police uniform in marked Radio Car 110.  While on patrol, I observed a black Cadillac Escalade bearing NJ H57PPX with no front license plate parked near 82 Main Street.  A check of the registration yielded the VIN 1GYS4BKJ9KR743618.  A check of that VIN through a Police database yielded unusual VIN history, with the VIN first being titled in Pennsylvania.  A check of the Pennsylvania DMV yielded that the title was issued by a Beltin Auto Sales.  I have previously recovered numerous vehicles that were stolen with fictitious VINs where the fraudulent titles were obtained through Beltin Auto Sales.  I then exited my vehicle to look at the public VIN sticker.  Based on my training and experience, I immediately recognized the public VIN sticker to be fictitious.  Based on the unusual VIN history, the fictitious public VIN sticker, as well as my training and experience, I had probable cause to believe that the vehicle was stolen with a fictitious VIN.  I requested a tow truck to respond to assist in my investigation by gaining entry to the vehicle so that I could identify the real VIN.  Hackensack Towing responded and unlocked the vehicle.  I immediately recognized the federal VIN sticker to be fictitious.  I removed this sticker.  I was able to locate the real VIN which was reported stolen by the Port Authority Police Department (Laguardia) on 11/16/2020.  I conducted a probable cause search on the remainder of the vehicle.  Inside the vehicle I located a blank check (PNC Bank Mama Elena's Restaurant LLC, account #8137924155, check #1108).  I believe that this check may be fraudulent based on various identifiers.  The check was secured.  I also secured all fraudulent New Jersey registration paperwork as well as insurance paperwork that were in the vehicle.Hackensack Towing impounded the vehicle and brought it to Headquarters where I removed the license plate and the fictitious public VIN sticker.  Hackensack Towing then impounded the vehicle to their impound lot.I secured all paperwork, registration paperwork, and insurance paperwork in evidence locker #8.   The check was turned over to Det. Sgt. Tripodi.The vehicle was worth approximately $38925.00.Investigation to follow.

On Thursday, March 7, 2024, at approximately 0722 hours I responded Henry Place and Hudson Street on a reported suspicious vehicle. I spoke with the complainant, who works at 476 Hudson Street. He reported that a suspicious vehicle was already parked on Henry Place and left with the engine running at approximately 0600 hours when his coworkers went into work. A check of the vehicle's registration came back with negative results for it being stolen. The suspicious vehicle was a silver Hyundai Sonata parked facing East on Henry Place with signs of forced entry. I observed the rear passenger window to be shattered and the plastic underneath the steering column to be damaged. I notified communications. The vehicle was registered to an address in Elizabeth NJ. Elizabeth PD was notified to make contact with the registered owner, who after being notified, confirmed that the vehicle was stolen. The surveillance cameras did not appear to be functioning at 476 Hudson Street. Per Elizabeth Police Departments request the vehicle was impounded, Lin-Z Towing responded and removed the vehicle from the roadway. See tow report for further.   This incident may be in connection to report 24-020771. See P.O. Salas' report for further information.

column2: Motor Vehicle ImpoundWeapons - Unlawful Purposes 2C:39-4Recovered Stolen License Plate
column13: On 3/8/2024 at approximately 1944, I was on patrol in Police uniform in marked Radio Car 110.  While in the area of 90 Main Street, I observed a white Mercedes Benz AMG C63s parked facing northbound bearing NY KYE4726 with a dark license plate cover.  Every window of the vehicle was darkly tinted.  A check of the license plate yielded that it belonged to a Mini Cooper.  I approached the vehicle to see the public VIN in the windshield.  The vehicle had a hangtag (Hackensack Gardens, LLC #175) completely obstructing the VIN.  I requested a tow truck to respond.  P.O. Price also responded to assist.  I removed the rear license plate to secure it.  Upon removing the license plate, I observed the letter "E" was actually an "L" with two pieces of tape altering the letter.  A check of the license plate "KYL4726" yielded that the registration was suspended.  The rear VIN sticker placed by Mercedes Benz was removed from the vehicle.              It should be noted that on 11/9/2023 at approximately 2320, I attempted to stop a white Mercedes Benz AMG C63s in front of 337 Main Street  bearing New Jersey "ST0L3N", however the vehicle took off from the motor vehicle stop (case #23-098516).        As P.O. Price and I were looking at the vehicle, I utilized my flashlight and observed a brown and black bag with a black strap visible on the rear seat.  The bag was in the shape of a firearm, which is commonly used by persons to carry a concealed firearm in a designer bag.  I observed a pair of men's sneakers on the passenger seat, and the driver's seat was pushed back away from the steering wheel.  Also observed on the driver's side quarter panel and rear bumper were two bullet holes (one in each).             Based on the bullet holes in the vehicle, the fictitious/altered registration, the concealment of the public VIN,  the designer bag that appeared to be in the shape of a firearm, along with my training and experience, I believed that there was a firearm in the vehicle that was not being stored properly for transport, along with other evidence of criminal activity.  I requested a patrol/explosives K-9.  While we were waiting for the K-9, I observed the vehicle being manually locked two separate times by a remote key fob.  This action raised my suspicion that someone in the area was observing our actions, and would make an attempt to gain access to the vehicle.  Based on my heightened awareness, I observed  a dark skinned male wearing a blue hooded sweatshirt walked past the vehicle twice.  S.O. O'Neill #1685 and his K-9 "Max" arrived on scene.  S.O. O'Neill and K-9 conducted a sweep (case #BS-24-018967) which did not result in a  positive indication.  I then requested a narcotics K-9, and S.O. Moussavian #1730 and K-9 "Cash" responded.  S.O. Moussavian and his partner conducted a sweep of the vehicle (case #BS-24-018971).  S.O. Moussavian advised that his K-9 indicated on the vehicle.  During one of the K-9 sweeps, I observed the same male with a blue hooded sweatshirt walk past a third time.Based on the bullet holes on the vehicle,  the fictitious/altered registration, the concealment of the public VIN, the designer bag that appeared to be in the shape of a firearm, my training and experience, the positive indication by a narcotics K-9, and belief that there was an individual in the area with a key to the vehicle, a probable cause search was conducted.  As I initiated my search I checked underneath the driver's seat.  I located a black handle Interarms model M720 .44 S&W caliber handgun (serial #AB106117) un-holstered underneath the seat.  The firearm was loaded with 5 hollow-point .44 S&W rounds.   In the designer bag (Christian Dior) on the back seat was two passports belonging to Carlos Taveras as well as a Louis Vuitton small zipper style bag.  Inside of this bag was a social security card belonging to Carlos Taveras, a New York benefits card for Carlos Taveras, a CitiBank debit card for Carlos Taveras, 2 New York birth certificates, three pawn slips and a ABM work id with Carlos Taveras information and photo on it.  There were also 5 .44 s&w hollow point rounds in the bag.  The hang tag which was blocking the public VIN from Hackensack Gardens, LLC bearing #175 was removed and secured. P.O. Price located two rounds in a green bag in the glove box (1 round .40 s&w hollow point ammo, 1 round of 9mm luger ammo) as well as one watch and one chain.  In the center console, P.O. Price located one more watch and two chains. Inside the trunk were the following items:3 boxes of .44 S&W ammo containing 25 hollow point rounds each1 box of .44 S&W ammo containing 15 hollow point rounds6 boxes of 9mm ammo (each containing 50 ammo)1 box of 9mm ammo (containing 19 rounds)1 box of 9mm ammo (containing 43 rounds) 1 33 round 9mm magazine for a Glock1 80+ round 9mm magazine for a Glock13 rounds of 9mm ammo(one of the boxes of ammo was in a white sneaker in the trunk, the remainder was in a yellow bag)5 New York license plates that were all entered as stolen: KXW7162, KVY5948, DJV7258, KEX3075, HTH27411 New York license plate KTS72391 New York license plate KYL4726Vanity license plate NJ ST0L3NVanity license plate NY FUCK 12partial license plate New York SB3937Also located in the vehicle were 3 pawn receipts from a Bronx Pawnbroker INC with the name "Carlos Taveras" and address of "2314 Valentine Apt #45, Bronx, NY 10458"List of jewelry:1 Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Offshore (N0440, 1 205890) busted down watch1 Audemars Piguet (N17020, J16709) busted down watch1 chain busted down with a ring and a fish pendant "Z$5"1 chain busted down1 chain (1 watch, 1 chain center console) (1 watch 2 chains glove box)Also in the vehicle were more men's sneakers which were left in the vehicle.All evidence items were secured in evidence locker #8.All items were photographed with the Patrol camera.  C.O. Gervasi entered all e-trace related information into the system.Investigation to continue to determine who was operating the vehicle.

column2: Criminal Attempt  2C:5-1Burglary - Auto - 2C: 18-2Suspicious Person
column13: P.O. Tedesco and I responded to the listed location on a report of a suspicious person. Upon arrival, I spoke to the victim, Osman Ramos, who stated a black male was trying to open his car door (NJ/U35RUH). The victim stated the suspect later identified as Jermaine Thompson had walked away heading East on Berdan Place so I advised Headquarters and P.O. Almonte started checking the area. The victim then explained that he was inside his house when his car alarm started going off. He looked outside the window and saw a black male wearing a gray beanie, a black jacket, gray sweat pants, and black sneakers trying to open his car door. The complainant started yelling out the window telling him to stop and the suspect walked up onto his porch and stated "I can open any car I want" and walked away. The victim then showed me footage from his home camera and I observed the suspect pulling on the door handle multiple times, walk onto his porch, and then walking away.     P.O. Almonte stated he was out with a party on Central Ave. and First St. that matched the description. I responded to the location and identified the suspect through the victim's video. The suspect was  placed under arrest and handcuffed with his hands behind his back and a searched incident to arrest yielded negative results. P.O. Almonte  placed the arrestee in the rear of Radio Car #111 and transported him to headquarters.  The rear of Radio Car #111 was searched prior to transport and upon arrival at headquarters with negative results for contraband.  At Police Headquarters the suspect was brought into OD room west and searched again. I responded to Police Headquarters and processed the arrestee.  The arrestee was released at approximately 2349 hours without any further incident.The victim's  video footage was e-mailed to detectives@hackensackpd.orgA victim notification form was completed.Complaints (#S0223-2024-000183) were signed against Jermaine Thompson for attempted burglary (2C18-2A(1) (3rd degree) and 2C:5-1A(1)

On March 29, 2024 at approximately 08:35 hours, while on patrol in the area of 375 RT 17 South, I received a notification from LOJACK of a stolen vehicle signal in the area. The LOJACK displayed code #G890R. I contacted communications where they advised me the code came back to a Green Honda Accord bearing NJ-J62UJB. I did a search of the area and was able to locate the vehicle in the parking lot of 417 RT 17 South.         The vehicle was unoccupied at the time and was parked between two tractor trailers. There appeared to be no heavy damage to the exterior of the vehicle and appeared drivable. Both plates were on the vehicle and the keys were inside.     Communications was able to confirm the stolen vehicle out of Paterson, NJ. The case number out of Paterson is 0688-24V-030612.     Court House Towing responded to the scene and removed the vehicle.     See Tow Report.

On March 29, 2024 at approximately 11:53 hours, while on patrol in the area of English St, I received an alert from the License Plate Reader on RC #112 of a stolen vehicle. The plate flagged by the LPR was NJ- C76SWP registered to a 2012 White Honda Pilot. I contacted communications and they were able to confirm the stolen vehicle out of Ridgefield Park, NJ on 03/22/2024.     The vehicle was parked outside of 125 English St. There appeared to be no heavy damage to the vehicle and the vehicle appeared drivable. The keys were also found on the front windshield.      Ridgefield Park PD was notified. They contacted the owner and the owner did not want the vehicle processed.    The original case number out of Ridgefield Park is #2024-03034.   The NCIC number is  NIC/ V575879948.   Court House towing responded to the scene and removed the vehicle.   See tow report.

column2: Motor Vehicle Theft  2C:20-3Recovered Stolen Vehicle
column13: On Sunday April 7th, 2024 at approximately 20:36 hours, I responded to 55 Linden Street ( My China Cafe) on a report of a stolen motor vehicle. Upon arrival, I was met by the victim. The victim stated that that he parked his vehicle directly outside of My China Cafe, while he went to grab orders for delivery from within the above mentioned establishment. The victim further reported that when he returned to his vehicle, he observed his vehicle to be traveling south bound on Linden Street  to which the vehicle then made a left turn through the Walgreens parking lot and continued to flee the scene in an unknown direction.   Through further investigation, the victim stated that he left the vehicle idling with the doors unlocked, however, the keys were within his possession, due to the vehicle having a "push to start" ignition system. The victim stated that he was unable to identify the suspects description due to the distance between the location from where the incident took place and where he last saw the vehicle traveling. The victim further reported that both NJ license plates (K86NNV) were attached to his vehicle prior to the vehicle beings stolen.   While obtaining the information from the victim, I then discovered two cameras attached to the exterior of the building which were pointing in the direction of were the crime took place. I then made contact with the landlord, Greg, who stated that he could not respond at the moment, however, he would contact us the next calendar day and provide us with the footage upon our request. The victim was advised of his rights and provided with victim notification form which was completed. The victim was afforded the opportunity the have B.C.I process the vehicle to which he ultimately declined. In addition, the Motor Vehicle check list was completed while on scene. The victim did wish to pursue with criminal complaints in the event that the suspects can be identified.    I then responded to headquarters to complete the proper documentation of this incident. Once at headquarters, It was brought to my attention that P.O. Koenig had already located the vehicle prior to in being entered into any system as stolen. Please refer to P.O. Koenig's report for further details.

column2: Recovered Stolen VehicleMotor Vehicle Theft 2C:20-3
column13: On Friday, May 10, 2024, at approximately  13:30 hours, I responded to 88 McKinley Street on a report of a stolen motor vehicle. While en route, headquarters advised me that the listed vehicle ( NJ- N20GTX)was recovered by Maywood Police. Upon arrival, I spoke with the victim who reported that, at approximately 00:30 hours, he parked the listed vehicle behind the listed address, in space 5. He further reported that when he returned, at approximately 12:30 hours, the listed vehicle was missing. The victim added that, he left the listed vehicle unlocked and left the keys inside. The victim indicated that shortly after discovering the listed vehicle was missing, he received a phone call from Maywood Police. They advised him that they discovered the listed vehicle parked on Essex Street, unoccupied. At the time, Maywood PD believed the listed vehicle was disabled and had it towed. The victim did not want the listed vehicle processed. A New Jersey Victim Notification form was completed and a copy was provided to the victim. The listed vehicle in valued at approximately $3,000.00.    Two surveillance cameras, mounted on the rear of 101 Hobart, were aimed space 5, However, I was advised that they only record live feed. No other surveillance cameras were seen in the area.

Suspect Descriptions: 1 Male, wearing black pants and a black jacket, unknown race.                                                  1 Woman, H/F or W/F, wearing a pink jacket, black pants and white shoes.       The complainant responded to headquarters to report a suspicious incident. He stated that on 05/10/2024, he had returned to his vehicle and discovered the passenger side door handle loose. He further stated that he reviewed camera footage from his car and discovered the following:  The two suspects walk up to his vehicle. The male suspect begins pulling on the door handle while on his phone, while the female suspect uses her cell phone to take pictures/video of the complainants vehicle. The complainant reported that no entry was made into the vehicle and that the suspects left out of his car's camera view after a few seconds.       The complainant stated that he was unsure of the cost to repair his door handle, but estimates it to be around $100.00. The complainant has vehicle insurance with Safe Co Insurance, but could not provide insurance details at this time.    The complainant stated that he only wanted this incident documented. He was advised on how to obtain a copy of this report. Furthermore, he was advised to send video of the incident to my department e-mail, when available.
